CHAPTER ONE
The Workshop of Filthy Creation

It was quieter in Paris today, though the riots have left scars. Half the ground-floor windows have boards over broken panes and there are holes in the street where cobblestones have been gouged up to use as missiles. After a night in the library I made my way home by the Place Maubert, in hope the baker would have macaroons again, but his shutters were closed, drips of fresh paint proclaiming his pride in the tricolour. It could merely be a ploy to avoid having his shop ransacked, I suppose, but everywhere now you will see such displays of revolutionary fervour.
I'm on my way back to my lodgings. Will you walk with me?

Yes.

We can cut through these back streets. It's not even ten minutes' walk from here. Or perhaps you would prefer the scenic route?

xoptx The short cut is fine.

xoptx By all means let's see the sights.

That's better. I love following these narrow alleys. You can emerge half a mile from where you set out and it's as if you've burrowed through space and time. And, of course, it's a relief to get away from the teeming crowds. Just keep your wits about you. While the law is busy rounding up aristocrats, common thieves have been flourishing.
Well now, if you're new to Paris, there's a sight for you: the Panthéon. An extraordinary tomb, is it not, all for one man? The statesman Mirabeau is buried there. A hundred thousand tonnes of stone to proclaim what any child can write as enduringly with a knife in the bark of a tree: "I was here". That's how much men fear, not death, but being forgotten.
What were we talking about? Ah yes, macaroons. There was a crowd outside the store, mostly women with empty baskets. They must have known the bakery would not open today, but it gives them a place to talk. And these are days when there is much to talk about. It is as though the air carries a charge, a vital spark that forces the heart to beat quicker. And the haze over the city now that autumn is here - dust from all the crowds, of course, but shining like the golden clouds that shroud Olympus.
A girl caught my arm. She had a tray of cockades, knots of cheap gaudy ribbons on a pin. 'Every citizen must wear one,' she said, and her eyes were so wide and bright. Hope and fear... Which is at the forefront, I wonder?

xoptx People are excited by the future

xoptx People are anxious

Yes, I feel it too. What a time to be alive! All of history to this moment has been lived in the childhood of Mankind, and now we have come to childhood's end. For there is no natural law that places one man on a throne and another at his feet. Such an order is the grossest violation of natural law, where the only true authority flows from reason. The people have arrested their tyrant, and now they have the power to shape their own future. That look in their eyes - it is the same excitement I felt when, stepping from the carriage that brought me from Geneva four years ago, I first stood before the university gates. That's why I bought the cockade even though - look, the ghastly cheap thing has already come unravelled.

What is your name?

No doubt you are right. I see the mirror of my own feelings in everyone I pass, their eyes shining with hope and fear - for the one always contains the other. You could never mistake it for the sleepy amiability of my native Geneva.

xoptx These are dangerous times

xoptx What is your name?

xoptx It would be better if you went home

I see you are unfamiliar with life in Geneva. It is all very fine if you are a cow with a bell about its neck - or a well-fed merchant, which amounts to much the same. Yet the future is a coming storm, and whether we go out to confront it boldly, or hide behind our shutters, it will sweep over us just the same. These people of Paris who pass by us - yes, there is fear in their eyes. But courage too. Their Revolution is a flame that will set the world alight - Geneva too - and from the ashes a new and better era will rise. I passionately believe that. It is the precept that has guided my studies from the mire of medievalism towards the shining city on the hill.

What is your name?

You must understand that here the people have suffered under the most appalling tyranny. It is not so long ago that philosophers were burned alive with their books, at the decree of an absolute monarch whose whims were as irresistible as death. A man might starve for want of a crust of bread, while another could choose to keep eating until he was sick.
And now the royal family has been seized by the mob, and all Europe is in outcry. But you should see it simply as a chemical reaction that had long been out of equilibrium. In restoring it to a placid state, reagents have been added that swing it the other way - unshaven guards outside the Tuileries, men who cannot read or write appointed as court judges. Yes, there are riots. It is the unknown that lies ahead, and the unknown is what men fear. But I have confidence that reason will prevail. It must. Men are not animals.

What is your name?

Why, what a question. Surely you know me?

Of course, you are Baron Frankenstein.

Baron? I am no aristocrat! Just plain Victor Frankenstein, the son of a Geneva magistrate. Our family is respected and I daresay we are more fortunate than most, but we are hardly noblemen. Which is just as well, since the National Assembly has abolished the nobility and even the Duke of Orléans nowadays styles himself 'Citizen Philip Equality'.

xoptx A brave new world!

xoptx The mob drags everyone down to their level

xoptx What about your family?

Indeed. Let me ask you something, my friend. What are the greatest accomplishments of Man? We could list the cathedral at Chartres, the Sistine Chapel, Allegri's Miserere. But all of these great works are tarnished, in my eyes, for they do not advance understanding. They merely celebrate what already is - and that celebration, not of the glory of Man, but of myth.
Now consider the events that are sweeping across the world. A spirit of confidence, optimism, bold enquiry. Men dare now. In my own endeavours, I seek discoveries as revolutionary as those of Copernicus and Columbus. It isis a new world - a time in which mankind can storm the gates of Eden and take for ourselves a seat in paradise. You quoted Shakespeare - let me assure you, I will 'wake the sleepers with my so potent art'.
But the thoroughfare is not the place to discuss matters of such weight. See, I allowed my words to become heated and a crowd gathers. Later, later.

xoptx Let's talk about something else.

xoptx What sleepers? Who would you wake?

See those guardsmen in their red liberty caps? How they would scowl if you spoke to them of 'the King'. To them he is now simply Citizen Louis Capet - or perhaps 'Louis the Last'. But I ask you, how can a man of any worth be lessened by stripping away titles and signs of rank and privilege? They are just tokens, they don't define a person. Could you not equally say that the Revolution ennobles all of us? What a man makes of himself can now be determined by his nature, not by the accident of birth.

xoptx 'Not in our stars, but in ourselves'?

xoptx And what accident of birth have you escaped?

You may have heard Citizen Fouché's favourite dictum, 'Death is an eternal sleep'? No? Well, in any case I was speaking figuratively. The dissecting room and the charnel house supply many of my materials, but my goal is not to bring the dead to life. It is - But no, not here. Later I will show you.

xoptx You seem very agitated.

xoptx How long have you been engaged in your work?

Yes, I have been working very hard, perhaps too hard. See this letter my father sent? Here: 'I know that while you are pleased, you will think of us with affection. You must pardon me if I regard any interruption in your correspondence as evidence that your other duties -' Duties, he says. ' - your other duties are equally neglected.'
Mens sana in corpore sano, he means. How well he knows me. I am by nature inclined to an excess of zeal that can harm my health. But my duties! He has no idea!
I must write to him. And Elizabeth. Henri too. I'll do it tonight. I cannot tell them of my work - not until I am certain of success. You know, it's strange that I came to Paris at this very time. It's as though the world has woken up around me, as though the great endeavour to which I have set myself has inspired a general casting-off of superstition. Coincidence, naturally. But what is coincidence? Ideas have a time. My studies, the discoveries I have made, go hand in hand with the spirit of change.

xoptx What is your work?

xoptx Who is Elizabeth?

xoptx Who is Henri?

Do you know, I haven't seen my family in almost four years? I become so lost in my studies, I might as well be in a diving bell on the ocean bed. Friends, correspondence, food and sleep, all are forgotten. It is a fault, I know.
I will write to father and Elizabeth tonight. Henri too. I cannot tell them of my work - not until I am certain of success - but they will be eager for news from the heartland of the Revolution. You know, it's strange that I came to Paris at this very time. It's as though the world has woken up around me, as though the great endeavour to which I have set myself has inspired a general casting-off of superstition. Coincidence, naturally. But what is coincidence? Ideas have a time. This is the age in which reason is in the ascendant. My studies, the discoveries I have made, go hand in hand with the spirit of change. I don't believe in destiny, of course, and yet...

xoptx What is your work?

xoptx Tell me about Elizabeth.

xoptx Who is Henri?

My father's sister married an Italian gentleman. Soon after the wedding, they moved to Italy, and for some years my father had very little communication with her. She died when I was four years old, and her husband wrote to my father to say that he intended to remarry. 'It is my wish,' he said, 'that you should take charge of the infant, and raise her as your own daughter. Her mother's fortune is secured to her. Reflect upon this proposition and decide whether you would prefer educating your niece yourself to her being brought up by a stepmother.'
My father did not hesitate, and immediately went to Italy, to fetch the little Elizabeth Lavenza home. I often heard my late mother say that she was the most beautiful child she had ever seen, and showed signs even then of a gentle and affectionate disposition. These indications, and a desire to bind the ties of domestic love, determined my mother to consider Elizabeth as my future wife; a design which she never found reason to repent.

xoptx So you are to be married?

xoptx Your mother is dead, then?

xoptx What is your fiancée like?

She caught the scarlet fever from Elizabeth. It was just before I was due to start my first term at university. I don't know if you have lost anyone close to you. It is a long time before you can accept that the person whose very existence appeared a part of your own is gone forever. You know it in your mind to be true, but on some level it is beyond understanding. And time, they say, eases grief, but my experience is that it sharpens it. When finally we realize we will never see the beloved face again, the full bitter weight of grief bears down on us.
But where is the sense in me telling you about a sorrow which all have felt, and must feel? The time comes when grief is an indulgence rather than a necessity, and we have lives to live and duties to perform. My mother's dying wish was that Elizabeth and I should one day marry, and so we shall - when my work is complete.

xoptx What is your fiancée like?

xoptx And Henri?

xoptx What is your work?

Elizabeth is gentle and good tempered, yet gay as a summer insect. Her feelings are lively, but they run strong and deep. Her imagination is luxuriant, so that she may seem to while away hours in daydreaming. But I have seen her apply herself steadfastly when she has a goal she wishes to accomplish. Her hazel eyes, although as lively as a bird's, possess an attractive softness. Her figure is slim; and, though hardy enough to match my pace as we would walk among the hills, she appears the most fragile creature in the world.
Moreover, I never saw so much grace both of person and mind united to so little pretension. If the servants have any request to make, it is always through her intercession. Everyone adores Elizabeth.

xoptx And Henri?

xoptx So, what are you working on?

So, what are you working on?

One day! Not now, not while I still have my studies. I am only twenty-three, and Elizabeth is barely twenty. I realize it's different for a woman. I have told her she must be patient.

xoptx What is she like?

xoptx You mentioned someone called Henri.

xoptx Tell me about your studies.

Tell me about your studies.

My brother William is much younger than I - by fifteen years, in fact. So if not for the presence of my cousin Elizabeth in our household, I would have grown up an only child. But I had a friend in one of my schoolfellows who compensated for the deficiency of a male playmate. The Clervals are friends of my father and their only son, Henri, soon became my best friend. When very young, I remember, we used to act plays composed by him out of stories in his favourite books, often very fanciful adventures in which dragons were slain by heroes of stout heart, and justice always prevailed against tyranny. That's the world we ought to live in, but somewhere along the way we acquire the notion that it's childish.

xoptx What is Elizabeth like?

xoptx And is it true you and Elizabeth are to be married?

xoptx Tell me about your studies.

Tell me about your studies.

Science gripped my imagination from an early age. In other studies you go as far as others have gone before you, and there is nothing more to know; but in a scientific pursuit there is continual discovery, continual wonder. So it was with me throughout my first two years of study here in Paris. My insatiable thirst for learning astonished my fellow students, and my proficiency soon impressed the masters.
When I realized that my professors could teach me no more - indeed, that in my grasp of the landscape yet undiscovered I could see more clearly than they - I thought of returning home to Geneva, to my friends and family. Then an incident happened that led me onto a fresh course of study, and that has protracted my stay these last two years.

xoptx What incident was that?

xoptx A fresh course of study?

My rooms are in the Rue Mouffetard, and meals are brought in by an old servant. Often I forget the time, however, and turn from my work to find the bread stale or the soup gone cold. Thus I will often be found breakfasting in a tavern on the way to lectures, a book propped open in one hand as I cram in food along with knowledge.
On the day I'm speaking of, the back room of the tavern was undergoing repairs when suddenly there was a great shout and the din of chisels stopped. Distracted more by the whispers of the workmen than I had been by their singing moments earlier, I went to see what was happening. The room was thick with mortar dust and chips of brick and stone lay everywhere. They had not put out sheets for some reason, so the table and chairs where I had often sat debating with my fellow students now seemed as a ruin long abandoned to time. On the table lay an object which I perceived to be a mummified human hand. A workman had found it behind the brickwork of the chimney.
I have no idea how it came to be there. That was not the mystery that occupied my interest. Rather it was the length of the nails, which are often said to grow after death. The sight of that hand, of unknown age and origin, severed and sealed away for who knows what reason, and yet continuing for a time to nurture some flickering spark of the essence of life … That is the question that has burned like a beacon before me these last two years. What is the essence of life, and how may it be generated?

And you have found the answer?

I have always been fascinated by the structure of the human body, or indeed of any animal. Behold, a manikin of fleshy clay binding up an interior of hard calcium and liquid-filled tubes. A machine - and yet it breathes, the heart drives the blood, and that heart quickens in response to fear or anger or love. Emotions - they were not on the list of ingredients. So where do they come from? Where does the principle of life originate? The ghost in the machine - that is what I desired to have under my microscope.
Soon after arriving at the university, I began to focus my studies on biology and physiology. But where those studies took me was on a foul journey indeed. If I had not been so driven to penetrate the mystery, I would soon have abandoned it. You see, I had not only to become acquainted with the surgeon's saw and scalpel. It was also necessary for me to scour the slaughterhouses and dissecting rooms for choice items as avidly as other students search the shelves of bookshops. I collected bones from charnel houses. On wooden frames, such as my beloved Elizabeth would use to practice needlework, I decanted serums of bodily fluids and grew tissue cultures on dishes all around my room. I stretched flesh in varying stages of putrefaction, the better to understand what processes are held in check by the force we call life.

xoptx It sounds delightful

xoptx But did you find the answer?

Oh indeed, especially as the spring turned to summer and my rooms acquired the distinctive reek of formaldehyde and the sour-sweet odour of dead flesh. And yet - can you believe this? - I was barely aware of it, so engrossed had I become in my secret toil, until one day when a fellow student came back with me to borrow a book. He made hasty excuses and left, and so glad was I of the opportunity to continue my work thus uninterrupted that it was hours before I understood the reason.
After that I rented a chamber at the top of the house, far removed from the other lodgers and separated from all the other apartments by a gallery and staircase. It's there I have my workshop of filthy creation.

xoptx And did you achieve your goal?

Yes. I succeeded in discovering the cause of generation and life. More than that: I am myself capable of bestowing animation upon lifeless matter. Here are my lodgings. Come up and I'll show you.

Lead the way

For privacy, and because of the disturbing smells - and sometimes sounds - that result from my work, I have taken this room up in the attic, far away from the rest of the house.
So here is the laboratory I was telling you about, well out of the way of prying eyes. Climbing those stairs is the most exercise I get all day!
It's cramped in here. You'll have to squeeze around the tank; it's where I store the fruit of my labours in its dormant state. Excuse the smell - that's the alkali bath in which the specimen is developing. A little high and chloric, you may think, though it reminds me of marzipan.
Let me move these jars aside. See the metallic coating? That is what stores the electric fluid. By linking the jars together in what Mr Franklin terms 'a battery' - like guns, you see - we can obtain an increase in the charge. That will be needed later. See, perhaps I can best demonstrate with this frog that I have on the dissection board.

xoptx Like Professor Galvani's experiments?

xoptx But what is this thing in the tank?

You're familiar with Galvinism, then. Good. That's part of the process I've been working on. Watch as I apply the wires here and here - and the frog's leg moves, though it has been dead for several days. The condenser jar supplies what Professor Volta calls 'animal electricity'. With all these jars I have here connected together, I could give you a shock that would throw you across the room. Or, putting it another way, if that electric fluid were to flow through the muscles of your arm, you would be able to punch a hole in that wall - if your bones didn't break first.

xoptx So your goal is to restore the dead to life?

xoptx What is in the tank?

Not really. True, if I can bestow animation upon lifeless matter, I might in time succeed in renewing life where death has apparently devoted the body to corruption. That's a goal for the future. At present, what occupies me is the instilling of new life in a creature previously without animation. I have gathered raw materials from cemeteries and charnel houses, but the body I have constructed - it is entirely a new being.

And that's what is in the tank?

I cannot show you the whole creature yet. It's not yet stable to remove from the liquor amnii, though here is its arm. Stand back, be careful the liquor doesn't splash on you. I'm not sure of its effect on ordinary human flesh.
I think of this tank as the creature's amnion. Are you aware of the origin of the word?

xoptx I'm sure you will tell me.

xoptx My God, is that a human limb?

Hah, you have seen through me; I am but a lecturer in search of an audience. Well, an amnion was a bowl used by the Greeks to catch the blood of sacrificed lambs - though the musculature you can see here may put you more in mind of lions than lambs.

xoptx Indeed, it must be a giant.

xoptx Why is the skin transparent?

xoptx This arm is quite dead.

xoptx You're building a man!

Say rather, "human-like". I have been inspired by Nature, but not constrained by her.

xoptx It's gigantic!

xoptx Why is the skin transparent?

xoptx Surely this is just a corpse?

A new species of man: Homo incusus, to fit him into Linnaeus's catalogue. A manufactured being, imbued with life by means of certain scientific processes that I have discovered.
Preparing a human body, with all its intricacies of fibres, muscles, and veins, has naturally been a work of inconceivable difficulty. Originally I intended to create a much simpler organism, but giving life to an aboriginal amoeba, or an artificial maggot to squirm around on a plate, would not astonish the world. I need to show something that cannot be denied.

xoptx This is surely the limb of a giant.

xoptx Why is the skin transparent?

xoptx This arm is quite dead.

xoptx Will it think and have feelings like a man?

Will it think and have feelings like a man?

The whole creature will stand about eight feet in height, and is proportionately massive. That makes it easier to work on. Even at this scale, I am frequently laying down capillaries as fine as cotton thread. And the light in here! With all the oil lamps burning it's like scouring the eyes with glass paper. I will need glasses as thick as Robespierre's before I'm finished.

xoptx Its strength will make it intimidating.

xoptx This arm is quite dead.

xoptx Why is the skin transparent?

xoptx So you mean to create a man?

xoptx Will it think and have feelings like a man?

Will it think and have feelings like a man?

He will awaken as a stranger in a strange land. Everything will be a wonder. Think if the world had been created just this morning. Imagine how you would regard a rainbow or a lightning storm if you opened your eyes with no memories of an existence before this moment. Rather you should feel pity and admiration for such a creature than to fear him for his size and strength.

xoptx But surely this is a dead body?

xoptx Why is the skin transparent?

xoptx So you mean to create a man?

xoptx Will it think and have feelings like a man?

Will it think and have feelings like a man?

Originally that was an accident of the skin-culturing technique I have been using. I tried for some time to fix it, until I realized that this translucence will make it easier for physiologists to study the functioning of the creature's muscles and arteries.

xoptx It will be horrific.

xoptx This arm is quite dead.

xoptx Is the whole body on the same scale?

xoptx So you mean to create a man?

xoptx Will it think and have feelings like a man?

Do you think so? I have made it resemble a man, though not always with human parts. Generating the fine nerve endings took too long, so I left its face mostly nerveless, like something limp stitched hastily over a skull. Admittedly there is that... and the yellowish cloudiness of the eyes, I don't know what caused that. But the transparency of its skin, combined with the strongly moulded features I have chosen, should make up for all such deficiencies. When it is animated and stands before an audience in the lecturing hall, I believe most will not regard it as a deformed specimen of humanity but as a wholly new thing, perhaps even with its own beauty.

xoptx Animated? This dead thing?

xoptx So you mean to create a man?

xoptx Will it be capable of reason and emotion?

Will it be capable of reason and emotion?

It has never lived, which is not the same thing. I told you I assembled some of my raw materials from graves and dissecting rooms. In a few weeks the creature will be complete, then this cold clay I'm showing you will radiate the warmth of true living flesh.

xoptx Is the whole body on the same scale?

xoptx Why is the skin transparent?

xoptx So you mean to create a man?

xoptx Will it think and have feelings like a man?

Will it think and have feelings like a man?

Ah, well there's the rub. The "ghost in the machine", as I said earlier. to précis Descartes. The structure of the brain is far beyond my power to replicate, so I implanted tissue from the brains of several unborn children, bathed in certain internally secreted chemicals that appear to stimulate growth, and grafted this to a fully developed brain stem.
Thus the creature will be born with an infant mind, but the mind should mature at a greatly accelerated rate. As to the nature of its thoughts and feelings - they may be like yours or mine, or they may be something entirely new.

xoptx So it will learn?

xoptx When will it be ready?

It is learning already. The brain is active, though sleeping as in the womb. Perhaps it can even hear what we are saying.

When do you mean to animate it?

When do you think his birthday should be? The perfect date would have been the first of Vendémiaire, then he'd be the same age as the Republic - but we've missed that. What about Halloween? No, I'm joking, my friend - and perhaps in poor taste. But just a few weeks' more work, late October or early November and I should be ready. There are a few small tasks still to complete. If you are interested, come with me next week and I'll show you.

END OF CHAPTER ONE


CHAPTER TWO
CHAPTER TWO
To animate the lifeless clay

An impressive building, isn't it? It used to be a gymnasium and tennis court. Aristocratic young men would learn to strike elegant poses with a racquet while never seeming to do anything so vulgar as trying to win. They also practised skewering each other with swords. Quite often the blossoms would come off the foil, and then they'd be brought in for us to operate on. I'm quite serious. I got the liver and kidneys of my creature from one aristocrat whose opponent's blade drove a little too deep.
Since the revolution the building has stood empty, apart from occasional use as an assembly hall. Well, not quite empty. You'll see. Ah, I can hear the night watchman coming. Where's my purse?
'Good evening, citizen. I found this bag of coins in the street and thought it might belong to you.'
'Bless you, citizen. I was wondering where I'd dropped that. Perhaps you'd like to come inside.'

xoptx What are we here for?

xoptx Lead the way.

I need the small cartilages of a human voice box - a very intricate structure, much too time-consuming for me to build by hand. If I can find one fresh enough, chemicals can be used to stimulate its growth to suit the creature's scale. Or perhaps I'll use it to make moulds in which I can nurture bone cultures. There are a thousand excruciating details like this - little wonder you think my nerves are shot.

Why would you look for such a thing here?

Come and see. That sweaty stink - doesn't that bring back memories of school, eh? In the salons men hide their animal excretions with scent and powder, but venture into zoo or gymnasium alike and you can't avoid the sharp odours of unadorned nature. And there's another odour here - can you smell it, that butcher's shop stink? That's the answer to your question.
See over there, against the far wall? Those aren't exercise balls. You'll be able to see better when the watchman brings another candle. Look - baskets full of human heads, fresh as pork loins. Today's crop from the guillotine. The bodies are carted off to the lime pits in the Madeleine Cemetery, but the heads are brought here where families can identify their loved ones and take this much of them away for burial. Here, catch!

xoptx Have some respect for the dead.

xoptx Won't the guillotine blade have destroyed the larynx?

xoptx Let's get what you need and be on our way.

I respect the living. The dead are gone, they're not here. These craniums don't hold a lifetime's memories, just a few pounds of rubbery grey jelly.

xoptx What about their families?

xoptx I thought you were looking for a voice box, not a brain.

xoptx What are we looking for?

You disappoint me. I thought you understood the significance of my work. It will change the world. The Jacobins have declared this to be Year One - and it will be, but not because of mere politics. Posterity will judge this to be the dawn of the era of Man's supremacy over nature and death. Now put aside your mawkish sentiment and help me pick one of these heads for my experiment. We don't have all night.

You do it; you know what to look for.

In most cases, not all. That's why I need you to help me look through them. Here's one with only minor damage to the laryngeal area. And another - no, I see the blade has cut right through the conus elasticus. But there must be three or four dozen here, so surely we'll find one that's fit for my purpose.

Let's get on with it, then.

These three are the best of the batch. See how the throats have been severed with the voice box largely intact. Which do you think? The sex doesn't matter for my purpose, incidentally. I don't merely stitch body fragments together, I will be using this as a model with which to construct a larynx for my creature.

xoptx This one has a noble brow.

xoptx Here is a beautiful woman.

xoptx This fellow has the face of a brute.

The watchman may be able to indulge our curiosity.
'That one was a chemist or philosopher of some sort, sir. I dunno what he done to 'ave 'is neck sliced.'
Indeed? Not a lecturer at the university or I'd recognize him. Hah, wouldn't it be extraordinary if I found Professor Krempe here one night? But what am I saying? I couldn't bear to have Krempe's droning voice emanate from my creature, even modified by the chemical treatments.
So, shall we give the philosopher a second lease of life, my friend?

xoptx Why not.

xoptx Or the woman?

xoptx Perhaps that ugly one.

xoptx What about the "black-hearted angel"?

xoptx Let's take Monsieur le Comte.

Yes, she has a pretty face. It makes her death doubly sad. The watchman may know why she was executed.

Oh, I have been in worse scrapes than that. To obtain a suitable heart, I gate-crashed a blacksmith's funeral and had to operate on the body with his family in the very next room. Nearly got away with it, too, but someone saw me climbing out the window. You can run pretty fast when you have three blacksmith's sons on your heels!

Come back on the evening of the last day of Brumaire - for then 'the fog will lift'. No? We have to learn to couch our humour in revolutionary terms, these days, may friend. Until the twentieth of November, then.

CHAPTER THREE
CHAPTER THREE
Wilder dreams

A dreary evening. Listen to that rain, drumming on the roof. It's been coming down like that for days.

xoptx You look dreadful.

xoptx I see you've had a letter from your cousin.

xoptx There is a letter on the table here.

xoptx What are these jars and cylinders?

xoptx Do you need any help?

My nerves are shot. The strain of getting everything ready, often working all night. And this incessant rain. The damp is in my bones. It wouldn't be so bad if it were absolutely pelting down. It's that soft whispering patter on the tiles that wears me down. Can you hear? 'Hubris, hubris, hubris,' it seems to be saying.

xoptx Put this work aside. You need to rest.

xoptx Why all the jars and wires?

xoptx At least let me help you.

Yes. Dear Elizabeth. I don't have time to write back to her now. Well, it's not just lack of time. What would I write? Look, she says, 'My uncle and I conversed a long time last night as to what profession William should follow.' William is my brother. He's seven years old, for heaven's sake. 'I proposed he should be a farmer... the least hurtful profession of all.' Oh, I thought it was we surgeons who swear that oath. First do no harm. But no, it seems it's farmers.
How can I reply to such trivialities? I am on the verge of something momentous. I love Elizabeth - but no, throw this letter away. There's no time for foolish sentiment.

xoptx Perhaps you should rest.

xoptx What are these wires connected to?

xoptx What needs to be done?

Yes, I know. It's from my cousin Elizabeth. I don't have time to write back to her now. Well, it's not just lack of time. What would I write? Rest? Did Galileo rest? Did Newton? Did Michelangelo, when he lay on trestles under the Sistine roof and strained his eyes by reflected lamplight to see the fingers of God and Adam? No, no, there can be no rest till this rough form is infused with life, draws breath, takes its place in Creation.

xoptx What are these wires connected to?

xoptx What needs to be done?

Condensers. The columns there generate the electrical charge and this row of silvered bottles stores it. That evening when we went to the tennis court, do you remember what I said? 'Let there be life!' Let there be lightning would be as apt. Let there be lightning for this new Genesis. Not lightning in sky quantities, such as would split an oak or burn down a house. Just as much as can be bottled in a Leyden jar or two. A kick like a mule is quite enough to stop a heart. Or set it beating.
Did I ever tell you about the tree?

xoptx There's no time now.

xoptx What about the tree?

I was about fifteen years old. We were at our house near Belrive and there was a massive thunderstorm. It swept down from behind the mountains of Jura, and the thunder burst directly overhead with a violence that made the plates rattle on the dresser.
The whole time the storm lasted, I stood at the door watching its progress with curiosity and delight. Suddenly I saw a stream of fire issue from an old and beautiful oak which stood about twenty yards from our house; and so soon as the dazzling light vanished, the oak had disappeared, and nothing remained but a blasted stump.
When we visited it the next morning, we found the tree shattered in a singular manner. It was not splintered by the shock, but entirely reduced to thin ribbons of wood. I never beheld anything so utterly destroyed.

xoptx Surely a sign from God.

xoptx The power of nature is beyond our wildest dreams.

xoptx Don't get distracted.

Hah, you're speaking to the wrong man. My dreams have been wilder than any who has ever lived. I can't describe to you the torrent of emotion that has borne me onwards these last two years. I feel like a leaf in a hurricane. Throughout that time I have barely noticed the seasons or the affairs of men. Riots in the streets, storms, sleet, the fall of kings, the furnace heat of summer... All passed in a blink. I have been a sleepwalker confronting obstacles that melt away into dream-stuff. And now we are here. The labour that has burned off my health is complete. All that remains is to connect those electrodes and give my monster his vitalizing spark.

Then why wait any longer?

In the blasting of a tree? Oh yes, there's a sign indeed. 'Lest Man put forth his hand and take also of the tree of life, and eat, and live forever, therefore the Lord sent Man forth from the garden...'
This is the hand. The hand that God feared. I've plucked that fruit for mankind. Life and death, there's a good place to start, it seems to me. Breaking that boundary will pour a torrent of light into our dark world. And then heaven is the limit - if that. Let God hide in His garden while we plunder all the secrets that even He fears. I've had enough of reach exceeding grasp. I've had enough.

So why are we still talking?

If I did, if I did... a new species would bless me as its creator and source. Many happy and excellent natures would owe their being to me. No father could claim the gratitude of his child so completely as I should deserve theirs.
Perhaps you think this is overweening pride? See how my limbs tremble. I know I'm a sight - bloodshot eyes, unshaven. I must look to you more like a slave doomed to toil in the mines than a scientist in pursuit of his cherished dream. The work has brought me close to ruin. But I tell you, my friend, I have never seen more clearly. I'm like an ascetic of old, emerging from seven hundred nights in the wilderness, soul tortured, body racked - but the ordeal was worth the cost, because I return with the secret of fire.
It isn't pride to say I will be creator of a new race. Do you see? It's duty. It's my responsibility. What I have done, I have done for all mankind.

That's if it works.

You're right. Then giveGive me a hand with this winch. It's stiff, you'll need to get a good grip. One, two, three - heave. There, it's coming. The creature has been growing in the tank, even after I finished the surgical transplants and grafts. It must weigh at least five hundred pounds - there! There it... My God, look at it. The first of a new race of Man, waiting only for an electrical jolt to impart the spark of life.

xoptx A new race? Surely you don't intend...

xoptx It's hideous.

Why not? I have provided it with generative organs. In theory it could interbreed with Homo sapiens, though I'm unsure how the chemical treatments have affected its seed. The offspring would likely be mules. If it is to reproduce, I would have to create a female counterpart.

xoptx And will you do that?

xoptx What an unholy concept. The dead cannot breed!

xoptx First let's see if the process works.

Have you understood so little? It will not be some walking corpse from the pages of a cheap Schauer-roman. My process bestows life, not undeath! The heart will beat, the lungs will draw in air. You'll feel the warmth of his blood and his breath. Those eyes, dull now, will glitter with lively intelligence. What am I, a vaxdoux sorcerer? This is science! If you have nothing but superstition to contribute, please just stay out of the way.

As you wish.

Yes, the creature's skeletal frame has continued to grow inside the tank. I didn't expect it to become so misshapen. But have you ever seen a dragonfly larva? Nymphs, the English call them, but a creature less comely it is hard to imagine. It is a tiny engine of lethal parts, and yet wonderful for all that. And so, with a certain eye, appears my creation. See the network of muscles and arteries, clearly visible through the skin. If we were to strip off your own skin, something very like this would be revealed. So: hideous you may call him, but he is a brother to mankind.

At the moment, however, it's but a corpse.

The moment is here. If this were a play, how the heavens would howl. Instead of this dreary patter of rain, hailstones would pelt the roof and the crack and boom of thunder would drown out everything. But the world is not sentient. It takes no notice of us; to think otherwise is a childish delusion. It is we who observe and feel, while the universe is but our stage.
Ah well, the stage is set. Watch as I attach the electrodes. And with a throw of the switch - stand back, the electrical charge is considerable - there! A convulsive movement. Galvani saw that same twitch in his frogs' legs, but there's more. The stimulus is removed but the motion continues. See there! The hand is flexing. The chest rises and falls. Hark! Hear it? The rasp of breath. The creature's first breath!

I thought I was building a creature like an angel, a form to admire in which the perfect arrangement of muscles, arteries and nerves would be laid out for all to see. Hmm, the pigmentation in the choroid is rather excessive. I didn't expect the eyes to be such a lurid yellow. And with the translucent skin, now that the face is animated, there's a fright mask indeed. A hard one for a father to love.

xoptx Smile? It's like the grin of a skull.

A young woman in the bloom of health calls to me across the street. It's Elizabeth, my cousin. Surprised to see her here in Paris, and filled with delight, I run to embrace her. She draws me back into the doorway of an abandoned shop, on which the old seals that used to be used in times of plague can be seen peeling. I cradle her sweet face tenderly, realizing how I have missed her.
'No one will see us here,' she says with a smile that shows her teeth, and she presses against me. The fabric of her dress is very thin. I feel the heat of her body. As we kiss, I feel her tongue probe my lips. My heart is pounding. Her tongue in my mouth is cold, so cold, and I pull away, suddenly afraid. There is a smell in the air - her perfume, yes, but behind that a taint of things locked away for a long time.
This is not Elizabeth. It is my dead mother's head that I hold in my hands, the neck sliced raggedly, the eyes opaque as mothballs. Maggots crawl out from between her livid lips, from her nose, from the torn hole of her windpipe. And as they fall they burst on the flagstones, tiny stars of blood patterning the ground.

What now?

I can see Henri's face looking down at me. He's saying something. I can hear him, I can feel his grip as he shakes me, but it doesn't seem to matter now. Nothing matters.
I had passion without compassion. Logic to see my way to the summit, but not the imagination or the empathy to understand what it would mean to stand there, breathless, under the uncaring sky.
When my creature opened its eyes, that was the moment I had worked for unceasingly every day for two years. It had never been out of my thoughts in all that time, and yet it took me by surprise. I had never considered the feelings it would awaken. I had made a fatal miscalculation. Into all my precisely calculated equations, I failed to factor myself.

END OF PART ONE


PART TWO
Some are born to sweet delight,
Some are born to endless night.

CHAPTER ONE
Dark and Opaque Bodies

An incessant pattering hiss from above: surrounding, smothering, a continuous falling sound that is soft and sour. The taste of noises. The sharp tang of small hard instruments clattering down. The acidic snap of glass underfoot. The sticky saltiness of heavy solid objects.
Shapes too. Rough plaster like dry sloughing skin, an unyielding beam like dense muscle. A space where nothing is, no resistance as you move forward. Now cramped. Oblong shapes piled in a sloping descent. More beams. Bitter creak of hinges, dazzling gust of cold damp air.
This is not the warm wet that you knew all that time in the tank. It rattles off the ground, sluices your body - cold, dark, uncomforting. In your hand a soft thing, snatched from a hook. You wrap it around you, shivering.
Everything at once. It's too much. These are separate sensations that need to be sorted so that the world makes sense.

xoptx Do you concentrate on what you can see?

xoptx Or on your hearing?

xoptx Or on developing your coordination?

It's dark, but there are a few shuttered lanterns, hung over doorways, that flash on the hard rails of rain and give you meagre splinters of light to see by. Moving onwards with no sense of a destination, you see a few figures like yourself, stumbling through the streets awash with filth and mud. One comes close. How small he is. You reach out to him, but he stares with unfocused eyes and then falls in a heap.
The street is gradually gathered in by the sweep of a great featureless wall. You want to know what is beyond that wall. Perhaps it isn't cold and dark and wet like here. You have a memory of peace and warm security but you feel it draining away. Soon it will be gone.

xoptx Look for a gap in the wall.

xoptx Look for others like yourself.

From the lit window of a room beside the gate you hear people talking.

Are these creatures your brethren? In some ways you feel alike, in other respects there seems an unimaginable gulf. The basic form is the same, but you feel no empathy for the way they talk, dress and behave. Perhaps that is why, while part of you yearns to approach them, some dim instinct cries a warning that they would greet you with fear and hatred. Turning from the window with a hollow feeling inside, you slip past the dozing sentry at the gate and escape into the deep shadows of the countryside.
The two card players are the first to see you. They fall silent and slowly rise from the table, eyes fixed on you and mouths slightly open in what you first take to be a smile of greeting. In the corner, the man and woman continue their sweaty grappling until the woman, tousle-haired and red-faced, happens to glance in your direction.
A moment of stillness. You squeeze a sound from your throat. It sounds harsh and grating after the fluid babble of their own speech. And then the woman screams.

xoptx Do you run off?

xoptx Or attack them?

The rainwater will have to do to quench your thirst. It is cool, at least. Perhaps less enticing than whatever those men had in their bottle, but you don't dare to be seen by them. You edge carefully past the dozing figure towards the open postern gate.
The shouts wake the sentry. For a moment your eyes lock. There are many emotions seething there but you don't know how to read them. He backs away, holding out his hands and shaking his head. You only want to get away. The postern gate is small - you have to break the door off its hinges, but you manage to squeeze through and run for a long way, hearing the shouts get swallowed in the night, until finally there are no houses and you can lose yourself in the still, silent shadows of the countryside.
One of the card players grabs a bottle from the table. He swings it against your head. It shatters and your ear is ringing. He tries to thrust the broken bottle into your gut, but this time you take it away from him and you pull off his arm and then the other man has something sharp but you take that too and crush his head and throw him after the third man, who is only trying to get away with his trousers round his knees, and you hit them with the table to make them stop, stop the squirming and the shouting, and you keep bringing it down until they stop the noise you hate and only the woman is screaming and soon she stops too.
Outside, the sentry has woken up. His eyes are very wide as he sees you emerge from the gatehouse with the head of one of his friends. He is wearing a metal stick across his back and struggles with it, trying to swing it round to point at you, but as you come close he throws the stick down and runs off.
He'll be back with more of them. Perhaps more than you can defend yourself against. The countryside will be safer.

Leave the city.

Creatures stir in the hedgerows, less threatening by far than your fellow man. You find shelter under the spreading branches of a tree where the rain drips and murmurs, but no longer lances icily against your skin. You feel safe in the darkness.
Sunrise comes as a terrifying blaze of fiery light. It sets your heart racing with both excitement and fear. As the sun climbs in the sky, the light becomes more and more oppressive, pressing on your nerves until you are driven off the road into the shade of the trees.

xoptx Find a secluded spot where you can rest.

xoptx Explore the woods first.

A shape flits across the sun and breaks into many fragments that settle with a rustling sound among the curling red leaves. You watch in silence, perceiving the separate shapes to be tiny moving things with wings. The sound that permeates the forest seems to emanate from their throats.
Gradually your impressions become clearer. You no longer confuse your various senses. Sounds do not convey flavours, each sight no longer floods you with impressions of texture, smell and noise. And as you learn to distinguish the senses, so you also gain more control over your limbs. Instead of lurching clumsily from tree to boulder, clutching for support, you are able to move confidently and swiftly.

Now you need to find food, water and shelter.

You climb into the forest, finally throwing yourself down beside a clear brook where you are at least able to slake the dryness in your mouth. Tormented by a hollow ache inside, you find an apple on the ground. It is half rotted but the smell is sweet, impelling you to press it to your lips and suck the soft flesh from it. As the newfound urges of thirst and hunger recede, you succumb to weariness and sleep.

You awaken to find the world dark again. There is no rain tonight, but it is so cold that the moss crackles underfoot. It's a good thing you brought the gown from the place where you first became aware. You pull it tighter around you, revelling in the soft caress of the fabric on your skin.
As you search for berries and insects, you become aware of a soft gleam sending faint beams slanting between the tree trunks. The source is a white half-disc that rises through the branches. It is like the sun, but cut in two, and different as the palm of a hand is different from the knuckles. The whole forest is silent under the silver light that haloes this radiant moon.
How does it make you feel?

xoptx Lonely.

xoptx Awestruck.

xoptx Indifferent.

It is not a disk but a globe - a great round mountain in the sky whose white rocks and bleak, illimitable deserts seem to come closer as you gaze upon it. You might as well be there upon the moon in perfect solitude as here, surrounded by teeming communities of creatures yet excluded from them by some aspect of your nature that you do not even grasp.
You gaze upon it in wonder. If each of those wrinkles on its surface is indeed a canyon or a range of mountains, as they appear to your eyes, then it is a thing of unbelievable immensity and yet it hangs suspended above the forest as though weightless. The world is full of mysteries, and each mystery excites a thousand questions. If only you had a mentor who could teach you understanding, so that you no longer felt segregated from all creation.
It provides light. What does it matter what you say about a moon? You dig under the frost and find a few white grubs, bitter to the taste but enough for your needs.
You thought you were alone in the forest, but the unmistakeable murmur of human voices leads you to a clearing where four men in ragged clothes squat around a blazing fire.

xoptx Approach them.

xoptx Watch them for a while.

xoptx Get far away from here.

Two of them exchange harsh words and stare at each other. You sense a tension in the group. Then one of the two drops his gaze, and by his posture it seems he has submitted. While his opponent rubs his hands complacently before the fire, the other gets up and gathers a few twigs, which he piles onto the blaze.

xoptx Keep watching.

xoptx Show yourself.

As you draw near to the fire, their belligerent scrutiny turns first to slack-jawed astonishment, then quickly to terror. The others bolt, but one - the man who earlier stared down his friend - stays fixed and frozen as you advance towards him. Glancing round, he sees that he's alone. Made weak by fear, he shambles off into the bushes on all fours like a sick animal.

They left you the fish, which you now know how to cook. Stoking up the fire with more branches, you are soon warm and well fed. But still alone.

Having observed the men earlier, you know how to build up the fire with more wood. While eating a supply of nuts you gathered earlier, you drop a few into the fire, thereby discovering how to draw more flavour and sustenance from food by cooking it. But even this gives you little cheer, for what you want most of all remains out of reach.

You notice that the fire consists of burning branches. While adding more that you've gathered, you notice that you dropped some of your precious store of nuts into the fire. When you rescue them, they are tastier than any you've eaten before. So fire doesn't only give warmth. It adds flavour to food too.

xoptx Keep to the woods for a while.

xoptx Go looking for habitation.

They pull some sticks from the fire and you smell a delicious aroma. It looks like fish from the stream nearby, but the fire has done something to it.

xoptx Emerge from hiding.

xoptx Slink away.

Light bleeds into the sky, peeling back the night. For a few minutes, red fire trembles on the horizon. You stretch out your hand but it is beyond your reach, and soon dissolves in a clotted white haze.

xoptx Pursue him?

xoptx Remain in the hut?

He is old and his legs are weak. He staggers on, lent strength by fear, continually glancing back as you draw closer. In the middle of the field he sinks to his knees and, with clasped hands, bends his head and starts muttering the same sounds over and over. What do you feel as you look at him?

xoptx Anger.

xoptx Pity.

xoptx Kinship.

You follow the old man as he gasps his way up the slope of the hill. It is steep, but nothing to you. You could overtake him easily - and you want companionship so much. It is a need even stronger than hunger or fatigue. The old man looks back. His face is a mask of terror. Is there any hope of making yourself understood?

xoptx Yes.

xoptx No.

He is feeble in your grasp. You lift and shake him, hearing the dry snap of bones. It's in your heart to prove yourself the monster he took you for, but he doesn't last long enough for that. Out of curiosity, you gouge and peel away his face and cannot suppress a shout of pleasure that sends the birds flying from the trees. Under the skin, he is no different from you.

You return to the hut.

What he is feeling is fear. You yearn to make him understand that he doesn't have to fear you, but he is too terrified even to look up and see your imploring gestures. Rather than prolong his terror, you turn away. Sorrow is like an oppressive weight pressing down on you, and for all your great strength you're not sure it's a burden you can bear.

xoptx Go back to the hut.

xoptx Get far away from here.

You bend close. His hands tremble and his muttering falls silent. There is a stink as he voids his bowels. You meant only to assure him that you too know what it is to be afraid, to flee like a hunted animal with no hope of refuge. As you try to articulate these feelings, a series of moans escape your lips. The old man stumbles to his feet again and runs as though broken inside. It would be easy to catch him, but instead you merely stand immobile and watch as he climbs a stile and lurches off along the lane.
You are left stunned - indeed, desolated - by the way the old man reacted. But the smells of his breakfast quickly distract you. Greedily you devour warm bread, milk and cheese. Only the wine is not to your taste - a sour drink, you spit it out. Then, overcome by fatigue, you stretch out in front of the fire and fall asleep.

xoptx Make yourself at home.

You return to the hut.

It seems important to conceal the aftermath of such an act, just as your first dim memories are of one who tried to expunge your existence. The discordant singing gets louder. Dust is flung up and there is the sound of hobnails and clogs on the flinty road. They are severed heads, white and blood-flecked, mounted on sharp poles that the leaders of the crowd are brandishing with triumphal glee.
As the procession comes into view around the hedges you see most of them are armed with clubs and knives, and a few with sticks that they use to send volleys of fire and smoke up into the air. It was the cracking of those fire-sticks that woke you.
There are far too many to fight. Luckily they seem unaware of you. They go marching past, jeering and laughing and screaming. There are hundreds of them and it seems to take forever, but finally the last straggler vanishes along the road.

Slip away into the woods.

A few days pass without you seeing another soul. One morning you awaken with a start, for the world has been transformed overnight. Everything is covered in a layer of cold white stuff, which you soon discover to be frozen water. As you stand ankle deep in it, you feel the cold as a dull sapping ache that penetrates to your bones. The woods are a stooped, untidy black tangle, the trees finally stripped bare of leaves, and the fields present a vista of uniform white from which a disconsolate wind blows steadily. Even your gown gives little protection.
Curls of smoke mark out a village where you see people moving about. Because of the bitter cold, you are desperate for shelter and food, but there is no chance of finding nuts and berries in the snow, and the branches you gather are too wet to burn.

xoptx Do you risk going into the village?

xoptx Or do you pass it by?

A little distance from the village stands a chateau with peeling paintwork on the shutters. A cartwheel without some of its spokes is propped against the gates. You go closer, thinking the place might be deserted, only to almost run into a man who is coming around the side of the house. He hasn't seen you. There is no time to turn back. Plunging into the bushes, you come across an outhouse built onto the back of the chateau. It is a half-ruined structure of bare piled stones, roofed with old timbers covered in bedraggled thatching. But it is adjacent to the main chimney and the interior is dry. You crawl inside and pull the broken door to behind you.
You wander up the main street as if in a dream. After the wide, undisciplined prospect of the countryside, these little neat rows of cottages with their painted doors are astonishing and alien. The gardens are abundant with fruit and vegetables. In the windows of many houses you see milk and cheeses that make your mouth water. They seem to invite the hungry passer-by to enter, but no sooner have you set foot through the door than children are shrieking, women screaming, men shouting.
You retreat along the street, pelted with stones. Several men gather together and, wielding long sticks with prongs on the end, they run in to jab at you. You are pierced, and as your blood flows there is a roar of delight from the persecuting mob.
They are monsters! Sobbing with pain, you crash through a hedge and lope off across the fields.
From inside the house comes a sound sweeter than the birdsong in the woods, yet not from any throat that you can imagine.

xoptx Do you want to find out what it is?

xoptx Or stay as quiet as you can?

You find a crack in the rear wall of your hovel. It looks as if there was once a window here that has been blocked up. Widening this crack with a sharp stone, you are able to make a chink wide enough to see through into the house. Later you can block it with pebbles so that they don't notice a draught.
You peer into a room where an old man sits at a kind of table or raised box. He is running his hands along the edge, which seems to consist of keys made from a different wood from the rest. The music is coming from inside it.

You must wait for nightfall to gather some food.

You huddle inside your lair. The bushes set around this side of the house make it possible the outhouse has been forgotten and left to fall to ruin, so you feel safe from discovery. Inside, the floor is only packed earth, but it is dry. You carpet it with straw and moss. Now that the gaps in the walls are plugged, the draught isn't so noticeable and, with a little residual heat from the back of the chimney, it is almost comfortable.
You pull your gown around you. Weeks of sleeping rough are slowly reducing it to rancid tatters. You will need to steal some new clothing, especially now the weather seems to be turning colder.

xoptx Take a closer look at that gown.

Night closes in, but to your amazement the people in the house have sticks which they can light to create tiny fires and, by setting these around a room, they have light to see by even though it is dark outside.

Eventually he finishes, closes the book, and they douse the lights before going off to other rooms, presumably to sleep.

xoptx Will you go to sleep now?

xoptx Or sit up pondering what you've seen today?

Through the following days, as winter closes its grip, you get many opportunities to observe the family. By luck, the crack in the back wall of your hovel overlooks the room where the old man spends most of his day, and as the others are always looking in to see that he's all right, you soon begin to think of yourself as the fourth member of the family. Or the fifth, if you include the cat which often enjoys a good meal in the house and then finds her way around to your hovel to see if you have found any fish or dead birds she can convince you to part with.
You see that in spite of their fine house and clothes, they are not without cares of their own. From the solicitous way the younger two set aside a portion of their meals for the old man, you surmise they are short of food. Having noticed this, you also become aware of the patches on their clothes and the threadbare furniture. They have a single cow, who sometimes gives only a cupful of milk. No doubt this constant hardship is the reason for the downcast expression you often catch on the young man's face when he's working in the garden, and the tears the girl sometimes sheds when she's alone. And all this time you have been in the habit of sneaking into the house to help yourself to food.

xoptx Will you live only off what you can forage from now on?

xoptx Or will you just continue to take what you want?

The old man is blind, making him unable to help with any of the daily chores, but the young man and woman look after him and give him food from their own plates, going hungry rather than deprive him.
Some emotion stirs within you as you contemplate this. Is it:

xoptx Loneliness?

xoptx Or contempt?

You long to join them, but dare not. The brutal treatment you received from the villagers is fresh in your mind. For the time being, you resolve to remain hidden in your shelter, quietly observing them and hoping to learn enough of their ways and gentle manners that eventually you might be accepted into their company.

The weeks pass.

The weaklings! Each day you return again and again to the crack in the brickwork that is your window on their lives. The young man takes a morning to gather firewood that you could carry back and chop up in an hour. They weep to see their plates half empty, yet their cheese and bread and eggs are nightly banquets compared to the handful of woodlice or hard bitter berries which must do to sustain you. There they are beside a warming fire, while you huddle out here like a pig in its sty. But not for long! You must bide a little longer, learn the ways of mankind - and then your innate superiority must surely make you master of such as they.

The weeks pass.

Moved by their kindness to each other, you feel ashamed of the food you've pilfered from their larder. It is a hard winter, but you satisfy yourself only with the berries, nuts and roots you are able to gather from the woods.

Finding the young man's tools in an outhouse, you go out by night and return with enough firewood to keep them warm for a week. When the girl opens the door in the morning, you are waiting crouched in the bushes to see her astonishment. She calls to the young man, who claps his hands together and almost falls on his knees beside the pile of wood, his mouth wide open in a rarely seen expression you associate with unbounded joy.

You continue to sneak into the house to help yourself to milk and bread, timing your forays to coincide with those times that one of the family is held up by chores from breakfasting at the same time as the others. This way, each assumes that one of the others is taking more than their fair share, and they don't think to look for a thief from outside.

By degrees, as you continue to spy on them, it dawns on you that the sounds they utter are a means of communication. Some sounds produce pleasure or surprise, others mirth or sadness. What godlike science! You strive to master it - a difficult task, for you must strain to hear through the crack in the wall and they speak rapidly. It takes you months to learn a few words. Fire. Wood. Bread. Milk. And there are words for people too. The girl is Agatha, but also Daughter and Sister. Felix, the young man, is sometimes called Brother and Son. The old man is Father only. If he ever had other names he has lost them with age.
You have a name. Why can't you remember it? You try to dredge it up from the deeps of memory, but all you get are sharp smells that sting your nose, the taste of something acrid, images of darkness, rain, light on broken glass. And a face! No, it's gone.Even their cat Childebrand enjoys several names and basks in their affection. Only you have no name, like the beasts of the wild.
