Perhaps they tolerate his useless presence because he is able to entertain them with his music.

Time passes.

Felix is often sad. Perhaps that's why you feel the greatest kinship with him. Often you see him coming in from the fields with a frown on his handsome face and shoulders bowed as though under a terrible burden. It seems as if each step costs him all his energy, and he would like to throw himself to the ground and never move again. At other times, in the middle of fixing up one of the house's dilapidated shutters or carrying out fodder for the cow, he will pause and look into the distance and heave a sigh as though an inner pain could split him in two.

Time passes.

A thaw sets in as the days start to become noticeably longer. One morning, you are cupping your hands to drink from a pond when a shaft of sunlight hits your face, which appears with fiery clarity in the water.
Of course you've seen your reflection before. But this time it comes as a shock. You are so used to spending the day watching the family that you have come to fancy yourself as one of them. The red, gristly countenance with the round yellow eyes and skeletal grimace is like some creature of the depths staring up at you from the water. You feel a thrill of fear, as if it might reach up and drag you down into a mire of darkness from which there is no escape.
You scurry back thirsty to your lair, pulling the twigs and leaves behind you as if that might shut out the scrutiny of some immense, unseen, celestial eye that is somehow judging you. And if such an eye exists, what does it make of you?

xoptx That you are hideously ugly?

xoptx Or rather that you're different?

You are. More than ugly: monstrous. Even the cat has taken to slinking out of your small store of food if it sees you approaching, and will not suffer to let you stroke it, though it stretches contentedly enough in Agatha's lap.
The thought of Agatha's caresses makes you press your fists to your temples to squeeze out those feelings that can only torture you. She would never greet you with smiles and soothing words, or run light fingers over your aching limbs.
Your appearance sets you apart, it's true. Yet inside you have the same feelings, the same needs. Your stomach rumbles at the smell of baking bread or a ripe cheese. If you cut yourself, you make the same noise as Felix does, the same reflex of jerking back the injured hand, of putting your tongue over the cut. You feel pain in the same way - so why not sadness and joy and love? You are a man like him. But unkind nature has made you in such a way that no one can see that.
Why is Felix sad? Why are your family so poor? They begin to obsess your sleeping hours as well as your attention while awake. In your dreams, you don't peer in through a crack in the wall, you sit among them in the parlour. As they talk of their sorrows, though their language remains a clash of meaningless sounds, in the dream you listen judiciously, with profound understanding, weighing every thought as they sit watching you with eager smiles. Your gentle demeanour and wisdom have entirely won their favour - no, even their love - so that they do not see you as a monster but as their saviour who has come to protect them and restore their happiness.
You wake to see the buds on the trees are turning to blossom. The din of birdsong fills the air, dew sparkles on the grass where only a week ago lay snow, and the scent of flowers is woken by a sun returning joy to the world after the long, long months of winter. But how do you feel?

xoptx Are you hopeful?

xoptx Or fearful?

Your dream has shown the way. You must apply yourself with fresh zeal to learning the art of language. Your vocal cords are harsh but supple. When alone in the heart of the woods, you have practised speaking those few words you've learned. If you try harder, you can acquire the articulacy to present yourself to the family. You have heard Felix say, on finding one of your mounds of firewood awaiting him by the kitchen door, 'Good spirit, wonderful!' Or words to that effect. At any rate, he will surely welcome you, his mysterious benefactor and friend to be, if only you can explain that you are not the monster that your face and form suggest.

Let us hope you're right.

To have such a dream, and awaken to such a golden dawn, serves only to deepen your impending sense of doom. It seems to you that you were created by one who never built into you a capacity for happiness. Or perhaps, beholding you a thing of such frightening aspect, he cast you out into the wild, expecting you to die. Stubborn life, to keep so unfortunate a weed thriving next to the most beautiful flowers. If you were a weed, and Felix found you in his garden, the pruning knife would see to you soon enough. Why pine away, pressed to the crack in the wall you can never cross, living in dreams which are only that? You have seen yourself - a monster, born to be an outcast. You will never be welcome by the fireside with your fellow man.

Perhaps the new season will bring hope.

With spring comes warmth, and pleasant sprinkling showers that rapidly transform the earth. The family spent the winter months huddled close to the fire whenever tasks did not force them outside, but now they live mostly in the open air. Father quits his parlour to sit out on the lawn for several hours each day. Even Felix, as he sets off to work in the fields, now walks with a less mournful trudge.
The birds sing more cheerful notes. The leaves bud forth on the trees. Happy, happy earth! A fit habitation for gods now, though a short time ago it was bleak, damp, and unwholesome. Your spirits are elevated by the enchanting appearance of nature. The past is blotted from your memory. The present is tranquil, and - at least in your most optimistic moments - the future is gilded by bright rays of hope.
The season advances rapidly. The weather is fine, the skies cloudless. The nights when you are abroad foraging are balmy, and you come back to your home laden with fruit. It astonishes you that what before was barren should now bloom with the most beautiful flowers and greenery. Each day brings a thousand scents of delight and a thousand sights of beauty.
And then, one morning, a newcomer arrives whose presence will work the magic of spring on your little family.

END OF CHAPTER ONE


CHAPTER TWO
CHAPTER TWO
The Crack in the Wall

Hooves clatter on the cobblestones. The house gets few visitors, so you scrabble under the hedge to get a better view. The figure who dismounts is a lady in a black veil. Sister, who is at the door plucking a chicken, rises hesitantly. Then, when the lady lifts her veil, she presses her hand to her mouth in surprise and calls excitedly to Brother.
He rushes out with his breakfast napkin still in his hand. You think that he's about to sweep up the newcomer in his arms, so delighted does he appear. Instead he visibly holds himself back and, full of smiles, merely takes her hand and kisses it again and again.
She must know one of his names, because you hear the word 'Felix' spoken in a sweet, husky voice. As Sister beckons her into the house, she turns to see that her horse is happy to be led off to the stable by Brother. You catch a glimpse of her face. Her long black hair, darkly glittering eyes and full wide lips all contribute to her beauty, but what strikes you most of all is her expression of innocent wonder.
Is she more beautiful than Agatha Sister?

xoptx Yes.

xoptx No.

When you first saw Agatha you thought her beautiful, because she seemed the kindest and most pleasingly formed of the few women you'd encountered. But this newcomer has revealed to you what truly angelic beauty can exist in female form. If you were to learn that the heavens had opened and she had stepped from a rainbow, you could not be more entranced.

Hurry back to your hovel so you can observe her.

Indeed, for Agatha is made more handsome by her forbearance. Despite the family's difficult circumstances, she remains patient and cheerful, always ready to go short in order that Father or Brother should have more. A tiny chick, fallen from its nest, could not hope to be rescued by one gentler or more caring. That is true beauty, because it comes from within.

From your hovel you can observe the newcomer.

Felix is transformed. All trace of sorrow has gone from his face as he brings the stranger a succession of plates of food and cups of milk and water and wine, while she and Agatha and Father laugh to see him so joyful.
It is soon clear that she does not speak the same words as they. That's why Felix brings her everything he has in the larder. Gradually she makes herself understood by signs, and with a cup of coffee in front of her she describes what must have been her journey. The flow of words is as beautiful - and as meaningless - as the babbling of a brook.
The others sit in attitudes of polite attention, but it is obvious to you that they don't know any of her words either.
She is like you, then, in not being able to communicate?

xoptx That's so.

xoptx Not really.

Exactly like you. She is a stranger among people to whom she is incapable of expressing the good intentions of her heart, because she does not know their words. But every nuance of her feelings is clear to you, as one of kindred spirit.
Hardly, for she is beautiful and she is welcome.
Her names are Safiye and Beloved. You stay with your face pressed against the crack in the wall, hanging on every incomprehensible syllable that falls from her lips - as does Felix. It is as though his nerves, previously made torpid by melancholy, have been instantaneously thrilled into life by some spark, driving him to and fro about the room. He can't sit for more than a minute without jumping up to bring Safiye something, or to hold her hand and smother it with kisses. Agatha laughs and says 'Calm' and 'Down' and 'Silly'.
When you look up, you are amazed to find the whole day has gone. Inside they're already lighting candles for the evening meal. You've eaten nothing for hours, and the sight of their supper makes your stomach growl so loudly you fear they might hear it through the walls.

xoptx Will you continue to spy on them?

xoptx Or go out into the woods?

It's interesting to watch them eat. Each time Safiye asks for a plate to be passed to her, she makes Felix Brother say the word. She then repeats it over and over, allowing him to correct her. In the space of just an hour you learn jug and bluebells and carafe and thank you and apricot and full up. And the last, made with a gesture expressive of a full stomach, is a lie, because you can see that the tiny meal has left her still hungry.

You could learn in the same way.

You walk through the woods and for once you feel part of nature, rather than a boil upon her body. The undergrowth ripples in a light breeze. Flowers make constellations of pale radiance among the deep moonlit shadows. The tiny eyes of woodland creatures glitter in the dark, and the contemplative hooting of owls seems to welcome you across the threshold of a new and more hopeful era in your life.

xoptx Do you go back and get some sleep?

xoptx Or stay out in the woods for a while?

You are too excited to sleep, even though the effort of concentrating all day on the flood of new sensations is, you now discover, as exhausting as physical labour. Finding a secluded glade deep in the forest, you decide to risk lighting a fire. It is the work of moments to gather some twigs, and for kindling you rip a few pages from thea book you found in the pocket of your gown.
You don't even look at the pages until they start to catch alight. But as the edges glow redly and start to char, the topmost page flutters back to reveal a drawing. Jumping to your feet, you snatch it from the fire and desperately beat out the flames.
It is a picture of your own hand.

xoptx What use is that? Burn it.

xoptx There may be more drawings in the book.

You drop the torn page back onto the fire and watch as it blackens and curls. You want no reminders of your dimly remembered past. With Safiye's arrival you have the chance to study the language as she does, and then you will no longer belong in the midnight dells of the woods, but can take your place at the table with other men.

A worthy goal.

There are, and not only of your hand. There are detailed drawings of bones, showing how the skeleton is articulated, with arrows to indicate where muscles are attached. On another page you find a series of sketches of a face, developing in stages from an object that looks like a dissected snail through layers of complexity till - you flip through the pages urgently till you find it, there: the countenance you know so well and have grown to loathe. The glistening red-striped nightmare thing with bared teeth and translucent-lidded eyes that looks back at you whenever you kneel by a pool to drink.
Then this book contains the secrets of your origin. If you could decipher how words are written... It seems an impossible goal, but you must learn! Now that Safiye is here you have a chance to learn the language as she does. Then, somehow, you must learn reading too. And at last you will know where you came from.

Tonight you made an important discovery.

The days now pass as peacefully as before, but with the difference that the cloud of sadness has lifted from the household. The warmer weather makes life easier for the family, and Safiye's arrival has brought a thawing of the heart for Felix who, in the vigour and enthusiasm with which he approaches his daily chores, is like a man remade.
Safiye improves quickly in her knowledge of the language and, by eavesdropping on her lessons, so do you. Within two months you have learned most of the everyday words. You practice them at night, calling out into the woods where the trees muffle your elated shouts.
While mastering speech, you also look in on the lessons Felix gives Safiye in reading. He has a blackboard on which he forms each letter in chalk, and it does not escape your notice how tenderly he guides her hand in copying out each day's lesson. What do you think lies behind their relationship?

xoptx He wants to give her his love.

xoptx He wants something from her.

The love between Felix and Safiye is different from the love you have observed within the family. The latter is always a quiet, contented affection, revealed in the small sacrifices they make for each other, often in secret. They do not need to seek out each other's company. It seems to you that it is akin to your own undemonstrative love for the seasons and the land.
But Felix's love for Safiye is ardent and consuming, like thirst. He cannot sit silently with her, except at those times he watches her with the same expression as when enraptured by music. The rest of the time he is forever bringing her inconsequential gifts, or teasing her, or finding excuses to touch her. It is no mystery. When you see Safiye your instinct is to protect her. Felix must think as you do.

When you can read, everything will be clearer.

You have learnt one thing about human nature, and it is that nothing is given without the aim of receiving something in return. Your family cherish each other because of some calamity that has left them without servants in a house too big to heat properly. They need each other or they would be alone and helpless - a condition you know all too well.
By the same token, Felix wants something from Safiye. So far you have not been able to determine what it is, only that his desire is urgent and is but scantily satisfied by being in her presence. Comparing his behaviour to your own small stock of unrefined emotions, you guess that what he is feeling is a kind of hunger. Certainly he watches Safiye with the keen attention that Childebrandthe cat watches a mouse hole.

And you? What do you want?

You do not exempt yourself from your own dispassionate analysis. You desire kindness and companionship - commodities as vital to life, you believe, as food and shelter. Shut out from society as you are, you are like a severed limb that dies for want of blood. You would give the family physical protection and the benefit of your labour, as indeed you do already, in return for a place by the hearth. It is a transaction in which they will figure your monstrous appearance, but you believe the balance is still in your favour.

Learning to read will help.

Felix bases the lessons principally on a book called Ruins of Empires. At first you have no real idea of the difference between various books, other than that one might deal with true things and another with stories which seem to be fashioned merely to entertain. But Felix explains that he has selected this book because it is written in imitation of an Oriental style, which you infer to be something with which Safiye may be more familiar.

xoptx Why is that?

xoptx What do you learn from this particular book?

Felix teaches her largely from a book called Ruins of Empires. He explains to Safiye that he has selected this book because it is written in imitation of 'the Oriental style', which you infer to be something with which she may be more familiar.
Naturally, the book you are most eager to read is the one you found in the pocket of your gown. You have already deciphered the first page: Frankenstein. A name? He is described as conqueror, and his book contains the truth about how you came to be. Never did a pupil have greater motivation to learn. You listen with rapt attention as Felix begins the lessons.

xoptx What about Safiye's origins?

xoptx What do you learn from Felix's book?

She is from a land called Turkey, which lies far to the east. Felix often calls her 'his Arabian' but he smiles when he says that, so you think it is a kind of teasing. You gradually piece together her story from listening to them talk. She has another name, Betrothed, and it seems that her father was a friend of the old man - so 'father' is a description that can be attached to more than one person.

Do you wonder if you have a father?

xoptx Do you wonder if you have a father?

xoptx And what do you discover from this book of Felix's?

The book imparts a cursory knowledge of history, and of the countries and empires into which the world is divided. And in its discussion of the customs and beliefs of different peoples, you begin to glean something of the eternal nature of man.
You learn that men can be virtuous. They can create magnificent works of art and music that surpass the beauties of nature. Such a man is supposed to be lauded over all others, praised, conceived of as noble and even godlike. Yet they can also be vicious, crude, selfish. Though society deplores such a one, and affects to despise him, that ignominy seems no deterrent - men still act wickedly. Strangest of all, it is possible for one man to be both good and evil.
You must have seen enough of mankind by now to judge which side is dominant?

xoptx Good.

xoptx Evil.

A man might give a little of his meagre supper to a kitten, or stop in his work to rescue a fallen sparrow from the path of a plough. If such kindness and meekness is present in human nature, and praised by religion and philosophy alike, how can the darkness ever be stronger than the light?
Certainly there is evil in the world - you hear enough of it in the accounts Felix reads of wars waged and tortures inflicted - but it seems to you that it is not the desire to do evil for its own sake that provokes these deeds. Men are wicked out of fear or anger, because they distrust what they do not understand, because they dread harm from another's hand if they fail to strike first. It is ignorance and lack of empathy that allows evil to flourish. Exposed to the light of reason and commerce, it must wither like an unwatered weed.

xoptx What else do you learn from the book?

xoptx Never mind philosophy. What about the girl?

xoptx What do you think about what you've learned?

Though society deplores one who is base and vicious, and affects to despise him, that ignominy seems hardly a deterrent. Men still act wickedly. For a long time, hearing Felix read passages from the book that describe acts of evil, you can find no spark of empathy with the perpetrators. They seem another species, far removed from the man who would give a little of his meagre supper to a kitten, or rescue a mouse from the path of a plough. Why murder? Why steal? Why is it necessary to have laws and governments? But when you hear the details of all the wars that have been waged and blood spilled through the ages, you can only turn away with disgust and loathing, glad that you are not made as other men.
Thus you surmise that the true nature of man is malicious, and it is only laws and the invented punishments of heaven that it has been possible to tame him to moments of virtue.

xoptx What else do you learn from the book?

xoptx Never mind philosophy. What about the girl?

xoptx How is this new knowledge changing you?

You must do. The old man has even referred to his own father, a long-dead figure whom Felix and Agatha call Grandfather, so it seems that everyone has a father. Yours must have written the book you found - Frankenstein, Victor. When you have mastered reading you will be able to find out what message he left for you in the book and, if he is alive, you may discover clues that will enable you to seek him out.Apparently you do not - or, if you do, he is dead. Fathers protect their children. Perhaps there was some deadly threat to you and your father saved you, but at the cost of his own life. That would explain faint memories you have of pain, confusion and fear. There was one who cast you out. Was he your father's murderer? If only you could remember.

xoptx What does Felix's book teach you?

xoptx What do you think about your new knowledge?

What do you think about your new knowledge?

The author talks about justice, and you are interested to hear that he asserts all men are equal, free and entitled to the produce of their labour. Encouragingly, it seems that Felix agrees with these sentiments, although he qualifies them by adding that it is in their potential for equality and freedom that men are created the same.
'An equal right to liberty?' ventures Safiye in her fluidly accented French.
Felix turns to the next chapter. 'If they do not resort to force of arms to assert that right,' he mutters darkly.
You long ago realized that some have more than others. Your family have a larger home than most of the farmers who live in the vicinity, but they have less food and livestock, and can only gather enough fuel to keep one room properly heated in winter.
Which interests you most:

xoptx What the book has to say about such things?

xoptx Or how all this knowledge will change you?

Not only the book itself. As your understanding grows, every conversation of your friends now opens new wonders. Having read the chapter about social justice, Safiye is brimming with questions which continue long after the lesson is over. During supper she asks, 'If there is natural equality, why are some wealthy and some live in squalid - this is the correct word, squalid? - poverty?'
Felix sweeps his hand in a gesture that invites her to see the reduced circumstances in which they live. 'This new regime has not brought about equality, it has merely turned the natural order upside-down.'
'It is all because of envy,' laments the old man.
'But if there is equality,' says Safiye, 'how can there be envy?'

xoptx What do you think Felix meant by that?

xoptx How does this all apply to you?

xoptx Are things getting clearer as you learn more?

Apparently the De Lacys - for that is the name of your family - were formerly wealthy. Felix makes frequent reference to local fields as though he owned them, though it is clear that he receives no produce from them except when he agrees to work for the local cottagers. On those days he is often in a surly mood, though Safiye's smile always dispels it.
The lesson seems to be that strength enables you to take what you want. The cottagers are more numerous, so they took the De Lacys' fields. But how did the De Lacys come to own so much of the land to begin with? That remains a mystery. Felix is right to say that the current division is inequitable, though if you consider it impartially, as the book's author purports to, you must admit that it seems less inequitable than before. But are you impartial?

xoptx Yes.

xoptx No.

You have seen how your fellow man esteems riches. Without any means of his own, a person is but a vagabond or a slave and has no hope of acquiring better status except by theft. You have no money, no friends, no property of any kind. Moreover, beauty is another commodity - but you are poor in that too, being hideously deformed and loathsome not only to others, but in your own sight.
Even the attributes that stand in your favour only set you further apart from other men. You are stronger, more agile. You can subsist on a coarser diet and endure extremes of heat and cold that, you now realize, would kill anyone else. But what use is that? When you look around, where are the others of your kind? You are alone - a monster, a blot upon the Earth. All men flee from you. The only emotions they can feel for you are fear and hatred. Gazing in through the crack at your family, you have never felt further from hope of achieving the love you crave. With an effort you stifle a racking sob.
Safiye looks up. She looks straight at you! 'What was that?'
'A fox,' says Agatha. 'They sound so human when they cry, don't they? Like an infant in pain.'

The world must seem different to you now.

You cannot help but recall the very lesson Felix taught today: 'Men being equal and free, owing nothing to each other, have no right to require anything from one another unless they return an equal value for it.'
It is clear, then, that it would be impossible for a virtuous man to become wealthier than his neighbours, for he could only do that by exploiting them. The painful conclusion is that one of Felix's ancestors must have been lacking in virtue. However, the balance of equality is now restored, and you are sure that no blame attaches to Felix himself.

xoptx How does this all apply to you personally?

xoptx Are you making progress in your studies?

Not at all. The De Lacys are your family. The author of the book may say as he wishes, but the truth is that personal loyalty is the greatest of virtues. In any case, you have seen the greater intelligence with which Felix addresses himself to any task. He plans what he will do, and completes each task methodically - quite unlike the haphazard labours of the local peasants whom you have watched toiling in the fields. If you were one of those peasants, you would be glad to work for Felix, for you can see that he has superior virtue, wisdom and breeding to the common herd of men, and would be a lord whom it would honour you to serve.

xoptx How does this all apply to you personally?

xoptx How do you feel your knowledge is progressing?

Knowledge clings to the mind like lichen on a rock. There are times you'd like to shake off all thought and feeling and return to the inchoate state in which you first roamed the countryside. You knew pain and discomfort then. Men spurned you. But you were not tortured by possibilities. You were as unaware of tomorrow as any wild beast. But now you have acquired learning. And what it tells you is that, if history is any guide, you are doomed to be regarded as a monster.
But surely there is hope that, having learnt to read, you can educate your mind and find a way to overcome the circumstances of your creation?

xoptx Yes, there must be.

xoptx No, there is no hope.

You are learning the extraordinary power of words. They could be the key. Words are not merely names with which to label things; they can alter what they describe. A man could be labelled a tyrant or a traitor, and from then on the word becomes a cage to confine him. A tyrant or a traitor is all that he can be. But strip away the word, and the man underneath could change. A 'tyrant' is evil, but any man can be kind. A 'traitor' is by nature treacherous, but even that man may prove trustworthy and loyal. Words have too much power to be used carelessly. So you resolve not to think of yourself as 'monster'. You are a being like any other, equal in the eyes of your creator.

You'd learn faster if you had books of your own.

There is only one way to overcome pain, and that is death - a state which you fear, having heard of it from books, yet do not understand. You love the gentle manners and amiable qualities of your protectors, as you see them, but you are shut out from intercourse with them. You can only observe them furtively, when you are unseen and unknown, which increases rather than satisfies your desire for companionship. The gentle words of Agatha, and the animated smiles of the charming Safiye - these are not for you. Nor the mild exhortations of the old man and Felix's lively, intelligent conversation.
You have heard about the difference between the sexes, about the birth and growth of children. According to what is written in books, the right state of things is for the father to dote on the smiles of the infant. As youth acquires experience, each human being has brother, sister, friends, and all the various relationships which bind one person to another in mutual bonds.
But where are your friends and relations? No father watched your infant days. No mother blessed you with smiles and caresses. Or, if they did, all your past life is now a blind vacancy. From your earliest remembrance you have been as you are now in height and proportion. You have never yet seen a being resembling you, or who claims any intercourse with you. What are you? The question recurs again and again, to be answered only with tortured fancies. If there is an answer to your predicament in books, you have yet to find it.

You'd learn faster with books of your own.

One night, while foraging in the wood, you venture further than usual and come upon a road. On the far side, the ground slopes steeply away towards a surging river. You stand for a moment enjoying the sensation of overlooking the tops of the mighty pines, which you are used to seeing soar high up on all sides high above you. The sky is already getting lighter, and you are just about to head back to your lair when you notice a leather trunk in the ditch beside the road. A broken rope lies beside it, by which you gather it must have fallen from one of the coaches you have seen only from afar.
It is locked, but you quickly break the hasp. What a treasure trove! There is a thick cloak, along with shirts and fabric with which you should be able to make yourself good clothing before the winter. And beneath that you find a still greater prize: several books.
Back in the hovel, you investigate your find. Some are written in a language you don't know, but there are three you can decipher. They are John Milton's Paradise Lost, a volume of Plutarch's Lives of the Noble Greeks and Romans, and Travels by Thomas Jefferson. Now you can study and improve your mind throughout the day, without having to wait for Safiye's next lesson.
Which do you look at first?

xoptx Paradise Lost.

xoptx Plutarch.

xoptx Jefferson's Travels.

The book comprises short biographies of men who, you gather, lived long ago and did great deeds, governing ancient republics on which the precepts of liberty and equality are founded. Plutarch's writings elevate you above the wretchedness of your own condition as your imagination carries you among the admirable heroes of past ages. You feel sure that Pyrrhus would have welcomed you among the ranks of his companions, that Cato would have perceived in you an integrity to match his own, that the Spartans would have admired your fortitude and the Athenians your dedication to acquiring wisdom.
Plutarch intended a lesson in juxtaposing these lives. Some of the men he describes dedicate their lives to great works and public affairs, others to massacring or enslaving their species. Your studies have equipped you with a sophisticated mind, so the lesson does not escape your notice, but to which kind of story are you most drawn?

xoptx To peace.

xoptx To war.

The household of your protectors has been the only school in which you have studied human nature. Perhaps that is why this book evokes in you a great abhorrence for vice. Induced by such feelings, you admire peaceable lawgivers like Numa, Solon and Lycurgus in preference to warlords such as Romulus and Theseus. The benevolent lives of the De Lacys no doubt caused these attitudes to take a firm hold on your mind. If your first introduction to humanity had been from observing a group of soldiers burning for glory and slaughter, you might have been imbued with different sensations.
What will you read next?

xoptx Paradise Lost.

xoptx Jefferson's Travels.

xoptx Or do you possess another book?

Do you possess another book?

Though your reading has opened up a vast store of ideas, including the wisest teachings of those long dead, you still have little direct experience that would allow you to clearly interpret the concepts written here. Your understanding of virtue and vice, which Plutarch describes as though they were inherent qualities of nature, is limited to the sensations of pleasure and pain. And though pleasure and virtue are desirable, they are hard to sustain. Clothes must be darned and patched, fires must be continually stoked, comfort and peace are hard-won and fleeting. Men resort to violence because violence is easy, and feeds itself - it is not the hearth, it is the forest fire. Whenever you have confronted men, they have met you with anger and hate. Therefore that is the side of your nature that is doomed to hold sway over your actions, though you could wish it otherwise.
What will you read next?

xoptx Paradise Lost.

xoptx Jefferson's Travels.

xoptx Do you possess another book?

Do you possess another book?

Paradise Lost excites different and far deeper emotions.As you turn the pages of Paradise Lost, you feel as though you have taken flight on wings of imagination with no idea where the voyage will take you. You read it, just as you read the other books you found, as a true history. An omnipotent God, challenged by his creatures, vanquishes them in a titanic war and casts them down. As you turn the pages, though lying still and silent in the mouldy interior of the ruined outhouse, you feel your pulse racing as images of lightning, blood and rain seem to lash around you. This book is like a key to your own life - but is it hard to decide whether you are more like Adam, or like Satan?

xoptx Adam, certainly.

xoptx Adam.

xoptx Satan.

Of course. For are you not, like Adam, united by no link to any other being in existence? And yet in other ways Adam's state is very different from yours. He came forth from the hands of God a perfect being, happy and prosperous, guarded by the especial care of his maker. He was allowed to converse with, and acquire knowledge from, beings of a superior nature. By contrast, you are wretched, helpless, and alone - as Adam was after he transgressed against God's rules.
Is that it? Did you anger your father so that he cast you out? But, if so, why do you have no memory of it?
Perhaps you'll find some clue to unlock the secrets of the past in the other books:

xoptx Plutarch's Lives.

xoptx Jefferson's Travels.

xoptx Have you another book you should look at?

Have you another book you should look at?

Like Adam, you are united by no link to any other being in existence. And yet in other ways Adam's state is very different from yours. He came forth from the hands of God a perfect being, happy and prosperous, guarded by the especial care of his maker. He was allowed to converse with, and acquire knowledge from, beings of a superior nature. By contrast, you are wretched, helpless, and alone - as Adam was after he transgressed against God's rules.
Is that it? Did you anger your father so that he cast you out? But, if so, why do you have no memory of it? Perhaps you'll find some clue to unlock the secrets of your past in the other books:

xoptx Plutarch's Lives.

xoptx Jefferson's Travels.

xoptx Have you another book you should look at?

Have you another book you should look at?

Like Adam, you are united by no link to any other being in existence. Yet, as you read on, you begin to see Satan as the fitter emblem of your condition - for often, like him, when you view the bliss enjoyed by Felix and the others, you cannot fight the bitter gall of envy that rises within you.
What about the other books:

xoptx Plutarch's Lives.

xoptx Jefferson's Travels.

xoptx Have you yet another book you should look at?

Have you yet another book you should look at?

Jefferson's book implies that he crossed a vast ocean in order to tour about the countries of France and Italy. The purpose seems merely to have been leisure, and in his description of lolling on feather beds, and buttering fresh-baked bread, and of ripe fruits plucked from sun-drenched orchards, you feel as if those memories could almost leap across from his mind to your own. His prose is easy and elegant, lacking the grandeur of formal authors, but with the sense rather of an agreeable conversation. So absolutely does his prose work its spell that, when he writes of the necessity of 'ferreting the country people out of their hovels' you start and look round in alarm, momentarily convinced that Jefferson himself has thrust aside the ramshackle door of the outhouse and, having discovered you, is standing there smiling in the hot white blaze of the sun.
Still, engrossing as it is, this book seems to give few insights into your condition or the great mysteries of human society which you hope to decipher. Perhaps one of the others?

xoptx Plutarch's Lives.

xoptx Paradise Lost.

xoptx Read a little further in this book.

xoptx Is there another book you've overlooked?

You are excited to discover that Jefferson's reason for the journey was not mere sightseeing, but to visit a spring in southern France said to have curative properties. 'On the advice of my surgeon,' he writes, 'I shall take the waters in the hope of restoring my hand.'
These words send you leafing frantically back and forth through the book. What was wrong with Jefferson's hand? You envisage it like your own, a thing like a rabbit skinned and laid out on the kitchen table. Perhaps Jefferson wore a glove to conceal it from prying eyes. And, in bathing in the chemicals of the spring, did it acquire a seemly clothing of fair skin?
And this is France! And you know south from north by the stars you have heard Felix name to the old man as they walk in the garden. You could find this spring and, unfinished as you are, perhaps it could make you whole and human.
If this book found at random, which seemed so unpromising, turned out to be so apposite to your case, what might you find in others? What will you look at now?

xoptx Plutarch's Lives.

xoptx Paradise Lost.

xoptx Is there another book you've forgotten about?

Is there another book you've forgotten about?

In the pocket of your gown is a book you have carried for almost a year without knowing where it came from or who gave it to you. You almost dread to read it, having glimpsed drawings inside that can only be of you.
Opening it now, you are stunned to find yourself confronted with a meticulous drawing of the very hand that holds the book. So it is a book about you...
Some of the pages are missing. In the days of your earliest memory, when you were but a brute with no thought for past or future, you were in the habit of using them for kindling. You could howl in pain when you think of it now. Each precious page contains details of your origin - the only record, perhaps, of how you came to be.
The book keeps you spellbound for hours. When you look up, the family have had their supper and retired to bed, and half the night is gone, and you feel as though you had stepped off a cliff and are falling headlong into a fate that will swallow you entirely.

What is in the book?

It is the journal of Victor Frankenstein. In it he describes the months that led up to your inception, minutely setting out every step he took in the progress of his work. It is no story of divine creation. No clay became flesh by the agency of thunderbolt or blazing sun. Instead you are forced by self-torturing curiosity to read the whole series of disgusting circumstances that produced a misshapen golem of reconstructed flesh and assembled parts. The minutest description of your odious and loathsome creation is given, in language which vividly paints your maker's horrors and renders yours indelible. You feel sick but you cannot tear your eyes away.
'Hateful day when I received life!' you groan in agony. 'Cursed creator! Why did you form a monster so hideous that even you turned from me in disgust? God, in pity, made Man beautiful and alluring, after his own image. But my form is a filthy type of yours, more horrid from its very resemblance. Satan had his companions, fellow-devils, to admire and encourage him, but I am solitary and detested.'

xoptx Can you bear to read on?

xoptx Or have you seen enough?

If only you had used the whole book to light that first fire - at least it would have warmed you, and you need never have discovered the awful truth. Now you dash it down, stamp on it, tear at the covers with your teeth. You want to destroy it but then, your anger spent, you gather up every loose page and carefully put them all back in order, sobbing as you do. It is a hateful thing, but it is all you have of your creator.

The scientific account of your manufacture is mixed in with random comments, domestic observations, shopping lists and even sketches of Frankenstein's family. You hang on every word and drawing, desperate to know as much as you can about the man who made you.
And then, turning the page, you find a note in the margin that you have to read over and over:
'Specimen is shaping up to be quite an abomination! Need to acquire about 150 litres sulphuric acid. Will liquidate it when efficacy of the process is established. Second phase, working with a team of surgeons, will be to construct something more acceptably proportioned.'
So your maker never intended you to live.

A terrible revelation.

The scientific account of your manufacture is mixed in with random comments, domestic observations, shopping lists and even sketches of Frankenstein's family. You hang on every word and drawing, desperate to know as much as you can about the man who made you.
The image that emerges is of a brilliant man, driven by genius and ambition to the edge of exhaustion. A man of such accomplishments, who meant to do work of the greatest benefit to mankind. His love of his friends and family is evident even in the brief notes and sketches he includes. No doubt Frankenstein is a man as great as any of the savants of the ancient world. A man in whom the spark of the divine is surely present. And yet that perfect man has a flaw, a deep and fatal rift into the very heart of his character. Because, for all his talk of the good of man, and liberty and love and all the virtues - for all that, he still regarded you, whom he should have protected and nurtured as the masterwork of his own hands, as merely a experiment. An object without a soul.

A terrible revelation.

END OF CHAPTER TWO


CHAPTER THREE
CHAPTER THREE
The Hour and Moment of Trial

Autumn arrives with a sharp, damp smell like faraway smoke. From overheard conversations, you were already aware that the seasons are cyclical and that winter would come again. But during the long months of summer you had the opportunity to forget the gnawing cold and bleak lightless days that accompany the year's end. Now it is with surprise and grief that you see the leaves change and fall. As nature again assumes the bleak appearance it wore in those confused days when you first beheld the sun and moon, you feel a deep melancholy settle on you. The flowers and birds that sustained your spirits have deserted you. A year has passed and nothing has been achieved. Or has it?

xoptx You know the name of your creator.

xoptx You can now converse with your fellow man.

xoptx Or do these thoughts give you no comfort at all?

At lunch today, Agatha puts a bowl of dried flowers in the middle of the table.
'That's a lovely scent, darling,' says the old man with a smile.
'Oh yes, Agatha,' says Safiye, whose grasp of French now is nearly as good as yours, 'it make me to forget the sad going of summer.'
From here you can't smell the flowers, but you think they make a lovely splash of warm autumnal colours against the white of the vase and the tablecloth.
'It's to cover up the smell,' says Agatha, looking towards the crack above the hearth that is your spy-hole. 'I've been noticing it for months - haven't you? I think a rat died in the wall.'

There is a knock at the door.

You get encouragement from a story Agatha is telling the others over lunch. She went into the nearby village this morning, and found that some people had shut a simple-minded lad in the pillory and were amusing themselves by pelting him with rotten fruit.
'I thought I smelled plums,' says the old man. 'I hoped you were baking a pie.'
'Father! It's not funny.'
'No indeed,' says Felix, 'you'll be scrubbing that blouse for a week.'
'I had to get him out of there, didn't I?' she goes on, ignoring them. 'The boy was in tears. I can't believe people can be so cruel.'
'They have to find new targets to persecute now that their Revolution has done away with the old villains,' says Felix, a sour look replacing his laughter.

There is a knock at the door.

And not just his name. You know he is a native of Geneva, a city somewhere to the south. Equipped with Jefferson's diary of his travels, you might be able to find it. But what then? You conjure up an image of yourself, raw-boned and naked, approaching a burgher of the city and asking directions to the house of Frankenstein.
At this notion, an unaccustomed noise bursts from your lungs. You are quaking and gasping for breath, and you have to press your face to the ground so that the family on the other side of the wall won't hear. You've seen this emotion in Felix and the others. It's mirth. But their laughter is so gentle and temperate, easily stifled behind a hand, while yours is a coarse, irresistible outpouring of guttural cries. Brute that you are, your feelings so uncultivated - what would Felix and Agatha think if you presented yourself to them, even if you were not so hideous?
And yet, that laughter... It felt good.

xoptx You are learning what it is to be human. They will see that.

xoptx Ugly as you are, you can rely on their kindness.

You have learned a great deal from the De Lacys - not only how to speak and read, but how to conduct yourself well, to love virtue and forswear evil. Their amiable and benevolent dispositions allow you to persuade yourself that they would overlook your personal deformity. Could they turn from their door one, however monstrous, who solicited their compassion and friendship?
Therefore you are firmly set against the despair and dread that constantly threaten to creep into your heart. If you carefully groom yourself for an interview with them, it may be that you will not need to spend another year in furtive exile.
This has become a fond dream, and you are aware that you must not postpone it too long in case the magnitude of expectation overwhelms your courage. You dread to fail - but you must not think of failing. Your understanding improves so much with every day's experience that you must soon be ready to take your place in the community of man.

Not long now.

You have spent a year living in squalor, with fear your constant companion. Even at night, out in the woods a long way from any habitation, you dread to hear the crack of a twig that might announce some wandering pedlar or traveller - not because you fear any physical danger, for you know now that you have the strength of ten ordinary men, but because discovery would drive you from the one haven you have been able to find. And it would drive you, too, from the De Lacy family whom you have come to love as your friends and protectors. It is dangerous to harbour such feelings. In your more rational moments you understand that. But, starved of affection and company as you are, you cannot help weaving fantasies of acceptance in which you imagine yourself sitting among the family, perhaps being taught the harpsichord by Father, his old hands guiding yours, or reading aloud to Felix something that has caught your attention in a book.
Foolishness, mere foolishness! If they ever were to accept you, your status among them would be lower than a servant. And yet, that would be enough.

It would indeed. You must speak to them soon.

The family's happiness is not decreased by the passing of summer. They love one another and their joys, depending only on each other, are not interrupted by the casualties that take place around them. The more you observe them, the more you long to claim their protection and kindness. Your heart yearns to be known and loved by these amiable creatures. To see their gentle looks directed towards you with affection is all that you desire.
Might they turn you away with disdain and horror, as others have? You dare not think so. The beggars that stop at their door are never driven away, even though God knows the family have little enough themselves. You will be asking, it is true, for rather more than a scrap of food or old clothing. You require kindness and sympathy, and a place among them. Yet have you not striven to be worthy of them? You can't believe your petition to be utterly without merit.
So do you think you are ready to approach them?

xoptx Yes.

xoptx Not sure.

Their visitor is a man in a floppy red hat that reminds you of the one the old man wears to bed. He wears no wig, and with his hair sticking out scruffily and the warily puzzled look in his eyes, he resembles a chick that has been pushed out of its nest.
Safiye and the De Lacys stand to receive him. He has two armed men with him, but he tells them to wait at the door. The atmosphere in the room is tense. Seeing the drawn look on Felix's face, you realize that your own hands are clenched and your breath feels short and raw. You're not sure you can bear to lie still and quiet here.

xoptx Run off to hide in the woods.

xoptx Stay and watch what happens.

It is the only safe course of action. If you remained pent up in the narrow hovel, all the while stirred by the impulsion of whatever violent emotion you have caught from Felix's manner, you might not be able to stop yourself from crying out in rage - and then all would be lost.
You remain under a hedge on the far side of the lawn until you see the man in the red hat leave. Creeping back to your lair, you continue to work on a suit of clothes you are making from items you found in the travelling chest.
'You have a harpsichord,' says the man, jabbing several times at one of the keys. He notes the old man's wince. 'I prefer the violin myself. I find the sound of the harpsichord too old-fashioned.'
Felix draws a breath and you feel sure from his thunderous expression that he is about to say, 'Of course you do.' You even mouth the words. But instead he breaks out in a smile and says, 'Me too.'
Felix's good humour, though obviously insincere, pleases the visitor. The tension does not entirely dissipate, but you no longer feel the empathic throb of impending violence.
This is new - the lesson that one emotion, so powerful that it hangs in the air like a vibration, can be swept away and hidden under the mask of another. In the honesty of their dealings with each other, the family have given you few opportunities to observe such dissimulation, yet you can see how useful it must be in society at large. To feel one thing and feign another - yes, to be fully human, you must master that.

xoptx Do you take time to process this new concept?

xoptx Or are you more intent on seeing what happens next?

You know the family so well by now that you can simulate their thoughts and emotions in your imagination. At times, to dispel the solitude while wandering in the woods at night, you have invented whole conversations between Felix and Safiye that prove to be uncannily close to a real exchange they will have later. Perhaps that is to be expected. Since you learned to speak and read by observing them, it's inevitable that you would absorb some of their character too.
Thus, by placing yourself in Felix's shoes, you can play out in your mind a version of all the disdain, circumspection and anxiety with which he received the visitor. And then you practise overlaying all those emotions with a counterfeit of good humour and hospitality.
It is an effective trick. You have learned how to lie.
You cannot conceive of how Felix could misrepresent his feelings like that. Has he not often spoken of his esteem for the teachings of Marcus Aurelius, who said that a man should present the same face to friend and foe alike? You are a little disappointed to find your friend falling short of his principles in such a way and, after due reflection, you decide to forswear such behaviour yourself. You consider yourself a true Stoic: 'If it is not right, do not do it. If it is not true, do not say it.'
As the visitor has left by the time you go back to the crack in the wall, you return to work on a suit of clothes you are making from items you found in the travelling chest. Soon you will introduce yourself to the De Lacys, and you must look the part. Vestis virum reddit, after all - the clothing makes the man.

Now decide when you will approach them.

'Your guest here,' the visitor is saying. 'A foreigner?'
'My fiancée,' says Felix.
'She has papers? Never mind, we can check.'
'Sir, if you can tell me - ' says Felix, anxious to draw the conversation away from Safiye.
'Citizen.'
'Pardon me, citizen. Perhaps you can tell me why you're here?'
'This house has been deemed too large for one family.'
'We are really only able to live in a few rooms these days, citizen.'
'It is too large. You will need to move out.'
'Where would we go?' cries Agatha in alarm.
'Find honest employment and accommodation will follow. This house is a relic of the unacceptable past. It will be torn down.'
'What about my books?' says the old man. It is a tone of patrician authority you have not heard from him before, and it seems to daunt the visitor for a moment.
'You have a lot of books, don't you, citizen?' He picks one up with a pettish gesture, riffling the pages, and you feel a stab of indignation when you realize that he cannot even read. 'Have they been appraised?'
'Appraised?' says the old man less confidently.
'Officially sanctioned. To ensure they contain no sedition.'
The visitor stays long enough to take coffee and cake, but he doesn't sit down or remove his floppy red cap. When he finally leaves, the tension departs with him like air from a deflating balloon.

xoptx Listen to what the family say about the visit.

xoptx Get ready for your own meeting with them.

The luggage you found by the roadside contained clothing as well as books. It is all too small for your giant frame, of course, but you have watched Agatha at her sewing often enough. With needle and thread you took from the house, you have been working on a suit of clothes that will make you presentable for the all-important first encounter with the De Lacys.
Nobody says anything for a while, but it is impossible not to sense the undercurrent of shock and dismay. Finally Felix flings down the boots he's been scrubbing. 'An outrage!' he fumes.
'I don't see why they have to come and bother us,' says Agatha forlornly. 'We lost our land and our servants, isn't that enough?'
Only the old man remains unperturbed. 'In a week that man will be either promoted to a different department or guillotined in a purge. '
'But it is the government,' says Safiye.
The old man gives a bleak laugh. 'There is no government. They cut off its head. Now they are a beehive when the queen is gone, buzzing in useless agitation because, when they finally realize the futility of their cause, they will have to admit that they're finished.'
His equanimity soothes the others' fears, but you can tell that despite his show of calm he's really worried. The visitor - who must be some sort of official, despite his unprepossessing appearance - clearly has the power to evict your friends from their home. But you have power too. What should you do?

xoptx Pursue the official?

xoptx Or prepare yourself to meet the De Lacys?

Your black dressing gown is in tatters, but it was your first possession and you are too fond of it to throw it away. Patched up, it becomes an undershirt. There was no wig in the case, but you did find a hat folded under the books and clothes. Wide-brimmed and floppy, obviously intended for hot summer days, it gives no protection from the bite of autumn chill, but it serves to disguise the great glistening dome of your skull and shade from others' view the penetrating stare of those unpalpebrated eyes.

xoptx Do you want to try out your clothing?

xoptx Or are you now ready?

You hang around the border of the woods at daybreak until you see a man with a scythe walking on the far side of the field. He is a long way off. Stepping out from the trees, you raise your hand in greeting.
And he waves back. He waves. A simple gesture that men make to each other every day. It means more to you than anything you can remember. Your heart is pounding in elation as you turn back into the enveloping comfort of the woods.

Now you are ready.

It isn't hard to track him. He leaves heading north and you find his horse at the first inn on that road. Hidden in the hedge, you wait until the last drinker staggers out and the lights are put out. Creeping up to the window, you see his two guards stretched out on wooden pallets in the common room. With the aid of an apple tree you climb up to the next floor and look in. The first room has two figures - the innkeeper and his wife, probably. In the next window, you see the floppy red cap.
The catch yields to the pressure of your hand. You ease yourself into the room. In the bed lies the man. You hear his breathing change, sense the stiffening of his body.
'You're awake,' you say to him. 'Don't try to cry out.'
'Who are you?'
He is trying to speak loudly, you think, both to assert himself and to rouse his guards. But fear has made his voice a dry whisper.
'Today you threatened friends of mine.'
'The De Lacys?' He sits up, reaches for a taper beside him.

xoptx Let him light it.

xoptx Warn him not to.

He fumbles with a tinderbox. By the time he has it lit, it is to see your face rising into the light on the other side of the bedroom table. His mouth makes all the motions of screaming, but no sound comes out.
'What are you ..?' he finally manages to say.
'I am the death that will come in the night for you if any misfortune should befall the De Lacys.'
He falls back on his pillow, completely bereft of strength.

xoptx He's got the message.

xoptx You can't trust him not to talk.

'Leave that if you value your sanity.'
You stand up to your full height. He can only see a silhouette in the moonlight, but he gets an impression of your size because you hear him gasp.
'Stay back,' he says. 'I carry the authority of the Committee of Public Safety, and...'
You don't have to say anything to silence him, just let your weight press harder on the floorboard.
'I have heard you guillotine men in Paris.'
'We... I don't...' He musters his little courage. 'What of it?'
'If you cause any trouble for the De Lacys, I will find you and I will take off your head. Not with a blade, either.'
'Nothing will happen to them. I never meant to...'
So he says. But can you trust him to stick to his word?

xoptx Yes.

xoptx No.

Leaving the official quaking in his bed, you climb back down and return the way you came. As you creep back into your hovel, you have to stifle a laugh. He won't be getting any sleep tonight.

Now get yourself ready to meet the De Lacys.

'This red hat you petty officials wear. It's called a Phrygian cap. Do you know what the Phrygians are famous for? No? They had a knot that no man could untie. For perhaps a thousand years that was true, until Alexander came to Phrygia.'
You loom over him. He gives a tiny sound, barely a squeak, and presses down into the bedclothes. You reach for him.
'And do you know how Alexander untied the knot ..?'
Perhaps his guards are woken by the blood dripping down through the floorboards, but by that time you are halfway back to your hovel and the moon has already set.

Now get yourself ready to meet the De Lacys.

Your best course will be to wait until De Lacy senior is alone. As the main reason why people react to you in horror is your hideous appearance, it is providential that he, the wisest of your potential benefactors, should also be blind. At least your voice, harsh as it is, is not obviously inhuman. If you can gain his goodwill in the absence of his children, he will mediate on your behalf with them.

Your opportunity comes soon. The sun is slanting on a carpet of red leaves, diffusing cheer if not warmth. Safiye, Agatha and Felix have set out on a long walk. Alone in the cottage, the old man sits at his keyboard playing the opening contrapunctus of Bach's Die Kunst der Fuge. It is a sweet sad air, mournful and yet gloriously so, and he plays with a precision and depth of feeling you have never heard from him before.
You hesitate on the threshold. Though Bach intended this piece of music as merely an exercise, everything human is articulated there. We live and will die. Nothing has meaning except what we give it. And yet the tiny equations of mortal perception contain everything that is beautiful and true.

xoptx Does it make you feel your case is hopeless?

xoptx Or make you more determined to speak to him?

At first his countenance is illuminated with pleasure, but, as he continues, his expression changes to introspection and sadness. Suddenly he lets his fingers drop from the keys and sits motionless, absorbed in reflection. You feel a bond of kinship with this old man whom you have come to know so well. If he, deprived by sightlessness of the books he loves, is able to forge on and find solace and even beauty in a world of darkness, what right have you to self-pity? You knock on the open door.
Your heart is pounding. This is the hour and moment of trial that will decide your whole future. The enormity of emotion makes your limbs feel like dead wood, and you have to fight an urge to flee back to your hovel and pull the concealing planks behind you. A breeze catches your cloak, and the blast of chill air helps to revive you. You knock at the door.
'Who's there? Come in.'
'Pardon this intrusion. I am a traveller in want of a little rest. You would greatly oblige me if you would allow me to remain a few minutes before the fire.'
'Then enter. The warmth of my fire I can freely offer you. Unfortunately my children are not here and, as I am blind, I'm afraid I should find it difficult to fetch you anything to eat or drink.'

xoptx Tell him that doesn't matter.

xoptx Tell him he's already done a lot for you.

'Do not trouble yourself, my kind host, I have food. It is warmth and rest only that I need.'
'Then draw a chair to the fire and sit,' he says.
'I don't understand.' He swivels on the stool, tracking the creak of floorboards as you advance into the room.
'I mean that you are my benefactor.'
'How?'
Careful, you're alarming him. 'By talking to me. Few extend me that courtesy, for an accident of birth left me disfigured.'
'Care I for the limb, the thews, the stature, bulk and big assemblance of a man? Give me the spirit.'
He's quoting. You hazard a guess: 'Shakespeare.'
All wariness evaporates in an instant. He smiles. 'Sit, friend.'
Friend. How marvellous that word is.
Minutes pass in silence. Every moment is precious to you, in case the others should return, yet you are still uncertain how to broach the subject. Perhaps you should ask him to play something?

xoptx No, there isn't time.

xoptx A good idea. It will break the ice.

He seems pleased to be asked. Turning back to the harpsichord, he lets his fingers find the keys and then bursts into a performance of Rameau's Tambourin. It is of a very different mood from the Bach he was playing before you came in - a fast-paced work full of gusto and melodramatic flourishes, a mere entertainment. How disappointing that he doesn't recognize you as a kindred spirit. Yet why should he? You are intimately acquainted with his feelings, but he knows nothing of you.
And there is another problem. Over the volume of the music you cannot make yourself heard. Finally, the only way to stop him playing is to get up and pull his hands from the instrument. He cries out in alarm.
In the abrupt silence, you hear voices on the path outside. The others are coming back. You left it too long.

xoptx Throw yourself on the old man's mercy.

xoptx Get out of here before the others see you.

At last he speaks. 'By your accent, stranger, I suppose you are a native of this region.'
'Not exactly. Or perhaps I am. At any rate, I came originally from Paris, but I was educated by a local family so that I think of these parts as my home. I am now going to claim the protection of some friends, whom I sincerely love, and of whose favour I have some hopes.'
'What are they called? I may know them.'

xoptx Tell him about yourself first.

xoptx Time to drop some hints about your friends.

'I do think you know them well. But let us change the subject. I am an unfortunate and deserted creature. I look around, and I have no relation or friend upon Earth. These people to whom I go have never seen me, and know little of me. My heart is full of agitation. If I fail with them, I am an outcast in the world forever.'
'To be friendless is indeed to be unfortunate. But the hearts of men, when unprejudiced by bigotry and political rhetoric, are full of brotherly love and charity. Rely, therefore, on your hopes. If the people you speak of are good and amiable, do not despair.'
'They are. But they think me a monster.'
'I can tell from your speech that you are not. So enlighten them.'

xoptx 'I only hope they'll listen.'

xoptx 'That will not be easy.'

'There is no question of it. They are a close family of gentle birth, who have shown great fortitude in dealing with the straitened circumstances forced on them by the current troubles.'
'I see.' He sits deep in thought for a moment. 'How is it you come to know this family?'
'Though they do not know it, I have been their neighbour for the last year. I live apart from my fellow man, being shunned by reason of my appearance, which is grotesque. Thus I must throw myself upon the family's mercy, because without their protection I am doomed to suffer the slow and agonizing demise of the exile.'
'Do not despair. To be friendless is indeed terrible, but the hearts of men are full of brotherly love and charity. If this family is good and amiable, your hopes will not be dashed.'
'They are the most excellent creatures in the world, but unfortunately they cannot help but be prejudiced against me. I have good dispositions. My life has been hitherto blameless, and in some degree beneficial, but a fatal bias clouds their eyes, and where they ought to see a feeling and kind friend, they behold only a detestable monster.'
'That is unfortunate. But if you are really blameless, cannot you undeceive them?'

xoptx 'I hope so.'

xoptx 'I fear it will be hard.'

You go on: 'I believe that honesty will prevail over prejudice, certainly. Pericles swayed the Athenian assembly, after all, and it was Thucydides who was banished in the end.'
'You are a man of learning,' he says, nodding.
How your heart soars to receive that compliment from the old man's lips.

xoptx Admit to everything.

xoptx No, tread softly. Don't alarm him.

'I have made every effort to improve myself in spite of difficult circumstances,' you reply, choosing your words carefully. 'I hope that my friends will see this and overlook other factors.'

xoptx Correct him.

xoptx Let him think so, it could help.

xoptx 'It's kind of you to say that we are kindred spirits.'

You can hear voices and laughter from outside. There is the clunk of muddy soles against the boot scraper by the door. The others are back. So soon!

xoptx Throw yourself on the old man's mercy.

xoptx It's all going wrong. You must flee.

You sit in silence.
You know those words so well that they have become like part of your innermost self. It is strange to hear them from another's lips.

He could be describing you as much as himself.

After a few moments, the old man continues, 'I have made up my mind to help you.'
How do you reply?

xoptx 'Thank you.'

xoptx 'Then I will tell you everything about myself.'

A strange way to phrase it. Does he realize? His sightless eyes peer through you.

xoptx It's time you told him everything.

'Excellent man!' you cry. 'I thank you, and accept your generous offer. You raise me from the dust by this kindness and I trust that, by your aid, I shall not be driven from the society and sympathy of your fellow-creatures.'

xoptx It's time to tell him.

xoptx If only he would guess, it would be easier.

You confess how you've been living in the shed adjoining the house, watching them from the walls. 'I learned everything from you and your family,' you say, your words coming in a rush now. 'Even how to speak and read.'
