Something buffets you hard across the shoulders. Felix has got a poker from the fire. He's clubbing at you again and again while you hear Agatha shouting, 'Kill it! Felix, kill it!'

xoptx Run off.

xoptx Hit back.

This is the moment of decision. Either you will be happy forever, or hope will end here. You struggle vainly to find words to answer him, but the mere effort saps all your remaining strength. You sink in the chair and sob aloud.
There are voices outside, the tap-tap as Felix empties his pipe against the wall. They're back already.

xoptx Quickly, throw yourself on the old man's mercy.

xoptx You've left it too late. Flee while you can.

You cannot bear to face them. Not here in this room, which you have come to think of as the placid heart of all that is good and wholesome. By intruding here, you suddenly see yourself as if through the eye pressed to the crack: a monster grotesquely dressed in human clothes, a ghastly interloper, an abnormal growth that has no place among the natural creatures of the world.
You have not a moment to lose. Seizing the hand of the old man, you cry, 'Now is the time! Save and protect me! You and your family are the friends whom I seek. Do not you desert me in the hour of trial!'
'Great God!' he exclaims. 'Who are you? Felix! My son!'
The door is thrown open. Felix rushes in. Behind him, Safiye screams and turns to run. Agatha sags against the door frame, weak with horror.
'Save me!' you implore the old man, but the face he tilts up to you is a mask of pain. In your panic you are crushing his hand.
Something buffets you across the shoulders. Felix has a poker from the fire. He clubs you again and again. 'Monster! Leave my father alone!'

xoptx Run off.

xoptx Hit back.

Thrusting the astonished Felix aside, you race across the lawn. Twigs and thorns tear at you as you push deeper and deeper into the woods. Soon the fine clothes you laboured so long over are torn and filthy with mud. Ruined, like your hopes.

You raise your hand. The poker falls from Felix's hand. You see the look of terror in his eyes. He knows that your blow, when it falls, will shatter his skull like an egg. But you cannot strike. Not in this room, which is like a shrine to everything you aspire to.
Night comes and, no longer restrained by the fear of discovery, you give vent to your anguish in fearful howling. You're like a wild beast that has broken from a trap, even at the cost of gnawing off its own leg, and now wanders unchecked in rage and pain. You sweep aside branches, destroying anything in your path, ranging through the wood like one of the ineluctable daemons of Eastern myth.
'Frankenstein! Cursed creator! Why assemble a wretch with all the desires and hopes of a man, and contain his soul in a vessel fashioned from nightmares? Why bestow the spark of existence so wantonly?'
What is it you feel at this moment?

xoptx Despair?

xoptx Anger?

Some of both, perhaps. You burn with shame at being such a thing, so hated that you must be hateful, so twisted that your soul must be a shrivelled pit. But at other times your will rises up to burn away that despair, as the sun burns away obscuring mist, and you can clearly see that you are hideous and shunned only because of the feeble cowardice and hypocrisy of men.
You are strong in body and spirit. Educated. Intelligent. You should rule as Alexander ruled, carried with his feet clear of the Earth, as gods must be. Avert your gaze because you are unworthy, miserable men! Call me hideous? Hideous then as the countenance of Yahweh is terrible and would blast the mind. A hideous beauty ..!
Both. It's both.

xoptx Will you return to the De Lacy house?

xoptx Or quit this area forever?

Your feelings are rage and revenge. As Frankenstein is not here, the De Lacys can be his proxy. You could with pleasure set fire to their house and its inhabitants, and glut yourself with their shrieks and misery as it burns.

xoptx So you intend to return to the De Lacy house?

xoptx Or will you quit this area forever?

There is nothing to keep you here.
You pass a miserable night. The cold stars shine in mockery and the bare trees sway their branches above you. Now and then the sweet voice of a bird bursts forth amid the stillness. All but you are at rest. You, like the arch-fiend, bear a hell within you. You ache to tear up the trees, spread havoc and destruction around you, and then sit down in the ruins.
Finally, spending your strength on an orgy of destruction in the heart of the wood, you sink to the damp grass. You are sick with despair. There is no one who will pity you. But is it too late? As you lie there, your mind offers the last and worst of the torments Pandora's curiosity inflicted on mankind: hope.
Is it hopeless to think you could yet salvage your situation with the De Lacys?

xoptx Of course it is.

xoptx Perhaps not.

Why should you feel kindness towards your enemies? The days of pleading for man's goodwill are behind you. From this moment you declare everlasting war against the species - and, above all others, you swear hatred against Frankenstein, who made you and sent you forth unprotected into this vale of insupportable misery.
The sun is rising. You slink back towards your lair but, hearing the voices of men on the other side of the hedgerows, you know that you won't be able to return unseen while it's light. Accordingly you hide yourself in some thick underwood, there to plot revenge.

Return to the house at dusk.

The sun is rising. You slink back towards your lair but, hearing the voices of men on the other side of the hedgerows, you know that you won't be able to return unseen while it's light. Accordingly you hide yourself in some thick brushwood to reflect on what to do next.
The pleasant sunshine, and the pure air of day, restores some degree of tranquillity. Now that you consider what happened, you see that you've been too hasty in your conclusions. You certainly acted imprudently. Your conversation with the old man had some success. You had his sympathy. Your mistake was allowing yourself to be seen too soon by Felix and the women. Instead you should have gained the trust of De Lacy senior, and only later present yourself to the rest of the family. But your errors are not irreparable. You can return to the cottage, find the old man, and still win him round.

Return to the house tonight.

You creep back into your hovel, which has remained undiscovered. Here you wait until the hour when the family normally get up. But the hour passes, the sun climbs higher in the sky, and you hear no sounds of activity from the house. Looking in through the crack in the wall, you see the empty room. The chair where you sat lies overturned on the floor. It appears deserted and, as you think that, your limbs begin to tremble violently. You hardly dare to breathe, as if by holding your breath you could avert this catastrophe.
After several hours you hear voices in the garden. Through a gap in the hedge you see Felix talking to another man. He's wearing the same clothes as yesterday, and from his dishevelled appearance it's clear that he hasn't been back to the house until now.

xoptx You may as well leave. There's nothing here for you now.

xoptx Eavesdrop on what they say.

You return to the house and let yourself in. Taking an armchair by the fire, you position facing the door through which the family will enter in the morning. You will be the first and last thing they see as you mete out the proper deserts for their unkindness.
But the hour passes, the sun climbs higher in the sky, and you hear no sounds of activity from upstairs. Suddenly you feel that the house is deserted and, as you think that, your limbs begin to tremble violently. You hardly dare to breathe, as if by holding your breath you could avert a catastrophe that seems to be rushing in on you.
After several hours you hear voices in the garden. Looking out, you see Felix talking to another man. He's wearing the same clothes as yesterday, and from his dishevelled appearance it's clear that he hasn't been back to the house until now. You are about to rush out and attack them both when you notice the pistols tucked into Felix's belt.

xoptx Leave. There's nothing here for you now.

xoptx Eavesdrop on what they say.

Felix intends to sell the house, that much is clear. In your clumsy attempt to ingratiate yourself, you succeeded only in tipping their determination towards quitting this place which, since the visit by the official in the red cap, has been growing more inevitable. Set on your futile dreams of being accepted, you didn't see it. Turning away, you slip into the woods without looking back once at the house you had grown to think of as your home.
'Well, I don't know, sir - I mean, citizen,' the other man is saying. 'No point me buying it if it's just going to be confiscated by the Committee, see what I mean?'
'Come on, Marchi,' says Felix, looking around nervously. 'I'm offering you a good price.'
'You're in a hurry to get away, Citizen De Lacy. Where are you going to go, anyhow?'
'Turkey,' says Felix, obviously biting back the last of his patience.
'That's a benighted land, citizen.'
'Yes, well... France has had too much light. She is dazzled.'
Agatha comes around the corner of the house. 'Felix, I can't find Childebrand.'
The cat. It has made itself a nest in your hovel to have a litter of kittens.
'We can't look for her now. I don't like leaving Safiye and Father alone. Marchi, please let me know by tomorrow. If you don't want it, Colbert is interested.'
They remain for a few minutes and then leave without even looking inside the house.
The De Lacys won't be coming back. In leaving they've broken the only link that held you to human society. As you sit brooding, thoughts of injury and death seethe up. But then you think of how you were accustomed to dote on the mild wisdom of the old man, the gentle eyes of Agatha who screamed 'Kill it! Kill it!', the dignified forbearance of Felix and the exquisite beauty of the girl he called his Arabian. Again you are confused. Is this rage you feel at being spurned, or grief at losing them?

xoptx It is hate, certainly.

xoptx It is sadness. You loved them.

When you think how the De Lacys have spurned and deserted you, anger wells up and, having nothing human to hand, you dash out the brains of Childebrand's kittens. But that is no more than a drop to satisfy a raging thirst, so you turn your fury towards the house that was for so long the focus of your hopes.
As night advances, you position firewood around the side of the house towards which the wind is blowing. After having destroyed every vestige of cultivation in the garden, you wait with furious impatience until the moon goes down to carry out your plan.

Burn it down.

A gush of tears somewhat soothes you. But minutes later, when you think how they have spurned and deserted you, anger returns and, having nothing human to hand, you turn your rage towards their dwelling which was for so long the focus of your hopes.
As night advances, you position firewood around the side of the house towards which the wind is blowing. After having destroyed every vestige of cultivation in the garden, you wait with furious impatience until the moon goes down to carry out your plan.

Burn it down.

The fault is yours. Around their lives you spun a fantasy of acceptance, in dreams planting yourself in their midst. But how can you blame them if, finding a ranting monster lurking by their house, they had raised a mob to chase you away? Why should they welcome you? They knew nothing about you.
Nature must be in sympathy with your black mood, because a wind steadily grows, ripping apart the clouds and sending dead leaves racing across the field of harsh white stars. The gale evokes a kind of insanity in your spirits that bursts all bounds of reason. You light the dry branch of a tree and dance with fury around the house, your eyes still fixed on the western horizon, the edge of which the moon is just touching.
You wave your brand, the moon sinks out of sight, and with a shout of either laughter or pain you set alight the pile of wood, straw and bushes which you have heaped against the wall of the house. The wind fans the fire into an inferno, and the house is quickly enveloped by the flames, which cling to it, licking into the window frames and turning the roof brick-red until it caves in with a groan of blazing timbers.
No one comes to look. Either they're sound asleep or they don't care to venture out in the night to face this demon who has come to terrorize the ungrateful human race. Turning your back on the blazing house, you stalk off into the woods.

And where now?

Who else should you seek out in this world, if not the one who made you? That is a homecoming with a rightness to it. From Frankenstein's notebook you know his family lives in Geneva, and Safiye's lessons with Felix told you that lies to the south-east. As to how far it is, you have no idea. Nor can you ask anyone for directions on the way. Jefferson's book and the stars are your only guides.The sun and stars are your only guides. But you have determination in your favour. Your creator is the only being on Earth from whom you can hope for succour, although towards him you feel no sentiment but hatred. You are determined to seek from him the justice that no other man will give you.

Even though you keep off the roads, it is still safer to travel only by night to avoid being seen. One morning, however, finding that your path lies through a deep wood, and cheered by the bright autumnal sun, you are tempted to continue your journey through the day.

xoptx Do so.

xoptx No, it's too risky.

You are hardly bothered by the cold, but even so it is pleasant to feel the fragile warmth of the low sun on your face. Listening to the birds tweeting in the trees, you feel greater serenity and even pleasure than you have experienced in weeks.
The woodland path brings you at last to a fast-flowing river. Here you stand awhile, relishing the unfettered energy of nature embodied in the crashing, foaming water. Just as you are deciding which direction to take to find a place to cross, you hear voices coming closer through the trees behind you.

xoptx Hide in the bushes.

xoptx Run off.

Despising yourself for the feeble yearning for company the voices evoke, you plunge angrily off into the undergrowth before they reach you.

From a thicket of ferns you see a young woman come running towards the river. She keeps looking over her shoulder and laughing excitedly, as if chased by somebody in sport. She veers off along the bank, but is too intent on looking around for her pursuer to see where she is treading. Her foot slips. She disappears from view. She didn't even cry out.

xoptx Try and save her.

xoptx Stay hidden.

You rush from your hiding place. You see her, white with shock, clinging to a tree root. Her skirts are ballooned out around her, which has saved her from going under but also makes it difficult for her to drag herself out. You reach down and pluck her from the current, easily lifting her to the bank, where she collapses in a dead faint.
As you bend over her, a young man comes running out of the trees. He stares at you with a wild expression, which changes to the slack look of fear when you start to explain how you've just saved her. Darting forward, he snatches up the girl and hurries back the way he came. In all this time he has said nothing.

xoptx Chase him.

xoptx Let him go.

You start after him, hardly knowing why. Perhaps only to demand the common courtesy of thanks. The only sound is the heavy sob of his breathing and the crunch of dead leaves. Encumbered as he is, you are easily catching up to him without even needing to break into a run.
'Stop.'
To your surprise he does. Putting the girl down, he swivels round, drawing something from his waistband. A gun. Stupidly, you start to raise your hand. There's a loud crack like a branch breaking. It seems as if somebody has shoved you hard in the chest, and you look down to see a small red blot on your white shirt, which suddenly blossoms into a spreading stain.

xoptx He shot you. Punish him.

xoptx Let him go.

You reach to seize him but you're slowed by the wound. Having no time to reload, he throws the gun at you and, sweeping up the girl, runs off through the woods.
For a moment you stand looking at each other across the clearing. The air has a faint tang of gun smoke.
'She has the rest of her life because of me,' you say.
Your words seem to break the spell. He throws the gun down, lifts the girl in his arms, and heads off between the trees.
So that is your reward. You saved another human being's life and were repaid only with the miserable pain of a wound, which has shattered flesh and bone. The feelings of kindness and gentleness which you entertained but a few moments before give way to hellish rage. Inflamed by agony, you vow eternal hatred and vengeance on all mankind.

xoptx Press on to Geneva.

xoptx Stay here while your wound heals.

The ball entered your shoulder, and presumably is still lodged there, but without a knife you have no way of extracting it. Even with your superhuman strength and constitution, the wound remains stiff and agonizingly painful for days. It prevents you from foraging, which adds to your misery, as does the sense of injustice. Each day you renew your vows of revenge - a deep and deadly revenge, such as would alone compensate for all the outrages and anguish you have endured.
At last the wound is healed, and you continue your journey. The labours you endure are no longer alleviated by the daylight or the beauties of the changing season. You restrict your travels to the dead of night so as to avoid any encounter. So, deeming you a monster, that's what they have made you. A creature of the night. And you, playing your part, will bring them nightmares.

Press on towards Geneva.

It's not worth the risk, even for the pleasure of a crisp, clear autumn day. You cover yourself in a bed of dank leaves and wait for sunset before venturing on.

Nature decays around you and the sun is drained of heat. Rain and snow gust out of grey skies. Lakes and rivers are frozen. The surface of the earth becomes hard and chill and bare. Across empty windswept fields you watch the warm lights of cottages with envy, and the few times you creep into a village by night you make sure to help yourself to food from the meanest homes, so that the deprivation will be more keenly felt. For why should babies be snug in cradles, and their parents sup heartily by a warm fire, while you are fated to haunt the drizzle and the lonely hedgerows?
At long last you begin to perceive that the blue hump on the horizon is not cloud, but the rise of land into the mountains around Geneva. Daily it comes closer. At the same time, the days are growing longer and warmer, the grass is greener. A new year is coming to life. The year in which you will confront your maker.
You have his notebook still. Would it be wise to look inside and see what you can learn before your meeting with him? And yet - the account of your creation, phrased in so glacially aloof a tone, reducing the marvel of your existence to so many millilitres of this, a certain number of grafts and sutures, like the recipe for an ammoniacal stew. It is hard to bear.

xoptx Read it again.

xoptx You don't need the book. You need its author.

Turning past the baldly factual details of your own assembly and animation, you give more attention to the personal notes and drawings. Here you may find a glimpse into the soul of your creator. Why did he make you? What event set this course to his studies and thus shaped both your destinies? A mummified hand, he says, found in the brickwork of a tavern. Speculating on what caused the hair and nails to grow, he claims that that was the moment when he first conceived a passion for investigating the creation of life. Was that it? An event so random and simple truly set in motion the wheel that was to grind out the long exquisite torture of your life?

xoptx Perhaps so.

xoptx Absurd.

No, it had to be more than that. Only in stories are people shaped by a single incident. Your own hatred ofdespair at mankind was not charged up in one unkind act, for all that the De Lacys' abandonment of you was the straw that broke the camel's back. Frankenstein may believe that he consciously came on the idea of his work at that moment, but something must have been at work within him long before, gnawing away every other distraction until a spark revealed the obsession that remained and his mind said, 'This is it.'
He writes here of a cousin Elizabeth - once he writes sister and crosses it out. And there is a fiancée, also called Elizabeth. Not the same person, presumably. And a girl called Justine, of whom he has made an accomplished sketch. A plump-faced girl whose heavy-lidded eyes, arched neck and slight curl of a smile suggests some intimacy. If not for the name, you'd say she is the fiancée. On the opposite side of the same page, he has drawn in charcoal the mirror image of the girl's face, but this time the underlying musculature with its anchoring of cartilage and bone.
You close the book. There are no answers to be found here. Or, if there are, you can only do so when you have the key that is your creator's personality.

Press on to Geneva.

It won't be easy to enter the town, as the gates are locked at night. You retire to the parkland adjoining the walls while you consider how to go about locating your maker. Resting in a thicket-covered hollow through the day, you awaken in late afternoon and sit looking out across a stretch of lightly-wooded heath land.
From beyond the trees comes the sound of children playing. A blaze of red as a kite sweeps up to catch the late sunlight, followed by joyful shouts. Is there any future in which you will know such unclouded happiness? Perhaps Frankenstein can repair his work. If your appearance were less abhorrent to others, they would recognize the goodness of your heart. At least, you must hold onto that hope.
From beyond the trees comes the sound of children playing. A blaze of red as a kite sweeps up into the sky to catch the late sunlight, followed by joyful shrieks that course like acid through your heart. It is not in your power to give laughter, only hatred and fear - and that you mean to mete out in generous measure.
There is a gentle breeze dispersing the humid warmth of the day, giving you hope of a storm tonight. That is all that now can bring a savage joy to sweep away your melancholy, for when you stand whipped by rain watching the stamp of white furnace light in the heavens, at that moment you feel the master of all creation rather than its humblest and most detested reject.
As you think these thoughts, a boy comes up the brow of the hill. He is running straight towards the nook where you lie concealed. Has he seen you? There is no one else around. It occurs to you that if you could abduct a child like this, too young to share the blind prejudices of his elders, you would be able to bring him up as your companion. You would no longer need to be alone.

xoptx Seize hold of him.

xoptx Watch where he goes.

Of course he screams when he sees you, and covers his eyes. You pull his hand forcibly from his eyes.

'Monster! What are you?'
He screams again - a shrill noise that sets your nerves on edge. There doesn't seem to be anyone else around, but you cannot be sure of that.

xoptx Better let him go.

xoptx Make him listen.

Make him listen.

A young woman comes running up to the child. To your amazement, it is the same girl as in Frankenstein's sketch. He turns from her sullenly. She, eyes bright and angry, tries to wrest something from out of his pocket. He digs his little nails into her wrist.
'Ow! Spiteful little beast.'
'Give that back! It's not yours.'
She tugs it away from him and slips it down between her breasts. 'Don't you tell anyone I took it, William. If you do, I'll - '
'You won't do anything,' he snorts. 'A serving girl is all you are. I'll tell my father and he'll have you whipped.'
A strange cast comes over her face. An absence of expression, combined with an intense watchfulness. You recognize it as a look of impending violence, but the child is naïve. He thinks he's cowed her, and presses the point: 'He'll put his whip to your fat arse, Justine, and then he'll send you pack - '
He stops because she has her hands around his throat. 'Don't speak to me of your father!' she screams. 'You Frankensteins are all alike, thinking you own everything and everyone.'
You watch until his legs stop kicking. She lets go and his little body flops to the grass, just bones in a bag of skin. The girl looks around in panic and, seeing no one, runs off.
Frankenstein, she said. So that's interesting …

He races out of the thicket where you had dragged him and blunders straight into the arms of a young woman. To your amazement, if is the same girl as in Frankenstein's sketch. The child is trying to tell her about you, and you tense your muscles ready to run, but she's not listening.
'Give it to me, William.'
'What, no. Listen - back there, a monster!'
His hysterical babbling stops when she slaps him. An instant later they are tussling over a small trinket she has pulled from his pocket. The child sinks his teeth into her wrist so she hits him again, much harder this time, knocking him down. When he feebly kicks at her shins, she bends over him and circles his throat with her strong plump fingers.
'Stop! You daren't! Father will - '
She applies pressure - a great deal of pressure, as you can see from the tendons in her neck. 'Your father! He only cares about his spawn if they bear the precious Frankenstein name.'
She is only talking to herself now. The child will not move again. Finally realizing this, she falls back with a look of panic. But then her expression becomes furtive. She snatches the trinket from his hand, looks around, and hurries off down the hill.
Frankenstein, eh? Now there's a stroke of fate.

'Ogre! Don't you eat me, my father will have you hunted down if you do.'
'I'm not going to eat you, boy. But you will never see your father again. You must come with me.'
'No! Never!'
He's biting and kicking. You take a grip on his throat, thinking it will subdue him, but children lack the experience to react logically to fear. Instead he screams - that terrible shrill noise again. You let your grip tighten.
A woman's voice calls out from a few yards away. You're startled that she could come so close without you hearing. She is just on the other side of the thicket that covers your hiding place. The boy draws in a breath. Before he can shout, you clamp your hand across his mouth.
'William!' she is saying. 'William Frankenstein!'
Frankenstein ..? You see in the boy's eyes that it's so. He must be the son of your creator. Or his younger brother, perhaps. What extraordinary fate, that he should fall into your hands.
Looking through the thicket, you see the woman's skirts sweeping across the grass, already lank with the evening dew, as she paces anxiously. The boy squirms and tries to bite. You press him further back into the hollow.
She calls for him again, her voice further away now. He stops struggling and you feel his bony little body relax. Peering out, you see the woman as a dwindling speck among the trees. She is still calling, but too far off now for you to hear words, only the note of rising hysteria.
'Don't cry out,' you warn the boy, lifting your hand from his mouth. And then you see that he will never do so again.
'No... My father will punish you. He's Monsieur Frankenstein...'
'Frankenstein!'
The eyes have that look you know so well, full of terror and weakness that must be crushed and swept away. The stifled voice, the sob that fears pain but only invites it. As your fingers close tighter, you hear a faint whimper. From your throat, or the boy's? It doesn't matter. There will never be another.
'Ah... My father will punish you. He's a very important man.'
Anger. It's boiling inside you. You can't stop it. And then, gurgling as he feels his throat squeezed, the boy splutters out the words that drive away all hope of calm and reason:
'He is Monsieur Frankenstein!'
'That's a name I know.'
A breeze stirs the grass and lifts a few specks of thistledown into the long red light of the declining sun.

A young man comes from the woods, his puzzled smile gradually fading as he looks around and sees no sign of the girl. You creep on all fours through the bushes until you can see her holding desperately to a tree root while the water froths all around her. She manages to gulp in a breath and gives a faint cry. The man runs to the bank, tearing off his jacket, in time to see the current break her grip and sweep her away. He quivers on the edge of jumping in - a posture that is both tragic and comical - and then runs uselessly along the bank calling her name. A pity you will never know the end of their little drama, but you must be on your way.

You are tempted to follow and remonstrate with him about his ingratitude. But you feel so incensed that it could so easily turn to violence, even murder, and you don't want a search party out tracking you with dogs. Uttering a loud curse that must roll after him through the trees with all the awesome weight of God's last word to Adam, you turn away.

you wild winds, thus can you sleep so still
Whilst throbs the tempest of my breast so high?

And, in the eternal mansions of the sky,
Can the directors of the storm in powerless silence lie?

CHAPTER ONE
Even Cato Wept

Snowflakes are drifting past the window. For a time they become confused in my mind with the peeling paint on the shutters. A curl of white trembles in the breeze, vibrating with an awful anxiety, fragile yet never quite breaking free. That flake of paint is both familiar to me and very dreadful. I am conscious as I continue to watch it that I have been a stranger to the world for weeks. Perhaps months.
Hearing a commotion in the street, shouts and a burst of raucous song, I ask Henri if it is New Year.
'The year starts when the government says,' he replies without turning from the window. The reply is almost a reflex, as though speaking to himself, and from his tone I gather he has grown used to me sliding away into a state of extreme detachment.
I sit upright in the chair. 'How long have I been ill, Henri?'
It takes him a moment to respond. He slowly looks round at me, and the lines of weariness melt away as his face lights up. 'Victor!'

xoptx Ask him where you are.

xoptx Ask about the monster.

xoptx 'Thank you, Henri.'

xoptx 'You aren't listening to me!'

Henri stops me before I can say more. He looks weary, and I detect the impatience that he tries so hard to bite back.

You have had a brain fever and your mind has woven nightmares out of the work that caused your breakdown. xoptx Perhaps so.

xoptx You know it wasn't.

You know it wasn't.

'Dearest Henri, how good you are to me. You came to Paris with a heart full of excitement, eager to begin your studies at the university, and yet this whole winter has been spent in my sick room. 'Combative! I like that. In my present state, I could not go three rounds with a field mouse.'
'That's only the effect of long confinement. Exercise and fresh air will restore you. And, since you appear to be in good spirits, perhaps you will be glad to see this letter that arrived the other day.'

xoptx 'You have another letter there.'

The faint pale scars of acid on my hands are an indelible reminder of both my foul act of creation and vain attempt to expunge it. The form of the monster I brought to life has been before my eyes constantly in the long weeks of my illness, a nightmarish image indeed with his glassy yellow eyes and raw sinewy features. I know that I spoke to him, my throat is hoarse with shouting, and as Henri sat beside my bed in the night he must have heard all my ravings. He ascribes them to the delirium of my illness.

xoptx Could he really believe that?

xoptx It's fortunate that he does.

You're right. Henri is perceptive - much more so than most men. He must suspect there is some kernel of truth in my fears - that my disorder indeed owes its origin to some uncommon and terrible event. But he could never guess how I have violated the recesses of nature and called forth a thing that should not exist on this Earth. Let him keep whatever suspicions he may have, therefore. They are less awful than the truth.

xoptx But what about the creature?

xoptx Best not to dwell on such things now.

Do you think I don't know that? I am damned to bear these memories, my soul and mind marked as clearly as the burns on my hands, but Henri need never share the burden of such ghastly knowledge. He's done enough for me as it is. So I shall not allude to it again. He can think me mad, never guessing that my retreat into madness these last months has been the reaction of a sane mind, blasted by horror and seeking oblivion to heal itself.

xoptx But what about the creature?

xoptx Best not to dwell on such things now.

By slow degrees my recovery continues over the following weeks. True, there are relapses, usually on dull days when the view from the window is grey and rain spits against the panes. Then I sit for hours staring at my boots beside the door or the pattern on the china, feeling that slow horror of familiar things that creeps over us when the mind is at its weakest.
But as the spring approaches, my spirit brightens with the lengthening of the days. Brilliant blue breaks through the clouds, and even rain is a cleansing spray that scours the rooftops and makes them glisten in the sun. The fallen leaves that clogged the gutter in winter have blown away, and young buds are shooting forth on the tree outside my window.
'I'm glad you found these rooms,' I tell Henri, who with typical perceptiveness had me moved from the old lodgings in the Latin Quarter to speed my recovery.
'It promises to be a divine spring,' he says. 'Now you will speedily convalesce and we'll enjoy ourselves like old times.'

Perhaps the worst is behind you.

Perhaps it didn't live. Where would it find shelter? Who would give it food? When I think of it - a macabre thing, an abomination. Surely it would be best if itPerhaps he didn't live. Where would he find shelter? Who would give him food? When I think of him - a macabre thing, an abomination. Surely it would be best if he simply found a place to crawl away and die.

'Never!' I say, and mean it.
In the days that follow I make an effort to push the monster from my thoughts. The spring is here, and the longer days contribute greatly to my convalescence. Joy and affection reawaken in my bosom; my gloom lifts each time the sun breaks through the clouds to reveal the newly minted blue of a spring day. In a short time I am as cheerful as I used to be before I became gripped by the fatal obsession.

You can thank Henri for that.

'My friend,' says Henri gravely, 'I am glad that your mind is lucid at last. I have longed to have you recognize me and recover your wits and strength. Henri proves to be an attentive but cheerfully stern infirmarian, applying the doctor's advice as though it were holy writ. 'Surely not in Paris,' I say, and we both laugh. But I see the way everyone on the street either stares about them belligerently or looks down with sullen eyes. A year ago they were filled with anxiety, eyes bright with feverish excitement at what would come. Now, having seen the future, they face it with the hush of fear.

Even so, it must feel good to be out at last.

It's marvellous to sit at a bar again, and to feel that comforting sense of being immersed in a crowd of people all intent on their own merriment, but it only takes a couple of pints to send my head spinning. 'You'll soon get used to it,' says Henri, insisting on a third round.
After that, the effort of conversation is beyond me. I sit back and listen to Henri talk - and not just him, but the hubbub of convivial chatter all around us.
I don't remember getting home. As Henri helps me pull off my boots and collapse into bed, he says, 'This was your last day as an invalid. No more nursemaiding from tomorrow!'

Not before time, eh?

Each day we walk a little further. Henri says that if he didn't pick the route then he'd never see anything of Paris, as I would always head straight for the university.
In fact the opposite is true. Any thought of my former studies revolts me and sends my mind whirling back into turmoil. So it is with a start that, during a long afternoon stroll along Rue Dominique, I see Professor Krempe emerging from a little shop on the Rue du Bac. I turn away before he sees me.
Henri misses little. 'Are you all right, Victor? You have gone quite white in the face.'
'One of my professors. I'm surprised nobody has thought to guillotine him.'
'Oh, I'm sure he can't be as bad as all that.' He raises his hand to accost Krempe.

xoptx Talk to Krempe.

xoptx Tell Henri not to call him over.

Krempe is an uncouth, squat little man with a gruff voice and a repulsively whiskered countenance. I'm concentrating on his good points, you understand. Seeing me, he mimes a degree of astonishment that would be booed in the commedia dell'arte, complete with a slap to the forehead and eyes as wide as tennis balls.
'Herr Frankenstein,' he says, pumping my hand. 'So you have recovered your wits at last.'
Henri laughs nervously at this, perhaps mentally excusing Krempe's forthright manner as typically German. I am sure if Krempe tried to return home to Germany he would be shot at the border.

xoptx Ask what brings him to this part of town.

xoptx Try to get away as quickly as possible.

'I don't think we should speak to him in the street.' I pull Henri's arm down before Krempe sees us.
'Why ever not?'
'He is German. We are Swiss. Foreign nationals consorting in public... Well, you see how it might look if reported. And that fellow on the corner is surely a monitor for the district. See the way he's pretending not to notice us?'
With his sensitive nature and unfamiliarity with the country, Henri is more deeply attuned to the tightening regime than I. It's easy to make him see spies and secret police everywhere.
'I suppose you are right, Victor.'
Krempe waddles off down the street. His is a rebarbative presence that my nerves could well do without at the best of times, but the truth is that I don't want to have anything to do with my old studies, or anything that would remind me of them. If Krempe had the charm of Dionysus, still I would cross the street to avoid him.

Perhaps your old interests will reawaken.

Time passes and I assure you they do not.

From his pocket, Krempe pulls out an ornate watch with so much gold and enamel that it looks like a young wedding cake.
'I was getting this fixed. A fine piece of Swiss engineering, but I over-wound it.'
He looks at me with a dull little glimmer in his eye, the spark of what passes for humour in his crocodilian brain. I see the spark brightening lugubriously towards a witticism, but I get there first:
'And you could say the same of me. Yes, yes, Professor.'
'Victor has always been cuckoo,' says Henri with a laugh.

xoptx Make an excuse and leave.

xoptx You're trapped now. May as well talk to him.

My impatience to get away is obvious enough that even Krempe perceives it. Seeing me look off in the direction of the university, he asks am I taking Henri to Professor Lavoisier's lecture?
I know Krempe dislikes Lavoisier and is dismissive of his work, so it's a fair bet he wouldn't accompany us there.

xoptx 'Yes, and we're running a bit late.'

xoptx 'No.'

In fact I have not thought of lectures for nearly a year, and was simply hoping he would scurry off.
'You're not, in fact,' he says, showing a flash of nicotine-stained teeth behind the white hedge of his beard. 'The lectures have been cancelled since Professor Lavoisier's arrest.'

xoptx 'On what charge?'

xoptx What will happen to him?'

'Other than his involvement in tax collecting, you mean? Well, he supported Dr Lagrange when the courts wanted to imprison him as a hostile foreigner. That made him a few enemies. His wife has been arrested too, so I can only hope that somebody is looking after their collection of scientific apparatus. Given Lavoisier's fortune, it is enough to stock a medium-sized museum, as you can imagine.'

'There's only the one punishment these days.' Krempe is never one to leave any statement to the imagination, so he underlines this by striking his hand down into his palm. 'Whoosh-chop. Ah well...'
He starts to walk away, then thinks of something else and runs after us. 'My own savings have been confiscated, of course, but you Swiss are neutral. You could buy some of Lavoisier's chemical apparatus. He will have no further use for it, and the state can have no idea of its true market value.'
I wince at hearing this. Even Krempe is not so imperceptive that he fails to notice. 'Buck up, Frankenstein. A scientist cannot afford such dainty qualms.'
Henri tips his hat to Krempe and takes my arm to lead me away. 'What a vulgar fellow,' he says out of the corner of his mouth.
'Now you see why I wanted to avoid him! A pity we didn't run into Professor Waldman, who is far more agreeable.'

xoptx Agree.

xoptx Refuse.

'These are uncomfortable times.' Krempe looks unwilling to continue this line of conversation, and to my surprise we're able to extricate ourselves quite easily.
'Not fond of your professors, then?' says Henri as we watch Krempe cross the street.
'Some more than others. I wonder why he hurried off. Usually he'd bore us for hours just on principle.'
'There's no mystery,' says Henri. 'The authorities view hostile nationals with suspicion. As a German, he falls into that category.'
'Krempe? He's lived in Paris longer than anybody.'
'And how long have you lived here, Victor? Or I? If Krempe is careful, we should be ten times so.'

Henri stops, fixes me with a grave look. 'Victor, while you've been locked inside your own head everything has changed. How often do I need to tell you that?

xoptx 'What? We're hostile aliens now?'

xoptx You should meet one of my less disagreeable tutors.'

Henri checks in both directions to see that we can't be overheard. 'There's been talk of a French invasion of Switzerland.'
'Just talk, Henri. Tavern gossip, that's all that is.'
He nods, unconvinced. 'Hmm. What would you do with a standing army of more than a million men? When they have subdued all the rebellious provinces, do you suppose the Committee will leave them idle? Once you uncork a genie's bottle, God alone can help you.'
Probably Henri imagines a black-visaged genie out of the Arabian Nights. The face that appears in my mind's eye, though, is a leering spectre with transparent skin that exposes the bloody flesh and sinew to view. I can only hope ithe is long gone, as distant a dream now as the tales of Scheherazade.

xoptx Perhaps it is.

xoptx Perhaps he is.

xoptx You should think of returning home soon.

'Damn this fellow!' cries Krempe suddenly, giving me a painful buffet on the arm. 'Why, Herr Clerval, I assure you he has outstripped us all. Oh yes, stare if you please, but it is nevertheless true. This young chap, who came to us with his head full of thoughts of medieval alchemy, in just a few years has now set himself at the head of the faculties of physiology and chemistry. If he is not soon pulled down, we shall all be out of a job. Oh yes,' he presses on, noting the grimace I give him, 'Herr Frankenstein is modest - an excellent quality in a young man. Young men should be modest, you know, Herr Clerval; I was myself when young. But that wears out in a very short time.'
Modesty has never troubled me nor, I think, Professor Krempe. My discomfort is not that, but a wave of abhorrence, almost a physical nausea, at the thought of my old field of study. We are forced to listen to Krempe's eulogy on himself as a young man, but at least that happily turns the conversation from the subject that is so vexing to me. Eventually we extricate ourselves.
'Not fond of your tutors, then?' says Henri as we watch Krempe cross the street.
'Professor Krempe is not an easy soul to like, as I'm sure you'll now concede. Professor Waldman is all right, though.'
'Well, introduce me to him. Come on, Victor, I have yet to meet any of your university associates.'

xoptx Say yes.

xoptx Tell him no.

I arrange for us to have dinner with Professor Waldman. Our encounter is strange. My feelings for him have always been a mixture of affection and reverence. He is like a favourite uncle whom you see rarely but with whom you feel immediate affinity. He is stately, with a benevolent countenance and a voice like an opera singer, rich and full of warmth. And to hear that voice praising my scientific accomplishments to Henri, as he begins to do almost as soon as our coats are hung up, should bring me nothing but joy.
Instead, actual nausea greets every chemical formula or discovery that Waldman cites in my favour. I feel as low as any criminal whose sins are being read out to the court. A deep flush heats my face, which Waldman, like Krempe, attributes to modesty rather than shame and disgust.

xoptx Confide in him.

xoptx Grit your teeth and bear it.

I find it hard to put into words, especially with Henri present. After only a few stuttered words, I lapse into silence. They are both looking at me. Professor Waldman carefully sets down his knife and fork, just as I have often seen him lay aside his scalpel in the surgical theatre before imparting some piece of simple but profound wisdom.
'When you make a mistake in your work, Monsieur Frankenstein, what do you do?'
I shrug. 'If I noticed the mistake, naturally I would try to correct it.'
'Most certainly. So, now then: my question has you thinking of an intellectual mistake. A misplaced factor in an equation, perhaps. But why not a moral error?'
'There is a difference. A moral error betrays a person's true character.'
'Oh?' His iron-grey eyebrows shoot up in amusement. 'And does that missing minus in the equation reveal a fundamental flaw in your intellect?'
'Not if I spot it and correct it.'
'There!' Waldman again takes up his cutlery, feeling his syllogism proven.

xoptx Press him on this point.

xoptx He doesn't understand.

As we walk home, Henri is full of admiration for Professor Waldman. And full of good wine, too, as he is in one of his merry moods wherein he speaks the most delightful nonsense.
For example: 'Do you like oysters?' he says. 'I used to love them.'
'I remember.'
'Smoked oysters and steak - I would drag you miles out of your way to find a tavern where that was served. But you know, our tastes change as we get older. Now the very thought of oysters revolts me.'
'Perhaps you had a bad one.'
'Or just too many. A surfeit of something adored can turn it into something repellent.'
No, I am the one who had too much wine, because it strikes me only now that he isn't really talking about oysters. He must have noticed that I cannot stand any discussion of chemistry. Dear Henri! If only he understood. It's not overwork that has turned my heart and made me view the apparatus of my former science with horror. It's the monstrous face that I see reflected in every beaker and test tube.

Time may heal that.

I am lost for the right words, but Henri comes to my rescue. 'I'm not sure that I follow, Professor.'
'You, Monsieur Clerval, are not a scientist, so for you I will put it another way. In my faith, there is no absolution, as in a washing away of sin, but equally a sin is often seen as a mistake rather than a moral blot, so to speak, upon the soul. One can atone for sins by repentance and by making restitution to the one harmed by your action.'
Henri spreads his hands. 'I am not, to my shame, well-versed in the tenets of Judaism.'
'It is not so very difficult. There are three foundations of moral behaviour: law, faith and society. The last is a poor translation. I should say, loving kindness to others. Companionship, the gift of friendship to one's fellow man - this is the wellspring of ethical behaviour.'
'I am sure I will not fall prey to sin,' says Henri with a twinkle, 'as long as I have Victor's friendship to keep me to the strait gate and the narrow road.'
'Matthew verse seven.' Waldman nods. 'You see, Monsieur Clerval, I take care to know a little of all faiths.'

Food for thought, certainly.

'You would find our discussion of scientific matters unutterably tedious, Henri.'
'That can't be all he'd talk about.'
'You don't know these university professors. They are like monks in their single-minded devotion. Let's just enjoy ourselves and not think about work at all. I am getting to prefer poetry to science anyway.'
Henri lays his hand on my brow. 'Are you quite sure you're getting better?' he says with a grin.
'And I prefer the idea of Geneva to Paris,' I add. 'I think it's time I visited my family.'

Soon, when you're fully recovered.

It's almost another spring now, full eighteen months since I became ill. I had intended to return to Geneva in the autumn, as I am quite fit enough now for the journey, but there was some difficulty obtaining permits to travel, and by the time they came through the roads had been made impassable by early snow.
The delay struck me very bitterly. I began at last to realize how long I had been absent from my loved ones. Perhaps it was homesickness, perhaps because the shorter days and the howling November wind reminded me of the events of that terrible night, but I suffered a relapse and for several weeks after the official celebration of the new year - Year Two of the Revolution, as we had better remember to call it - I could not get out of bed.
After that, surprisingly, my spirits revived and Henri and I spent the winter cheerfully. There was no carol service to celebrate Christmas, of course. A new law has been passed, outlawing priests who refuse to swear the oath of allegiance to the Revolution.

xoptx Where do you think your creature is now?

xoptx What oath is that?

If it lives, it must have found some haven very remote from mankind, for it is impossible to imagine anyone enduring its company. It must have survived, I think, because my process imparted a superhuman level of endurance and vigour. It would be hard to kill, and might take a century to reach old age. I suppose I could be said to have cursed it with good health.

If he lives, he must have found some haven very remote from mankind, for it is impossible to imagine anyone enduring his company. He must have survived, I think, because my process imparted a superhuman level of endurance and vigour. He would be hard to kill, and might take a century to reach old age.

xoptx Unfortunate creature!

xoptx So when are you going home?

So when are you going home?

Priests who refuse to take it can be executed on sight. At the same time, how can any priest in conscience swear to serve the Revolution, when among its stated aims is the abolition of Christianity? And not in the name of Reason, either, which is a power before which men can honourably submit, but in the name of Robespierre's undercooked stew of religiosity. The Cult of the Supreme Being, as he calls it.
This official violence by the state strikes me as so appalling that I cannot wait for the day when I can finally leave France behind me forever. And yet it's strange... a year ago, mobs dragged imprisoned priests, nuns and aristocrats from their cells and massacred them in their thousands. At the time I hardly took note of it.

xoptx You were busy with your project.

xoptx You weren't the only one.

I am doubly accursed, then. First because I undertook to achieve a goal which can be called holy, if anything is holy, yet only from arrogance and ambition, without a moment's reflection in my heart for what responsibility it is to create a human life. And now you remind me that, in my obsession, I spared no thought for the abominable crimes being committed daily all around. My sin is compounded.

xoptx There was nothing you could have done.

xoptx Do you spare a thought for your creature now?

Oh, it was worse than that. I supported the Revolution. Insofar as I gave thought to the massacres and executions at all, a year ago I would have justified them to you as the adolescent tantrums of a society growing from infancy to adulthood. The old law was unjust, the old rulers were unjust, and thus they brought the violence upon their own heads. So I told myself, forgetting the oath that I swore when I began my study of physiology: in curing a sickness, first ensure your treatments do no harm.
In overturning the old injustices, the revolutionaries have created a monstrous form of government in which every citizen is under perpetual threat of imprisonment, torture or execution in order to protect a suppositional 'common man' who is in fact more mythical than any deity.

xoptx What does Henri say about all this?

xoptx The main thing is you'll soon be going home.

I'm expecting a letter from my father, setting a date for my homecoming. Perceiving my impatience, especially now that the spring is here, Henri makes a suggestion.
'Remember how we used to enjoy long walks in the countryside back home?' he says one morning over coffee. 'Why don't we take a week or two away from the city? See, I have marked on this map several towns and villages we could include on a walking tour. How long have you been at university here, Victor? And yet I'm willing to bet you've never gone to look at Fontainebleau or Versailles. And the Château de Vaux-le-Vicomte is said to be magnificent. We may find the gates have been flung open, thanks to your Revolution.'
'My Revolution!' I scowl at his jest. But it's a good plan. 'Let's do it, Henri.'

xoptx It will do you a power of good.

xoptx Let me know when you get back to the city.

It cannot be soon enough!
Unfortunate? How can you say that of such a foul thing? It is a crime against nature that it exists at all, and for that reason I can only pray that my calculations are wrong, and that some disease has already terminated the thing's miserable life. Oh, that I had had the courage to take a scalpel and -
But I must not allow the monster back into my thoughts like this. I will fall ill once more, and I could not bear to again postpone my journey home. When Paris is behind me, I can blot out these dreadful days. I'll marry and get on with a new and blameless life.

When are you due to set off?

Of course these are terrible times,' he agrees. 'But everything that is being done to the old ruling class is a direct result of the brutality or - worse, perhaps - the indifference with which they had grown accustomed to treat the ordinary people.'

xoptx Ridiculous. What does he know?

xoptx A good point.

Henri arrived here little over a year ago, it's true. What he knows of life in France before the Revolution came only from books and newspapers. But in spite of that I think he's right. I, who have lived here for more than five years now, had too high hopes for what would be achieved, and now feel betrayed by the tyranny of self-serving bureaucrats like Robespierre and Danton. Henri is able to see that, though we live in dreadful times, we are not without blame. All that is needed for the triumph of evil, says the English philosopher Edmund Burke, is for good men to do nothing.
I don't know if I'm a good man. I hope I am. For most of my life, though, I have found it very easy to do nothing - in a moral sense.

xoptx You mean the creature.

xoptx Forget all that. When do you leave?

Bereft of companionship, how is it possible for a man to be virtuous - especially if he has never had the opportunity to learn good from wickedness? I don't know what he will do, the poor wretch.
Do not mistake me. None of us may honestly trace a chain of culpability to others to account for the sins we commit with our own hand. Therefore whatever my creature does must be on his own conscience. Yet it will be upon mine also. I created him and, though his only sin was to be hideous and unloved, I cast him out. God help us both.

Forget that. You'll soon be going home.

'How can you excuse it, Henri? Any of it? Nuns raped and drowned, men torn apart by mobs, and now anybody might be taken from their beds in the dark of the night. Some disappear, others are whisked off to the guillotine with such indecent haste that their families may not even know of their arrest. The constitution is suspended. Trials proceed without laws. And you make excuses for it all?'
He looks as I imagine Judas must have, taking on all the weight of the world's sadness. 'I don't condone it, Victor. I understand it, which is not the same thing. We must always understand, or else we make monsters of our fellow man.'

You must be eager to escape from this madness!

We pass a fortnight in a walking tour of the villages south of Paris. My health and spirits have long been restored, and they gain additional strength from the clean country air, the new sights we encounter each day, the good exercise, and the conversation of my friend.
After long years of solitary study, secluded from my fellow man, I have fallen into an unsocial frame of mind. Henri soon sees to that. He strikes up conversations with milkmaids, shepherds, pedlars, innkeepers and anyone else we come across - and ensures that I too am drawn in. He teaches me again to rejoice in nature, to love the cheerful faces of children who follow us to the door of each inn and are happy to take a denier or just a sweet for the privilege of hauling our knapsacks between two or three of them.

xoptx He sounds a good man.

xoptx And when you return to Paris?

The best. He is an excellent friend. I owe him my health, my sanity, and probably my life, and few of us have the pleasure to be able to say that of another.
My selfish pursuit of earlier years had cramped and narrowed me. I was not aware how much, until his gentleness and affection warmed and opened my senses. I am becoming the same happy creature who set out from home years ago with no sorrow or care, loved by so many good friends. In those days, nature had the power of bestowing on me the most delightful sensations. A serene sky and verdant fields filled me with ecstasy. I thought it was everyone's lot to lose that as they grow older. Now I see I had simply blinkered myself with too narrow and all-consuming a field of study.
Smell it! That freshness of a stream running across bright smooth rocks. May is here and the season is, as spring should always be, like the remaking of the world. Flowers bloom in the hedges, buds are on the trees. At last I feel I am free of the disturbing thoughts that, all during this past year, have lurked in the corners of my imagination despite every effort to throw them off.

xoptx Is Henri enjoying himself?

xoptx You will return to the city refreshed.

If you knew Henri, you would realize that he never enjoys himself as much as when giving pleasure to others. And his energy is boundless! After a day's walking in the fresh air, a few pints of beer and a fine rustic meal are enough to send me off to bed very content. I often leave Henri in the common room deep in conversation with some farmhand or fellow traveller, and from the rings under his eyes and his luxurious yawns the next day, I think he often sits up half the night.
At other times, when we cannot find an inn, we camp out under the stars. The nights are crisp but not too cold to bear, and after a simple repast at the fireside, I stretch out under a blanket and listen as Henri weaves tales of wonderful fancy and passion in imitation of the fashionable Oriental writers, or recites my favourite poems.
When we were children, I looked down a little on Henri. I loved him, but I thought his intellect too vague and unfocused. That was my arrogance. His art is the equal of my science, for both exalt the divine imagination of mankind.

All too soon you will be back in Paris.

We return to the city on a Sunday afternoon. There is dancing in the street, and everyone seems to be clutching a bottle of wine or a jug of beer. My own spirits are as high as they have been in nearly two years. Without even knowing the cause, I bound along the street with feelings of unbridled joy and hilarity.
'What is it?' cries Henri, grabbing a man who comes reeling towards us in a drunken dance.
'The tyrant! He is no more!' splutters the man, before turning back to his dancing companion. She is no beauty, but today it seems that there is nothing ugly anywhere.
'Robespierre?' I turn to Henri. 'I thought his power was absolute.'
'Like the King's before him?'
Nobody bothers to check our papers. We learn that the Committee of Public Safety has been stripped of its dictatorial powers, the constitution restored. The next day, Robespierre rides the tumbril to Madame Guillotine. He's beheaded still wearing his powdered wig. There is widespread rejoicing at his execution but I don't go to watch, mindful of what Professor Waldman said. A man may not be evil, merely unable to see a way to correct his mistakes.
A letter arrives for me the next day. It's from my father. Thinking it to be final arrangements for the date of my homecoming, I rip it open - only to pause with a gnawing of dread. The paper is black-edged.

Read it at once.

'My dear Victor,' writes my father. 'You have probably waited impatiently for a letter to fix the date of your return to us, and I was at first tempted to write only a few lines, merely mentioning the day on which I should expect you. But that would be a cruel kindness, and I dare not do it. What would be your surprise, my son, when you expected a happy and glad welcome, to behold, on the contrary, tears and wretchedness? And how, Victor, can I relate our misfortune? Absence cannot have rendered you callous to our joys and griefs, and how shall I inflict pain on my long absent son? I wish to prepare you for the woeful news, but I know it is impossible; even now your eye skims over the page to seek the words which are to convey to you the horrible tidings. William is dead. That sweet child, whose smiles delighted and warmed my heart, who was so gentle, yet so gay. Victor, he is murdered!'
The letter almost falls from my fingers. Henri, seeing this, rushes to my side. I hand it to him. He reads it with a white face.

xoptx Talk to Henri; he shares your grief.

xoptx Who is William?

He's my brother. Much younger than I - just a child.

xoptx Henri must be as horrified as you are.

He lowers the letter without a sound but, when he turns to the window, I see the tears running down his cheeks. I cry with him.

Of course you must.

Henri wants me to talk out my grief, but I prefer to cherish it as a bitter black pill. 'As an only child, I can never know such sorrow as you now feel,' he replies with infuriating sympathy. 'There is but one consolation, and that is that he is at rest. He does not now feel the murderer's grasp. Earth covers his gentle form and he knows no pain. He can no longer be a subject for pity. His family and friends are the greatest sufferers.'
'What of those maxims of the Stoics?' I say. 'That death is no evil, and that the mind of Man ought to be superior to despair.'
Henri shakes his head. 'Even Cato wept over the body of his brother.'

Make haste now.

I explain what is my greatest fear, that it was my own deed that doomed my little brother. I don't know if Henri understands. He only says, 'It's natural for you to think that. Weren't thoseThose were Elizabeth's own words when she set eyes on William's body?.'
He has learned not to hear when I talk about the monster. Perhaps I could speak now with the eloquence and clarity of bereavement, and finally make him believe, but it is not to be. The ponies are hitched to the cart. The coachman hands me a whip.

It's time to go.

'Of course, I have no brothers or sisters,' says Henri, 'so I can only hazard a guess at the depths of your emotion. There is but one consolation, and that is that he is at rest. He does not now feel the murderer's grasp. Earth covers his gentle form and he knows no pain. It isn't William whom I pity. You, his family and friends, are the greatest sufferers.'
I hear him, but whatever turmoil is inside my heart can find no expression in words. I order a two-wheeled cabriole. The ponies are soon hitched. I take the whip and climb up.

God speed you homewards.

Bidding Henri farewell, I set out through streets thronged with people whose bright eyes are again turned on the future. But for me the future holds no shining promise. All I can see in the wide countryside dissolving towards a blue horizon is the shadow of inevitable night.

CHAPTER TWO
The Light of My Own Vampire

All that astounds and expands the spirit, and fills us with awe, is in those cloud-piercing icy pinnacles. The weight of millions of years is up there. I foresee that I am destined to become the most wretched of human beings. Already, in my early twenties, my life seems drained of purpose. My only feelings are of tragic grandeur and artful decay. It seems that I drive through the empty world at the end of time.

CHAPTER THREE
CHAPTER THREE
The True Murderer

The gates open at dawn, and I hasten through the familiar streets to my father's house. I anticipated this homecoming so long, yet now I hardly take note of my surroundings. What should I say of last night's encounter?

xoptx Tell them you saw William's killer.

That was my first thought. But when I reflect on the story that I have to tell... a being whom I myself formed and endued with life... a chance encounter at midnight among the precipices of an inaccessible mountain. Remember how Henri attributed every mention of the monster to my nervous fever? Knowledge of that illness would give an air of delirium to a tale already quite improbable. Of a certainty, if anyone were to tell me such a story, I would take them for mad.
Besides, the superhuman nature of the monster would elude all pursuit, even if I were so far credited as to persuade my relatives to commence it. And then of what use would be pursuit? Who could arrest a creature capable of scaling the overhanging sides of Mont Salève? By this reasoning, I am resolved to remain silent.

The trial begins at eleven o'clock. My father and Elizabeth are of course obliged to attend as witnesses. It is a living torture. Today's proceedings will decide whether the result of my curiosity and lawless devices will be proved to cause the death of two of my fellow beings: one a smiling lad full of innocence and joy, the other far more dreadfully murdered. I say more dreadfully because the instrument of murder in Justine's case is the law itself, which was created to protect the innocent.

The trial is about to begin.

Elizabeth professes affection for Justine but I think she never really knew her. To my cousin she has always been 'dear little Justine' the faithful servant. But Justine, as I know well, is a real person with her own moods, whims, accomplishments, pleasures and goals. A fully rounded human being, whose human flaws mean that she is deserving of the protection of the law no less - indeed, infinitely more - than if she were the perfect submissive doll that Elizabeth imagines her to be.

Do you think I have not considered that? A thousand times rather would I confess myself guilty of the crime ascribed to Justine, but I was absent when it was committed. Such a declaration would be seen as the ravings of a madman only. It would not save her.

You saw her letter to me. I hardly think I need spell out to you the kind of relations that may exist between the eighteen-year-old son of a well-to-do Genovese family and a hearty, uncomplicated young serving girl.
There is not the gulf between classes here in Geneva that existed in France before the Revolution. Yes, I know her as a dear friend.
Moreover, Justine possesses admirable qualities that promised to make her life happy. She should have had a husband and a family, whose lives she would have shaped with passion and wisdom. Justine appears calm. She is dressed in black, and her countenance, always engaging, is rendered exquisitely beautiful by the solemnity of her feelings.

As far as I can see, Justine carries herself with dignity and confidence, no doubt assured, despite the opprobrium laden upon her, that her guiltlessness will protect her from any calamity. Moreover, mindful that her confused statements at the time of arrest counted against her, I think she must have worked up her mind to this appearance of courage.
She looks around the court and quickly discovers where we are seated. Catching my eye, she gives a strange little grimace. I have seen it on the face of patients during an amputation, holding up steadfastly - because our dignity is always more precious to us than any discomfort - but for those nerve spasms that betray the violent turmoil beneath. Ovid tells us that even Atlas was seen to wince.
Justine, who is of strong character, quickly recovers. She returns my gaze with a smile of sorrowful affection that seems to attest her utter guiltlessness.

The trial begins. After the advocate against her has stated the charge, several witnesses are called. Before long, if I didn't know her for a fact to be innocent, I admit I would start to have doubts.
The facts are damning. She was out the whole of the night on which the murder was committed. Towards morning she was seen by a market-woman not far from the spot where William's body was afterwards found. The woman asked Justine what she was doing there, but she looked very strangely and only returned a confused and unintelligible answer. She returned to the house about eight o'clock in the morning, and when the cook asked where she had spent the night, she replied that she had been looking for William and demanded earnestly if there had been any news. When shown his body, she fell into violent hysterics and kept to her bed for several days.
The advocate now brings out the brooch that the servant found in Justine's pocket. He calls on Elizabeth, who testifies in a faltering voice that it was the same that, an hour before the child was missed, she had placed round his neck. At this, a murmur of horror and indignation fills the court.

I do not dispute it, I merely say that it was without my knowledge. Yes. Did the man in the street say to her, 'William Frankenstein has gone missing?' Surely not. He would have merely told her that a search party was out for a missing child. Of course, perhaps he recognized her. The encounter in the street might, after all, have taken place outside our very door. But in that case why be vague? Why not say, 'As I was nearing home, a man recognized me and told me that the household was out looking for Master William'?

I am the only one who knows for a certainty that she is not the killer, and even I find elements of her testimony hard to accept. I am afraid there's little chance of an acquittal unless I can produce some firm evidence. But what?

The advocate is asking her about the brooch.

She ought to be more organized in her thoughts. The magistrates will recognize her to be an uneducated girl, without the skill to marshal logic or rhetoric to her aid, but that may not necessarily count in her favour. They may say to themselves, 'She is confused because she is just a blameless serving girl,' or they might say, 'This is exactly the sort of crime a stupid lower-class girl like that might commit.'

Why not? Justine is without blame and, like the rest of us, she clings to her faith that the law exists to apportion justice. But look at the faces of everyone around us. Their minds are already made up. See that old man scowling at her? He is furious that a serving girl like her even has the temerity to defend herself. And that woman there, with pursed lips. She's gripping the seat in front so hard that her knuckles are white. She could pass by a whore in the street and not unveil a look of such disfavour as she has for my poor Justine.

How does she explain the stolen jewellery?

'Concerning the stolen brooch I can give no account, but I did not steal it. I know how heavily and fatally this one circumstance weighs against me, but I have no power of explaining it and, when I have expressed my utter ignorance, I am only left to conjecture concerning the probabilities by which it might have been placed in my pocket. But here also I am checked. I believe that I have no enemy on Earth, and none surely would have been so wicked as to destroy me wantonly. Did the murderer place it there? I know of no opportunity afforded him for so doing. In any case, why should he have stolen the brooch, to part with it again so soon?'

Several witnesses are called. All have known Justine for many years. Some step up to speak well of her. But fear, and hatred of the crime of which they suppose her guilty, renders those few timorous. Others have not shown up at court at all, being unwilling to come forward.

Of course. Excellent Elizabeth - this is Geneva, they love to hear a meek, well-spoken girl like her. None of your musket-wielding French harpies for this crowd. But the approval is all for Elizabeth herself. It is her generous interference they applaud, not the defendant.
You see - ? Justine stands and the applause turns to jeers. Now we can add blackest ingratitude to her crimes. Public indignation is adamantine, my friend. It screeches so loud as to deafen Reason. I saw it all in Paris. The crowd, having made up its mind, thinks and acts as a single entity. Not one of these people clamouring for the poor girl's punishment is any longer amenable to facts. They have confused the enormity of the deed, and their consequent thirst for vengeance, with the needs of justice.

It's horrible to witness - like seeing someone slip inexorably towards a precipice, with no power to prevent the calamity. If only I could do something. Poor Justine. I tell the court how Justine came to our household. 'Madame Moritz, her mother, was a widow with four children, of whom Justine was the third. Justine - that is, the defendant - had always been the favourite of her father but, after his death, mother and daughter were at loggerheads. My late mother observed this and, when Justine was twelve years of age, prevailed on Madame Moritz to allow her to live at our house.
'My mother conceived a great attachment for her, by which she was induced to give her an education superior to that which she had at first intended. This benefit was fully repaid by Justine's gratitude. I do not mean that she made any professions - I never heard one pass her lips - but you could see by her eyes that she adored her mistress. Although Justine's disposition is gay and in many respects inconsiderate, yet she paid the greatest attention to every gesture of my mother. She thought her the model of all excellence and endeavoured to imitate her phraseology and manners, so that even now she often reminds me of her.'
The prosecution advocate has been trying to interrupt me. 'I beg the court's indulgence, but I am curious as to your use of the term “inconsiderate”.'

I tell the court how Justine first came to live in our household at the age of twelve, was a playmate to my cousin and me, grew up with us, how she nursed my mother through her final illness, and the comfort she gave to Elizabeth and the maternal affection she bestowed on William after my mother's death.
'But, Monsieur Frankenstein,' says the prosecuting advocate, 'you have spent the last six years in Paris. How can you testify as to the defendant's adult character?'
'Because I know goodness when I see it, sir. Justine Moritz had a thousand opportunities to steal from us. I would happily leave a thousand thalers on a table where she was dusting, confident that not a single coin would be touched. Unless it had grime upon it.'
The advocate scowls at the nervous titters of laughter. 'Theft is not really the crime that most concerns us today, though, is it?'
'It is the major part of your circumstantial evidence against Miss Moritz. When that is removed, what motive could she have had for killing one she loved?'
'The semblance of love is not hard to affect – ' he tilts his finger in her direction – 'in one of this hardened and dissembling nature. That will be all, thank you, Monsieur.'

'By that I mean only that she is disinclined to think deeply about matters. She lives, as many do, in the moment. In my opinion she is not the kind of person to plan a crime in meticulous detail, as - '
'Ah, indeed!' says the advocate, smacking his hand down in triumph. 'And we have seen that this crime, appalling though it was, lacks any evidence of careful planning. That will be all, Monsieur Frankenstein.'

'I mean only that she is not given to excessive deliberation. That is, she is considerate of the feelings of others, but it is not in her nature to consider her future plans from every angle. That is no doubt why she became a maid of service rather than, say, a lawyer.'

I continue: 'When my dear mother died every one was too much occupied in their own grief to notice poor Justine, who had attended her during her illness with the most anxious affection. The advocate is on his feet again. 'You say that her nature, previously insolent, had now become crafty and dissembling?'

A ruthless analysis.

There's a good role model.

'You are describing the pathological mind, Father.'

She may yet be found not guilty.

I pass a night of undiluted wretchedness. In the morning I come straight to the courthouse without stopping to have breakfast, so as to be here when the verdict is announced. My lips and throat are so parched that I can hardly speak.

So. Justine is condemned to die.

I cannot pretend to describe what I am feeling. I have before experienced sensations of horror, and I have tried to find the words to frankly convey them to you, but I don't have words to describe this heart-sickening despair.

A servant enters. 'There's a message for you, sir,' she says, handing me a note.

Read it.

It's from Justine's defence counsel. 'She asks to see you, Elizabeth.'
To my surprise, she agrees to go. This is the last straw for my father, who has been out of countenance all morning. 'How can you even consider it, Elizabeth, after what Victor has just told us? She confessed!' he says in a hoarse voice.
He should know better than to try to change Elizabeth's mind. 'I will go, although she is guilty. I would regret every day of my life if I left her to go to her death without the chance to speak her words of repentance. And you, Victor, shall accompany me - I cannot go alone.'

Speak to her when she returns.

The idea of this visit is torture to me, yet I cannot refuse.

Go with Elizabeth to the prison.

Justine is sitting on some straw. Her hands are manacled and her head rests on her knees. She rises on seeing us enter the gloomy cell and, when we are left alone with her, she throws herself at Elizabeth's feet. Both women are weeping bitterly.

Dear lady, I had none to support me. What could I do? In an evil hour I subscribed to a lie.'
Elizabeth catches my eye. I can see she wants to believe.

xoptx Say something to comfort her.

Tell Justine to go on.

Justine pauses, weeping, and then continues. 'I am horror-struck, my friends, to think you might believe me capable of such a crime. Dear William! Dearest blessed child, I soon shall see you again in heaven, where we shall all be happy.'

xoptx Let her speak.
