I don't ask her how a diatribe against capital punishment, delivered in lurid terms, is meant to comfort Justine. Elizabeth would only feign innocent incomprehension. Suddenly I am disgusted with her games - with all such dainty human cruelties.

xoptx It's time you both left.

xoptx Tell Elizabeth you must talk to Justine alone.

Elizabeth returns with a brave smile in place of her earlier tears. She explains that Justine only confessed in order to receive absolution from the priest. I see my father's look on hearing this, but he bites his tongue.

Amiable cousin! Her thoughts are so mild and gentle. She hates to think ill of anyone, especially one she loves as dearly as her faithful maid. But I - I am a wretch, and none can guess at the misery that I must endure in silence.

Ah, good. She is consoled. Angels may weep, Justine faces death, and I am racked with shame and guilt. But Elizabeth at least can sleep soundly tonight, as her faith in human nature has not had to face the litmus test that would destroy it.

Attend Justine's execution.

'The executioners believe they have done a great deed. They call this retribution. Hateful word! When they say retribution, I know greater and more horrid punishments are going to be inflicted than the gloomiest tyrant has ever invented to satiate his utmost revenge.'
Elizabeth pauses and seems to reflect on the horrific effect her words are having on Justine. Justine smiles languidly. 'This, dear lady, is despair, and not resignation. Talk of something else, something that will bring peace, and not increase of misery.'
During this conversation I have retired to a corner of the cell, trying to distance myself from Elizabeth's extraordinary outburst which, I can only assume, is intended to chastise both me and Justine. I feel their eyes on my back. Should I speak?

xoptx Nothing you can say will help.

xoptx Tell Elizabeth to leave you alone with Justine.

True, silence better conceals the horrid anguish that currently possesses me. Despair! Who dares talk of that? The poor victim, who tomorrow will pass the dreary boundary between life and death? She cannot feel such deep and bitter agony as mine. I gnash my teeth, grinding them together and uttering a groan from my inmost soul.
Indeed, how can I trust myself to speak when it is my actions that have doomed both my brother and this poor lovely girl who has been made the scapegoat for his murder? And now to hear Elizabeth twist a gentle knife between her ribs with talk of reeking blood, retribution, and her own idle whim for a romantic death. It is insane! A nightmare! I gnash my teeth, grinding them together and uttering a groan from my inmost soul.

It's time you left.

We came to comfort Justine; I think she comforted us. As we say farewell, she indeed seems to have gained the resignation she desired. But I, the true murderer, feel the never-dying worm alive in my bosom, which allows of no hope or consolation.
I'm surprised to find I'm crying. Elizabeth also weeps, but hers is the misery of innocence, which, like a cloud that passes over the fair moon, hides but cannot tarnish its brightness. Anguish and despair have penetrated into the core of my heart. I bear a hell within me, which nothing can extinguish.
As the cell door clangs shut, Elizabeth gives a cry of great passion. 'I wish,' she calls to Justine, 'that I were to die with you. I cannot live in this world of misery.'
Justine reaches through the bars to clasp Elizabeth's hand. 'Farewell, sweet lady, dearest Elizabeth, my beloved and only friend. May heaven in its bounty bless and preserve you. May this be the last misfortune that you will ever suffer. Live, and be happy, and make others so.'

I leave her there and spend the next few hours pacing the streets. Anyone seeing me would think me a man trying either to find or to escape from something. Which is true, I wonder?

Attend Justine's execution.

'You are upsetting yourself,' I tell Elizabeth. 'Why not wait for me outside?'
She is reluctant to leave, but after many tears and embraces and backward glances, she finally suffers herself to be separated from her unfortunate maid. When we are alone, I ask Justine frankly about the matter of the confession.
She kisses me tenderly. 'Oh Victor, don't ask me that. I only want you to know that I am not guilty. Tomorrow I can go to meet the hangman without regrets, if that is so.'
'I know you are not guilty, dearest Justine. But why confess?'
She cannot hold my gaze. 'I still have family,' is all she will say. 'A little niece whom I adore. Since I am to be executed either way - '
'What? Has somebody threatened you?'

xoptx Ask about the brooch.

xoptx Say you'll speak to the magistrates.

'How did you come to have the brooch, Justine? Do you know how it got in your pocket?'
She nods, struggling with a spasm of emotion that deprives her of the power of speech. 'That night. I went to sleep in the barn, and - Oh God, Victor, I didn't believe it could be real! I thought it was a nightmare!'
'What? Tell me!'
I'm shaking her. She gives a sob and suddenly is in floods of tears - ugly, unrestrained tears, very different from her melancholy weeping with Elizabeth. 'It's too - I can't, it's too - '
'Too what?'
'Too shameful!'
I can get nothing else out of her. Bidding an emotional farewell, I escape into the teeming streets where life goes on.

Attend Justine's execution.

'My father appointed half the judges. I'll speak to him...'
She shakes her head, suddenly releasing the flood of unrestrained, ugly tears she wouldn't let Elizabeth see. 'It would do no good. Oh, go, Victor. I want you here but it does no good now. Let me be alone to make my peace with God.'
She is distant, her mind already half in the next world. I stay a little while, watching her pray, then slip away quietly to avoid the pain of farewell.

Attend Justine's execution.

She is hanged the next day. Apart from a priest, the executioner and a few court officials, I am the only one present. Justine, blindfolded, may not even have known I came.
After feelings have been worked up by a quick succession of calamities, the dead calmness of inaction and certainty that follows acts to deprive the soul both of hope and fear. Justine is dead, she rests now, and I am alive. The blood flows freely in my veins, but a weight of despair and remorse presses on my heart which nothing can remove.
In the days that follow I am unable to sleep. I wander the streets like an evil spirit. I have committed deeds of mischief beyond description, I know that, yet my heart overflows with kindness and the love of virtue. I set out on my course with benevolent intentions, thirsting for the moment when I should put my knowledge in service to my fellow beings. Now all is blasted. Instead of that serenity of conscience which would allow me to look back upon the past with self-satisfaction, and from thence to gather promise of new hopes, I am seized by remorse and the crushing sense of guilt, which hurries me on through the darkened streets, hounded by the half-dreams that sleeplessness has rendered feverish, submerged in my own hell of intense tortures such as no language can describe.

END OF PART THREE


PART FOUR
The everlasting universe of things
Flows through the mind, and rolls its rapid waves,
Now dark--now glittering--now reflecting gloom--
Now lending splendour, where from secret springs
The source of human thought its tribute brings.

CHAPTER ONE
The River of Ice

This brooding state of mind starts to take its toll upon my health, which has never entirely recovered from the shock it sustained in Paris. I begin to dread company. All sound of joy or even complacency is torture to me. Solitude is my only consolation.
I'm aware that my father and Elizabeth are concerned at my dark moods and long hours spent apart from them. After six years' absence, I should make the effort to give more of myself. On the other hand, the shades of William and Justine are always at my shoulder, silent and accusing, and yet I can give them nothing, make no reparation for the fiend I unleashed to destroy them.
As always, my father is making arrangements for the family to spend the summer at our house at Bellerive. I am in two minds whether to accompany them.

xoptx It will do you good.

xoptx Stay here in Geneva.

I take your advice, but soon realize my error. I thought I desired to be alone, but while the house murmured to my father and Elizabeth talking after dinner, or the gay thoughtless chatter and laughter of the servants, my exile had a kind of noble remoteness. Now, with the house almost empty, I find the silence pressing in on me until it is hard to breathe. The creak of a door, or the scratching of a leaf upon the windowpane, is almost unbearable. I am plunged back to the terrible estrangement of time and sensation that I experienced during my illness.
Sometimes I weep bitterly, praying for peace to revisit my mind only that I might afford my loved ones consolation and happiness. A foolish, futile prayer! I have been the author of unalterable evils, and must live in daily fear that the monster thatwhom I created will perpetrate some new wickedness.

xoptx Surely its revenge is complete.

xoptx Would you want to meet it now?

xoptx Surely his revenge is complete.

xoptx Would you want to meet him now?

I doubt it. I am troubled by an obscure feeling that it has yet to commit his greatest crime. Terrible to me though William's murder was, the child can have meant nothing to the monster. The act must rather have been calculated to strike at me, and therefore I dread to speculate on how it will next contrive to do me harm.
You cannot conceive my abhorrence of this fiend. See my hand trembling? I don't know if that is fear or rage. Both, perhaps. My heart jumps like one of Galvani's frogs and I feel my jaw tighten, whenever I think of its leering red face emerging from the chemical bath that spawned it. Oh, how I wish I could extinguish that life which I so thoughtlessly bestowed.I doubt it. I am troubled by an obscure feeling that he has yet to commit his greatest crime. Terrible to me though William's murder was, the child can have meant nothing to the monster. The act must rather have been calculated to strike at me, and therefore I dread to speculate on how he will next contrive to do me harm.
You cannot conceive my abhorrence of this fiend. See my hand trembling? I don't know if that is fear or rage. Both, perhaps. My heart jumps like one of Galvani's frogs and I feel my jaw tighten, whenever I think of his leering red face emerging from the chemical bath that spawned him. Oh, how I wish I could extinguish that life which I so thoughtlessly bestowed.

You need to get away for a while.

Oh yes. I would make a pilgrimage to the highest peak of the Andes if I could throw the fiend off it. I both fear and desire to see it again, that I might wreak the utmost extent of abhorrence on itshim off it. I both fear and desire to see him again, that I might wreak the utmost extent of abhorrence on his head and avenge the deaths of William and Justine.
Think what that monster has wrought. Our house is the house of mourning. My father's health is deeply shaken. Elizabeth has become sad and desponding; she thinks that even to smile would be sacrilege toward the dead. She is no longer that happy creature who in earlier youth wandered with me on the banks of the lake and talked with ecstasy of our future prospects. The first of those sorrows that are sent to wean us from the Earth has visited her, and its dimming influence has quenched her dearest smiles.

You need a complete change.

I have taken your advice, and you were right. Back in Geneva I felt constantly trapped. It was impossible to take a boat out on the lake after ten o'clock, when the gates are shut, and in summer that is to waste the most sweetly melancholy of the day's hours.
But here in Bellerive, I'm free. Tonight, for instance. Now that my father and Elizabeth have retired for the night, instead of feeling hemmed in by heavy stone walls, I can go out on Lake Neuchâtel under the moonlight. I almost feel like setting the sails and letting the boat run where it will. Out here in the middle of the water, surrounded by the milky immensity of the night sky, I can shrug off for a short while the sense of oppression that dogs me at all other times. Thoughts, feelings and even sense of self fall away. One is left with just the comforting void.

xoptx Are you talking about suicide?

xoptx Is it safe out here alone at night?

Strange you should say that. I am sometimes tempted, when all around is utterly peaceful like this, and I the only unquiet thing that wanders restless in a scene so beautiful and heavenly...

xoptx Yes, go on.

xoptx What's that in the water?

I was just going to say that I'm tempted to plunge into the silent lake, let the waters close over me and so end my calamities forever. Perhaps I would, but I must think of the heroic and suffering Elizabeth, whom I tenderly love, and whose existence has been bound up in mine since she was first brought into our household to be my betrothed. And then there's my poor father. How can I desert him, when he has already lost one son?
And if duty and love did not carry weight enough, logic also adds her thumb to the scales. For would it not be base desertion to leave my family exposed and unprotected to the malice of the fiend whom I let loose among them?

Better head back.

A large fish, perhaps. I heard it splash. Very large. It must have returned to the depths - I see no sign of anything now.
The night is getting cold. And yet the wind has dropped. I had better row back.

And then?

The days creep by. Neither the tenderness of friendship, nor the beauty of Earth and heaven, can redeem my soul from woe. The very accents of love are ineffectual. I feel myself encompassed by a cloud that no beneficial influence can penetrate. The wounded deer dragging its fainting limbs to some untrodden brake, there to gaze upon the arrow which has pierced it, and to die, is but a type of me.

xoptx You should speak to your father.

xoptx Elizabeth's company will ease this grim mood.

xoptx You need a complete change.

'I have observed the alteration in your mood,' says my father, as we walk out with cigars along the loggia of the house. 'You blame yourself for William's death - '
'Father, I am to blame!'
' - because you were not there to protect him. But, Victor, none of us could protect him. Rather than blame yourself, turn your fury on me. It was almost under my eye that the killer struck.'
'You don't understand.'
'Do you think, my son, that I don't suffer also? No one could love a child more than I loved your brother' - tears come into his eyes - 'but is it not a duty to the survivors that we should refrain from augmenting their unhappiness by immoderate grief? You owe that duty to yourself, for excessive sorrow prevents improvement or enjoyment, or even the discharge of daily usefulness, without which no man is fit for society.'
He does not understand that his advice, although good, is totally inapplicable to my case. I should be the first to hide my grief and console my friends if remorse did not mingle its bitterness, and terror its alarm, with my other sensations. I can only answer my father with a look of despair.

xoptx Speak to Elizabeth.

xoptx It's time you got away for a break.

It's time you got away for a break.

Elizabeth listens as I try to describe my morbid state of agitation.
'When I reflect, my dear cousin,' she says, 'on the miserable death of Justine Moritz, I no longer see the world and its works as they before appeared to me. Before, I looked upon the accounts of vice and injustice that I read in books as tales of imaginary evils. At least they were remote, but now misery has come home, and men appear to me as monsters thirsting for each other's blood.'
'But, Elizabeth, I am not talking of abstract disillusionment.'
'Yes, I see that. Everybody believed that poor girl to be guilty and, if she had murdered William, assuredly she would have been the most depraved of human creatures. For the sake of a few jewels, to have slain the son of her benefactor and friend, a child whom she had nursed from its birth, and appeared to love as if it had been her own!'
'Assuredly. But - '
'But Justine was innocent. I know. I feel she was innocent. You are of the same opinion, and that confirms me. Alas! Victor, when falsehood can look so like the truth, who can assure themselves of certain happiness? I feel as if I were walking on the edge of a precipice, towards which thousands are crowding and endeavouring to plunge me into the abyss. William and Justine were assassinated, and the true murderer has escaped justice. He walks about the world free, perhaps even respected. But even if I were condemned to suffer on the scaffold for the same crimes, I would not change places with such a wretch, for surely his conscience must cause him torment.'
'All the torments of hell,' I agree.

xoptx Ask her advice.

xoptx Speak to your father.

xoptx This is doing no good. You need to get away for a while.

Hear that splash just now? A large fish, perhaps. Very large - although sounds are magnified out here on the water. Anyway, it must have returned to the depths, as I see no sign of anything now.
The night is getting cold. I had better row back.

And then?

Not in deed, but in effect, I am the true murderer. Elizabeth reads the anguish in my countenance, but of course could never guess its cause. Taking my hand, she says, 'My dearest friend, you must calm yourself. These events have affected me, God knows how deeply, but I am not so wretched as you are. There is an expression of despair, and sometimes of revenge, in your countenance that makes me tremble. Dear Victor, banish these dark passions. Remember the friends around you, who centre all their hopes in you. Have we lost the power of rendering you happy? Ah! While we love, while we are true to each other, here in this land of peace and beauty, your native country, we may reap every tranquil blessing. What can disturb our peace?'
These words, from her whom I fondly prize before every other gift of fortune, are almost enough to chase away for a brief interval the fears that lurk in my heart. Even as she is speaking I draw her to me, as if in terror, lest at this very moment the fiend is lurking nearby to rob me of her.It is no use. Unless I were to share with her the horror of my profane deed, I can never make her understand. And that horror is mine alone.

You really need a complete change of scenery.

You have hit the nail on the head. Since I was very young, I've found that sometimes I can cope with the brooding thoughts that overwhelm me, but at other times the whirlwind passions of my soul drive me to seek, by bodily exercise and by change of place, some relief from my intolerable sensations.
So, see here, I have a map of the Alpine valleys. I intend to set out and seek the magnificence, the eternity of such scenes, to forget myself and my ephemeral human sorrows.

An excellent idea.

My father is pleased to hear my plans. 'I see how extreme is your grief, Victor. While you remain in these surroundings, from which you were so long absent, such raw feelings can only fester and grow deeper. The tonic you need is an excursion to those places associated only in your mind with boyhood amusements.'
'For my part,' says Elizabeth, looking up from the sampler she is sewing, 'I should enjoy an excursion up into the mountains.'
I had not thought of them accompanying me. Yet now that I see the smiling relief on their faces at my plan to banish the abject dolour in which I have been sunk, how can I refuse them?

xoptx Say that you need to travel alone.

xoptx Let them come if they want to.

They are not happy about that. Elizabeth seems to fear that I will do myself harm if left alone to brood.
When I explain that I need time and solitude to recover myself, though, my father nods, understanding my feelings. 'You need a new homecoming, one unclouded by the dreadful events of your first. Go, then, and come back to us.'

Over the next few days, my wanderings carry me towards the valley of Chamounix. I visited it frequently during my boyhood. The mountains appear at a distance, gradually advancing as I proceed up the ravine formed by the river Arve until they close off the sun.
Let's see, it's now the middle of August. It's been nearly two months since the trial, that miserable epoch from which I date all my woe. Many years have passed since I was last at this spot. I am a wreck, but nothing has changed in these savage and enduring scenes.

xoptx How have your nerves been since setting out?

xoptx This excursion will be good for you.

'You have so often described to me the beauty of the scenery near Chamounix,' says Elizabeth, in high spirits as soon as I acquiesce to her accompanying me.
During the first day we travel in a carriage. The mountains, appearing hazily in the distance in the morning, swiftly grow nearer. The Arve valley, whose course we follow, closes in upon us by degrees, shutting out the sun. Immense mountains and precipices overhang us on every side, and there is the constant echoing roar of waterfalls and the river raging below.
The next day we continue our journey on mules. As we ascend still higher, the valley assumes a more magnificent and astonishing character. Ruined castles hang on the precipices of pine-swathed mountains, and from time to time cottages peep forth from among the trees.

xoptx Is the trip helping to lift your spirits?

xoptx How are you coping with Elizabeth and your father?

The weight upon my spirit is sensibly lightened as I plunge yet deeper into the ravine of Arve. The immense mountains and precipices that overhang on every side, the sound of the river raging among the rocks, and the dashing of the waterfalls around, all speak of a power mighty as Omnipotence. Faced with that, I cease to fear the monster's vengeance. Why should I bend before any being less almighty than that which created and rules the elements, here displayed in their most terrific guise?

Indeed, now you can start to fight back.

The scenery is of singular beauty, of course, but what renders it sublime are the mighty Alps, whose white and shining pyramids and domes tower above all, as belonging to another Earth, the habitations of another race of beings.
We pass the bridge of Pelissier, where the ravine opens before us, and begin to ascend the mountain that overhangs it. Soon after, we enter the valley of Chamounix. The high and snowy mountains are its immediate boundaries. Colossal glaciers spill their scree upon the road.
'What is that rumbling sound?' says Elizabeth, half afraid and half delighted. 'Is it thunder?'
'An avalanche,' says my father, pointing to a plume of fine white smoke beyond the next ridge.
The weather is uncommonly fine, and above all rises the cathedral-white dome of Mont Blanc - the supreme and magnificent Mont Blanc. If mine were a sorrow to be chased away by any fleeting circumstances, this excursion would certainly have the effect intended by my father.

Press on to your destination.

It's not easy. Overwhelmed by the scenery as much as my turbulent emotions, I need a place to retreat and take stock. It is impossible to do this when Elizabeth is exclaiming every few minutes at some fragile butterfly alighted on a roadside bush, or the charm of peasant clothing, or the wood carvings under the eaves of cottages, or the fresh spray thrown up from waterfalls turning to rubies and sapphires in the sun.
Sometimes I allow my mule to lag behind, so that I may indulge in the misery of reflection. At other times I spur the animal on ahead of my companions, that I might forget them, the world, and most of all myself. At one point, getting a good mile further on the track, I alight and throw myself on the grass, weighed down by horror and despair, only to be disturbed all too soon by Elizabeth's trilling laughter and my father calling in clumsy good-humour, 'Are you going to doze away the whole trip, son?'
'Isn't it beautiful?' says Elizabeth, as I get back on my mule. Then a gust of wind comes up the valley and she has to clutch at her bonnet.
'That's from the south,' I say. 'It'll rain tomorrow.'

A tingling long-lost sense of pleasure has often come across me during this journey. At every turn in the road, some sight might remind me of days gone by - days associated with the light-hearted gaiety of boyhood. The very winds whisper in soothing accents, and maternal Nature bids me weep no more.
But at other times this kindly influence ceases to act. At those moments, trekking in the cold twilight of the rock faces with no sight of sun, I have found myself fettered again to grief. Fight it as I will, I cannot help indulging in all the misery of reflection. Then I spur on my mule, striving to forget the world, my fears, and, more than all, myself. And once, overcome by desperation, I alight and throw myself on the grass, weighed down by horror and despair.

Yes, here is the village of Chamounix. It's only as I get down from my mulewe get down from our mules that I realize how exhausted I am. I order an early supper in my room, but am too exhausted to eat it. Instead I stand at the window, watching nightfall reveal the pallid lightning that plays above Mont Blanc and listening to the rushing of the Arve, which pursues its noisy way beneath. The same lulling sounds act as a lullaby. When I place my head upon my pillow, sleep takes me swiftly. I feel it as it comes and bless the giver of oblivion.

xoptx Any dreams?

xoptx A new day tomorrow!

A new day tomorrow!

Curiously, as the purpose of this excursion was to have some time to myself, I dreamt that Father and Elizabeth came with me. All the way up the mountain, I either lagged behind or spurred my mule to overtake them. Elizabeth called out to me as I passed, and I hated myself for ignoring her yet still I did.
Then it became a game of hide and seek, as I concealed myself among the rocks and quaked with silent laughter to see them ride by, unaware of my proximity. 'Victor seems happier now that he's gone, don't you think?' I heard Father say.
I rushed out to protest, but my throat was so constricted that, when I called out to them, I could produce only a muffled groan. After some effort, I made myself heard. Elizabeth twisted in her saddle to look at me, just as a shaft of pure sunlight broke across the mountain peak to illuminate her.
'Why, Victor,' she said, laughing gaily, 'you see what happiness you diffuse when you are newly formed. Do not go back to your vat again.'
And when I raised my hands, I saw that the skin was transparent, revealing all the bloody working of muscles and the gleaming white of bone and sinew.

What do you think that means?

Oneiromancy, you mean? I am not superstitious enough to believe one's fortune can be marked out in dreams. Doubtless the preoccupation of my thoughts by the creature, combined with a somewhat morbid cast laid on by my own culpability in his crimes, created this nasty little shadow play to entertain my sleeping hours. Our minds are a vortex of sensation, memory and speculation, my friend, and small wonder those ingredients make a mystery of our dreams.

I don't say anything, but he brings me his book anyway. 'The Agonies of Young Werther,' I read on the cover. And inside: 'Volume One.'
'Volume Two is much the same but he dies at the end,' supplies the innkeeper helpfully.

The ascent is precipitous, but the path is cut into continual short windings, which enable one to surmount the perpendicularity of the mountain. It is a terrifically desolate scene. Everywhere you can see traces of the winter avalanche, where trees lie broken on the ground.
The path, as I ascend higher, is intersected by ravines of snow, down which stones continually roll from above. One of them is particularly dangerous, as the slightest sound - even raising your voice - risks bringing destruction upon the head of the speaker.
The pines here are not tall or luxuriant, but they are sombre and add an air of severity to the scene. Pausing after an hour's ascent, I look down on the valley. Vast mists are rising from the rivers, curling in thick wreaths around the opposite mountains, whose summits are buried in the uniform clouds. It is a melancholy vista, not helped by the sheets of rain lacing down from an iron-grey sky.

xoptx Nonetheless, an impressive view.

xoptx So your mood is no more cheerful?

You ask me that? Alas! Why does man boast of sensibilities superior to those apparent in the animals? It only renders us more needful. If our impulses were confined to hunger, thirst, and desire, we might be nearly free. But we are moved by every wind that blows and chance word spoken. A dream has power to poison sleep, and one wandering thought pollutes the day.

You said yourself that dreams signify nothing.

Indeed. It is nearly noon when I arrive at the top of the ascent, where there is a rock overlooking the sea of ice. A mist covers both that and the surrounding mountains, but by the time I've finished lunch a breeze has blown up, dissipating the mist so that it is safe to descend onto the glacier.
The surface is very uneven, rising like the waves of a troubled sea, descending low, and interspersed by rifts that sink deep. The field of ice is about three miles across but it takes me nearly two hours to cross it. The opposite mountain is a bare perpendicular rock. From this side, Montanvert is exactly opposite, and above it rises, in awful majesty, the immense bulk of Mont Blanc.
I remain in a recess of the rock, gazing on this wonderful and stupendous scene. The vast river of ice winds among the mountains, whose aerial summits loom overhead. Their icy and glittering peaks shine in the sunlight over the clouds. My heart was sorrowful before, as you know, but now swells with something like joy must feel, if I can remember joy.
Suffused in the sunlight that plays above the icy breath of the glacier, I cannot resist the urge to raise my voice and shout to the heavens: 'Wandering spirits, if indeed you wander, and do not rest in your graves, allow me this faint happiness, or take me, as your companion, away from the joys of life.'

It turns back across the ice. What can I do? I follow. As we proceed, I weigh its various arguments and determine at least to listen to its tale. I am partly urged by curiosity, partly by compassion. I have hitherto supposed it to be the murderer of my brother, and I need a confirmation or denial of this. For the first time, also, I feel what the duties of a creator towards his creature should be, and that I ought to render it happy before I complain of its wickedness.

Our route will take us down the Rhine to Rotterdam, and from there to London. On the river we pass many willowy islands and beautiful towns. We stay one night at Manheim, and, on the fifth day after our departure from Strasbourg, arrive at Mainz.
The landscape below this point becomes much more picturesque. The river descends rapidly and winds between hills that are not high, but still steep. We see many ruined castles standing on the edges of precipices, surrounded by inaccessible black woods. This part of the Rhine presents a singularly variegated landscape. In one spot you view rugged hills and ruined castles overlooking tremendous precipices, with the dark Rhine rushing beneath. Then, on the sudden turn of a promontory, flourishing vineyards lie revealed, with green sloping banks, a meandering river, and populous towns.

How soon do you reach England?

Our next stop is Oxford. Unlike Paris, where the university nests within the bosom of the city, here the magnificent colleges, interwoven by the lovely silver thread of the Isis and with stone walls and spires ablaze in the cold January light, create an impression of an Empyrean realm dedicated to the sacred pursuit of knowledge.
After a few days, however, my elation is tinged with disappointment. Oxford's curriculum elevates the arts but, in the sciences, places more emphasis on the teachings of the past than on the uncovering of nature's many still-guarded secrets. Bacon taught the supreme importance of empirical methods, but these scholars of today content themselves merely with endless discussion of his experiments.
At one lecture, my patience wears so thin that, under the pretext of asking a question, I draw attention to a number of developments in biology and chemistry of which the professor seems unaware. Our dispute creates a stir of excitement among the students, who previously gave every impression of slumber. To give him credit, rather than taking offence, he encourages me to speak and afterwards approaches me with an invitation to dine at his college.

xoptx You should accept.

Then my host explains, 'It's the quickest way to reach the hall. Across the roof, you see.'
I follow him. Outside, the flat roof is awash with rain and the dons hurry, hunched over, towards the door of the dining hall. In their slick black robes they look like great hopping crows.
My host and I have just been discussing the effect of ethyl mesylate on living cells. CHAPTER THREE

CHAPTER THREE
Forebodings of Evil

One of the remotest of the islands. It's perfect for my purposes, being hardly more than a rock whose high sides are continually beaten by the waves. You're right. I must not allow hubris and curiosity to lead me astray a second time. Somehow I must confound the monster's desires, whether they are just or not, or else a race of such creatures could threaten mankind's guardianship of this world.
The sun has set and the moon is just rising from the sea. I have been here for weeks now. The form of a female, counterpart to the filthy thingcreature I brought to life three years ago, is now complete and lies inert upon the bench, a gross hulk of flesh bathed in a tank of chemicals. She awaits the spark of electricity that will begin the process of vitalization. But that is a spark that will never come.

CHAPTER ONE
The Moment of Darkness

I walk about the island, a restless spectre. At noon, with the sun beating down strongly despite the chill wind off the sea, I am abruptly overcome by fatigue. Stretching out on the grass, I soon fall into a deep sleep, which restores me, and on awakening towards sunset I feel again as if I belong to a race of human beings like myself.
Now I am able to reflect with greater composure on what has passed, but still Adomthe fiend's words ring in my ears like a death-knell. I will be with you on your wedding night. Already it is a phrase that has taken on the character of a pronouncement in one of Perrault's fairy tales, doomy and yet dreamlike, with a dream's ability to be both more and less tangible than life.
A fishing boat arrives with a packet of letters for me. There is one from Elizabeth and one from Henri.

xoptx Read Elizabeth's.

xoptx They will keep. You have things you must do first.

I read it years ago, of course, but it's touching that she is making an effort to support my interests.. Really she has alarmingly little conception of my work.

Whether a blow is struck or my nerves simply spool out beyond their endurance, I cannot say. But the darkness at the edge of my vision grows to swallow me and then there is no one on the stage but for the baleful, invisible, but palpable presence of the monster.

The season of the assizes approaches. I have already been three months in prison and, although in continual danger of a relapse, I am obliged to travel nearly a hundred miles to the county town where the court is held.
I am spared the disgrace of appearing publicly as a criminal, as the case is not brought before a criminal court. CHAPTER THREE
CHAPTER THREE
The Cup of Life is Poisoned

Preparations are made. Congratulatory visits are received. Everyone is smiling, talking, joyful. I shut up in my own heart the anxiety that preys there in order to throw myself into my father's plans, even though they might only serve as the decorations of my tragedy. It is tomorrow. PART SIX
I seek no sympathies, nor need;
The thorns which I have reap'd are of the tree
I planted: they have torn me, and I bleed:
I should have known what fruit would spring from such a seed.

CHAPTER ONE
Wandering Ministers of Vengeance

I have hired rowers for the return trip because there is still a strong wind from the west. The fish too are unchanged, slipping through the net of rippled light just as they were when Elizabeth pointed them outyesterday. How can so monumental a change have taken place and reality takes no notice?
The bracing tang of the lake air. The autumnal patchwork of the shores. The watery dawn, with the white sun a shivering droplet balanced on the grey teeth of the mountains. The creak and splash of the oars. The fragments of the world are all present but, like a shattered vase pieced together with glue, it fulfils its function only. The thing itself has gone. I have lived through the boiling point of guilt, the freezing point of fear, and finally reached an absolute zero in which nothing stirs, no change is possible, the needle of hope no longer flickers.
In the belly of the boat she lies under a sheet, rocks from the inn's garden weighting the corners. I notice one of the men staring uncomfortably. Her hand has rolled free, as white as a chalk drawing against the dark planks, but showing a pinprick glint of colours as the rocking of the boat tilts her ring into the sun. It was my mother's, promised to Elizabeth since childhood.

xoptx It should stay here in the lake forever.

xoptx Will you bury it with her?

The ring flashes in the early light, rotating twice in the water before it slides out of the sun towards the murkier depths where trembling shade envelops it. My last glimpse is the diamond setting gleaming greenly as it settles on the brown Archaean skin of a rock. A single image, sharpened by the lens of the clear water, and then it is behind us, as irrecoverable as a moment in time.
I will live and die. A billion souls, or a billion billion, will come and go. And her ring will become the heart of a new rock - the geological evidence that we were here, and loved. And one day the Earth will break apart and that rock will be a meteor plummeting towards other suns. That vision seems more real to me, because more definite, than the events of the next twenty-four hours, when the terrible cacophonous din of emotion must surely drown out anything as frangible as bare facts.
