'But the creature of whom you speak appears to have powers that would thwart my best exertions. Who can follow an animal which can traverse the sea of ice, and inhabit caves and dens where no man would venture to intrude?'
My heart sinks. Despite having seemed to listen to my tale and to give it fair credence, his tone tells me that he does not believe a word.
It's obvious he intends to do nothing.
'Besides,' he continues, 'one of the crimes took place almost two years ago, the other several months. The killer could be halfway to the Orient by now.'
'I have no doubt that he remains near at hand. And if he has indeed taken refuge in the Alps, he may be hunted like the chamois, and destroyed as a beast of prey. But I perceive your thoughts - you do not credit my narrative, and do not intend to pursue my enemy with the punishment which is his desert.' As I speak, I feel the rage burning in my face.
'You are mistaken,' he says, a little intimidated. 'I will exert myself. If it is in my power to seize - well, the monster, if we must call him that - be assured that he shall suffer punishment proportionate to his crimes. But I fear, from what you have yourself described to be his abilities, that this will prove impossible. You must make up your mind to disappointment.'

He's just humouring you.

I weave him a story about a homicidal madman whom I treated in Paris as part of my studies, a hulking brute of a man with terrible disfigurements that set him apart from humanity. It has the beauty of being much the truth, though without the constructed body parts and the vitalizing spark through clay-like flesh. That's usually where I lose my listeners, I've found.'He was an inmate at Charenton, where he fell under the influence of the Marquis de Sade. Thus his brutality was refined into cruelty.'
'And this man escaped?'
I cast a sharp look over his shoulder and see him twitch nervously. Good, so he believes me.
'During the Revolution. Of course, all my attempts to civilize him with a serene environment were undone. He emerged into a bloodbath. Everywhere around him, shops were being smashed and looted, people torn apart by mobs. Violence, it must have seemed to him, had become the proper order of things.'
'And you say this man - '
'I prefer to say monster.'
'Yes, a monster indeed. And he has made himself the nemesis of your family?'
'He blames me for offering him a life of peace and goodness, in contrast to everything he witnessed after his escape.'

xoptx This is good. He believes you.

xoptx It's hopeless. Only you can kill the monster.

'I shall arrange protection for you,' says the magistrate decisively. 'I only wish you had come to me sooner. Your wife might still be alive.'
'Protection? No, no - we need to hunt him down.'
He purses his lips, and I feel a twinge of anger at his complacency. 'My dear sir, when he comes to assault you, as he surely will, my men will be ready.'
'How many men?'
'Two... Three.' He nods. 'An adequate number.'
'He has the strength of ten men. A hail of bullets might not stop him. He ignores pain, needs no rest, and he has a lifetime in which to exact his retribution on me. Lying in wait for him is futile. He must be hunted down.'
I see the look in his eyes. I've gone too far. I'm losing him.
'A hail of bullets?' He shakes his head as if to clear it. 'And how can I hunt him? Where is he? I don't have the manpower to scour the whole countryside. Surely if we wait...'
'I don't have that long.'
He says nothing, only looks at me quizzically. How can I tell him that my anger would run out? I must attack to survive, I need to fuel my anger. When it is gone I will have nothing left.

This is a waste of time.

'I don't think you can help me,' I tell him.
'Then who could?' He folds his hands. 'What help do you want?'
'Mountaineers, trackers, dogs, men with guns. If he is among the Alps, we must find his lair and trap him. If he is hiding in the countryside, or even in some deserted dwelling within the city, we must search until we find him. He must be surrounded. It will take many men. He could even be in the lake.'
'What?' The magistrate blinks, gives me a tiny half-smile. 'You mean he might have drowned himself?'
'He could remain underwater for hours at a time. I'm not sure. I didn't study him enough, but I think so.'
'It's October. Rather cold for a man to live like a fish.'
'He's indifferent to discomfort. It would have to freeze before he would notice.'
Somewhere I went too far. His look is hardened, incredulous. 'I can set a man to watch your house,' he offers.
'That would be useless,' I say, rising to take my leave. 'I would simply have yet another death on my conscience.'

You need to come up with a better plan.

I rise to take my leave. 'You cannot help me,' I say.
He nods. 'I don't think I can. I'm sorry, Frankenstein.'
What slip have I made that makes him think me mad? It must be an excess of vehemence, or perhaps something in the eyes. Men who went up Olympus would be driven from their home villages, pelted with stones, cast out. Truth and madness have the same look.
Despite the outcome of the meeting, I emerge into the street with freshened spirits for what is to come. It feels as if the last chains have been cast away. Before it was brute against civilized man. Now I understand that I am an outcast too. There is nothing left that can stop me from destroying him.

Then you'd better devise a plan of action.

As long as I remain in one place, my enemy controls the circumstances of our struggle. He can dictate the moment and place of his attacks, and as I told the magistrate he could pick from a dozen hiding places inaccessible to me.
So I consider his disadvantages. I take a pen and list them. He may be reluctant to kill me, because I am the only being to whom he has any attachment in the worldI am the only one who knows how to create more like him. His deformity creates two problems. First, it means that he must forage for or steal his food. Even though he needs little sustenance, that costs him time and effort. Second, he must find it hard to disguise his presence among men, making it hard to travel freely during the day.
He is physically robust, but he cannot turn to a physician for treatment if he is injured, as illustrated by his account of being shot by the woodsman. And injury becomes more likely when he is forced to travel, to risk discovery, and to accommodate himself to different climates and terrains.
Therefore I conclude that by harrying him from place to place, I can deprive him of the best of his resources, and so gain the upper hand.

xoptx And if he decides to stand and fight?

xoptx Then you may be leaving your homeland forever.

I entertain no delusion as to the likely outcome of any struggle. But if I am surprised - if I were merely to lie in my bed waiting for the monster to appear beside me in the night, then my life will surely be lost to no avail. My scheme now should ensure that the final encounter will be on a battlefield of my choosing, in which case I may be able to bring about our mutual destruction. I hardly need to tell you I have no greater hopes than that.

Then it is time to set out.

Before I leave, knowing that I am unlikely ever to return here, there is something I must do. I am at the cemetery where Elizabeth, my father and my brother repose. It is late afternoon. The red and yellow leaves lie in deep rustling drifts and a few gritty specks of snow hang in the air, making it seem as though reality's canvas is beginning to crack.
By previous arrangement, the sexton has left the mausoleum gate unlocked for me. Inside is echoing silence. A few leaves have been blown inside on the white marble where generations of my family trod, their names now listed on the walls like so many books filed in a library never again to be read.
Without intending to, I find myself kneeling before the recess where they were lately laid to rest. A few skeletal flowers protrude from a vase - unreplenished in the weeks I spent sunk in melancholy. There should be a ritual, something to mark this final threshold I'm about to cross. I bow my head to the floor. The stone is cold on my lips.
'By the sacred earth on which I kneel, by the shades that wander near me, by the deep and eternal grief that I feel, I swear.' The words come effortlessly, without requiring thought, as though I'm reciting a formula that I've always known. 'And by thee, O Night, and by the spirits that preside over thee, I swear to pursue the demon who caused this misery until he or I shall perish in mortal conflict. For this purpose I will preserve my life. To execute this dear revenge I will again behold the sun and tread the earth, which otherwise should vanish from my eyes forever. And I call on you spirits of the dead, and on you wandering ministers of vengeance, to aid me in my work. Let the cursed and hellish monster drink deep of agony. Let him feel the despair that now torments me.'

xoptx Do you speak in anger?

xoptx Or would you say you are coldly determined?

I begin my vow with solemnity, and an awe that almost assures me that the shades of my murdered friends hear and approve, but the furies possess me as I conclude. Rage chokes my final words into an inchoate howl.
Assuredly. I have long passed the stage of futile raging. In speaking this vow, I measure out each millilitre of bile as in a burette. My hatred for my foe has become a spear of ice that will impale us both.
I've been here longer than I intended. Outside, the sun has set and the shadows have rushed in among the stones. The outlines of the tombs against the dimming sky resemble a sunken ruin.
As I look, the gate swings shut. I watch, I don't try to stop it. A heavy cloaked figure is there, silhouetted against the last of the light. He slips the chain through the bars of the gate and I hear the snap of the padlock. Yellow eyes stare from that face that is as devoid of expression as a mask.
'Do you come here to remember the days of darkness, Frankenstein?'
'Vile insect. Tattered thing. Release me and I shall put an end to you.'
'And that is why you have not put an end to yourself. I heard your vow.' He laughs. 'You did not, in former days, believe in goblins and spirits.'
'I believe in vengeance, monster - that only. If you heard me speak just now to those, your victims, who lie here, that is because I am dead too, but cannot make the journey until I have set right the atrocity I committed those years ago.'
'The crime of giving me life?'

xoptx 'Yes.'

xoptx 'Not that only.'

'So you are like a man who finds a savage lion in a cage and throws the door open for its escape?'
'Precisely so. And all the lives it takes are my fault.'
'You would not blame the lion.'
'It's in a lion's nature to kill,' I say before I realize he has trapped me twice over, with words as well as bars.
'I am hated for doing monstrous things. Why? I was created a monster, was I not? You created me thus.'
'I created a man. You've made yourself a monster.'
'I think I have acted out your secret desires, Frankenstein. Which makes you the monster pretending to be a man.'
With a harsh laugh, he turns and lopes swiftly away through the gathering dusk. Locked inside the vault, I can only put my hands to the bars and watch him go.

xoptx Call for help.

xoptx Someone will come to let you out at dawn.

'No, it was much more, wasn't it? The act of creation cannot be evil. Your crime was in spurning what you had made, casting me out alone into the world without hope or knowledge.'
'I don't deny it. But I have been punished merely for a mistake - the oversight of callow youth.'
'If you think your punishment unjust, Frankenstein, how much more is mine. Once I had dreams of virtue and happiness. Once I hoped to meet with others who, pardoning my outward deformity, would love me for the excellent qualities that I was capable of bringing forth. I was nourished with high thoughts of honour and devotion. But now vice has degraded me beneath the meanest animal. No crime, no mischief, no malignity, no misery, can be found comparable to mine. When I call over the frightful catalogue of my deeds, I cannot believe that I am he whose thoughts were once filled with sublime and transcendent visions of the beauty and the majesty of goodness. But it is so - the fallen angel becomes a malignant devil. Yet even Satan had friends and associates in his desolation. I am alone, I am content to suffer alone, and when I die I am well satisfied to be remembered as a monster.'

xoptx Why indulge him by listening to this?

xoptx He need not have chosen to be a monster.

'Enough. Unless you mean to kill me now, devil, I suggest you flee. I intend to pursue you to the end of the earth and, hear this: I will destroy what I so unwisely created.'
That catches his attention. I see the gleam of his yellow eyes in the twilight as he studies me. 'You have not learned wisdom, Frankenstein, or you would stay in there among your ancestors. If you emerge, it is into my world.'
He turns and lopes away, despite his lopsided gait, with more than mortal speed. I can only put my hands to the bars and watch the object of my hatred flee from sight.

xoptx Call for help.

xoptx Someone will come to let you out at dawn.

'I made you with free will. If you are a monster, it's because you decided to be one.'
There is a grating of metal on stone as he tenses his grip on the gate. I am conscious that he could tear it from its hinges as I might break a twig from a tree. When he speaks, there is the extra edge of fury in his guttural voice.
'I tried to be a man! When I first sought the sympathy of my fellow man, it was because I wished to share the love of virtue, the feelings of happiness and affection with which my whole being overflowed. But now virtue has become to me a shadow, and happiness and affection are turned into bitter and loathing despair, in what should I seek for sympathy?
'I told you my story, but I could not sum up the hours and months of misery I endured. I desired love and fellowship, and I was spurned. Was there no injustice in this? Am I to be thought the only monster, when all humankind sinned against me? Why don't you hate Felix, whom I helped in his adversity but who drove me away? Why not blame the rustic who rewarded me with a bullet for saving his lover's life? No, you do not consider those virtuous and immaculate beings to be in any way culpable. It is I, miserable and abandoned, who am an abortion to be spurned and kicked at and trampled on.''I have ceased to think of you as a sentient being of any kind. To me you are like a fire, out of control, that must be extinguished.'It is too late to speak to me of loss of innocence, demon. You have forfeited that right and, because the blood on your hands is also on mine, I have devoted my existence to your destruction.'
He pauses for a long time, seeming to reflect deeply, before saying. 'Yes, it's fitting. To the end, then. To our last breaths.'
He turns and lopes swiftly away through the gathering dusk. Locked inside the vault, I can only put my hands to the bars and watch the object of my hatred flee from sight.

xoptx Call for help.

xoptx Someone will come to let you out at dawn.

I am answered through the stillness of the late afternoon by a loud and fiendish laugh. It rings heavily on my ears, the galleries of the surrounding charnels re-echo it, and I feel as if all hell surrounds me with mockery. Surely in this moment I should be possessed by frenzy, and destroy my miserable existence - except my vow was heard, and so I am reserved for vengeance.
The laughter dies away. I look up at the doorway but see only the grey, exsanguined sky and the deep tide of shadow that has crept among the tombs. Then a well-known and abhorred voice, distorted to an echo by the walls of the vault so that it apparently emanates from close to my ear, addresses me in an audible whisper: 'I am satisfied, miserable wretch. You have determined to live, and I am satisfied.'
I am on my feet and darting towards the door, but he is faster. A heavy cloaked shape tips into view, as big and unstoppable as a boulder, and slams the gate before I can reach it. I hear the snap of the padlock.
'Devil!'
I catch a glimpse of his yellow eyes in the twilight. 'If you had wisdom, Frankenstein, you would stay there and rot among your ancestors. But instead you will pursue me, because you do not realize that you are already dead.'
He turns and lopes away, despite his lopsided gait, with more than mortal speed. I can only put my hands to the bars and watch the object of my hatred flee from sight.

xoptx Call for help.

xoptx Someone will come to let you out at dawn.

I don't have to shout for long. The sexton's assistant, an old man who digs and tends the common graves, comes shuffling along the gallery outside. He has no lantern. The interior of the vault is in complete darkness now. He must only be able to see me as a dim outline.
'The wind blew the gate shut,' I tell him, mainly to give him the reassurance of hearing my voice.
'And locked it, sir?' He's doubtful, but in a moment I hear him fumbling with the keys.
'Did you see anyone else?' I ask as he opens the gate for me.
'No one comes here at this hour, sir. No living soul.'
If AdomIf he lurks nearby and were to hear me calling, he might take it as a sign of weakness. I belong among the dead. I am their emissary of vengeance to this world, but I have one foot already in the next.
The knights of old used to begin their lives of chivalry with a vigil before the altar. My own purpose is grimmer, but the rite will serve. I kneel not before God, but before the angry host of ancestors whose name has been stained with innocent blood. In the dark of the night I hear them whispering to me. I know what I must do.
Before dawn I hear the sweep of a broom among the dry dead leaves that have drifted in along the charnel gallery. The sexton's assistant gives a start when he sees me, then hurries to fetch the keys.
The morning air off the mountains holds that deeper cold that says winter is coming. I stand in the pale dawn, breathing the sharp air, remade by my vigil for the long ordeal that lies ahead.

END OF CHAPTER ONE


CHAPTER TWO
CHAPTER TWO
Encompassed by Peril

I pursue him for months. Guided by a slight clue, I first follow the windings of the Rhône, then a trail that takes me through northern Italy. I seek him along the fog-shrouded canals of Venice as autumn turns to winter, and down the Adriatic, sailing into the slate-coloured Ionian Sea past the cliffs where Penelope watched for her husband to return. I bow my head in bitterness, knowing there is no hearth swept for my homecoming. At the end of this chase, I will leave my bones in a strange land.
In Athens I find evidence that my quarry has been there just before me: a packet left with the banker who is to release me funds. It's a scrap of butcher's paper, clumsily tied with string. The banker tells me it was left in the doorway of his office after business hours. The handwriting, I notice, is not unlike my own. Of course, he has my notebook to copy from.

xoptx What's in the package?

xoptx Don't play his games. Destroy it unopened.

A lady's white glove with a rusty red stain on the cuff. He snapped Elizabeth's neck, so I doubt it's her blood. The glove, though - I didn't go through her belongings after the murder. It could be hers.
'I'm sorry, sir,' says the banker, backing out of his own office. 'I'll give you some privacy.'
I'm weeping. I curse my own weakness.I hadn't noticed. The thought of him having taken this and carrying it with him across Europe seems as gross a violation as any of his crimes so far.
You're right. There is no advantage to be gained. Any message or memento he has left for me can only be intended to mislead or to undermine my resolve. To the banker's astonishment, I drop the parcel into the basket beside his desk.
'It is a practical joke by a friend,' I explain. 'Now, sir, if I may have my money...'No, I must see what it is. I tear open the wrapping.
As I leave the banker's offices, it occurs to me that we are in a bustling city. The busiest city that my search has so far brought me to. It cannot have been easy for the monster to find a hiding place here. Yet he must have done - close enough to the city, at any rate, to be able to deliver the package by dead of night.

xoptx Perhaps a cemetery?

xoptx A hospital?

xoptx The Parthenon?

xoptx It's pointless to look. He will have moved on.

I waste several days visiting the graveyards of Athens. I find nothing to suggest the monster was here. In one patch of ground behind a small church there is a headstone marked LAVENZA. It is overgrown with weeds like the rest, but there are a few fresh flowers on the grave. However, it would be a mistake to read anything into that.

Then it's time to move on.

'It's a steep climb,' a would-be dragoman tells me, offering to carry my pack. His speech is a mixture of French and English, a necessary hedging of bets for one in his profession.
He must be surprised to see me ascend the steps so nimbly. 'We Swiss find going uphill easier than a level road,' I call back.
I don't know what I expect to find. The old ruins are dingier than I expected, a sad sight under the grey winter sky, though the marble reliefs of horses and heroes still convey a patina of awe. For some reason I'm reminded of my father, though I don't believe he knew Pericles from a periwinkle.
What clue would my foe leave me here? A message under a rock? There are hundreds, and nothing to stop sightseers taking them away in their pockets. I even see a plump, smug-faced young Englishman walking around with several Ottoman officials, who seem quite happy to stand back while he removes a few pieces of stone with a chisel.

The monster isn't here. It's time to move on.

I call on some teaching hospitals where they might store cadavers for dissection. It is illegal under the Ottoman rule, of course, but physicians have a way of getting around that in all parts of the world. Distributing a little money brings me to a mortuary attendant who is still shaken by the experience of finding one of his bodies walking around in the middle of the night.
A clever ploy on Adommy enemy's part, I suppose - hiding in plain sight. But although it boosts my morale to have discovered one of his stratagems, the practical value is nil. He is long gone.

xoptx Perhaps he had another reason for hiding here?

xoptx You're wasting time here.

What, that he feels some affinity for severed parts and anatomical slabs? The brain, you may recall, was assembled using embryonic tissue. The primordial memories buried there will be of my attic lab in Paris. They cannot go further back than that.

You could be onto something. I seek out one of the professors. Lacking a common modern tongue, we fall back on Latin. He tells me that several volumes were stolen from the hospital's library.
'When?'
'Very recently. Three days ago.'
That was around the time the mortuary attendant saw a flayed cadaver walking past his door. 'And the books that were taken?'
'Recent works on surgery, French and English for the most part. I was going to have them translated.'
Interesting. Why would Adommy monster want to study such things? With a sense of foreboding, I return to the hotel to plan the next stage of my journey.

I track him to Istanbul, where some beggars are talking of a huge cloaked figure haunting the docks at night. Scouring the waterfront on both sides of the city, I have found nothing the past few nights, but the sightings continue, so I believe he is still here.
Yes, see there on the hawser of that ship? Just keep walking. There, hanging halfway up the cable, a bundle like a fat spider wound in its web. That's him. Do you think he saw me? Tomorrow I shall take passage on that ship, wherever it is bound.

Each day, as we sail east, I make a thorough search of the ship. Where can he hide himself? I find no trace, but food is stolen from the kitchen - more than rats would take. He is aboard and yet somehow he evades me when we dock at Sevastopol.
Into the wilds of Tartary and Russia, then. He stays ahead of me, but he cannot shake me off. I am learning how to follow his tracks. And he has the disadvantage of alienness - sometimes the peasants, scared by a horrid apparition, tell me where he's gone. But he cannot stay away from habitation altogether, for I am driving him north where it is harder to find food in the wild. The snows descend, and I see the print of his huge step on the white plain. Look at my footprint beside it. Look at that. Yet the giant runs, and I pursue.

xoptx You're not chasing him. He's luring you.

xoptx You'll struggle to survive in the north too.

It's not so straightforward as you suppose. The pattern you have perceived has another explanation, you see - namely that we are both guided by a spirit, who moves us like chess pieces towards the inevitable end. Oh, but I am so weary. The weariness has got into my bones and it gnaws at them. When will my guiding spirit see fit to conduct me to the demon, so that I can destroy him and take the rest I so desire?
Or, as you see it, must I die and he yet live? If I do, swear to me that he shall not escape, that you will satisfy my vengeance. Perhaps I should not ask you to undertake my crusade. No, I'm not so selfish as that. Forget I spoke. I have no grounds in any case for thinking you'd keep a promise made to me.Yet, when I am dead, if he should appear, if the ministers of vengeance should conduct him to you, swear that he shall not live - swear that he shall not triumph over my accumulated woes, and live to make another as wretched as I am. Beware, he is eloquent and persuasive, and once his words even had power over my heart. Don't trust him. Don't listen to him. His soul is as hellish as his form, full of treachery and fiendish malice. Harden your heart and stop your ears if he tries to coerce you. Think of William, Justine, Henri, Elizabeth, my father, and of the wretched Victor, and thrust your sword into his heart. I will hover near and direct the steel aright.

xoptx It's unlucky to talk of failure.

xoptx Be resolute. You will strike that blow yourself.

Cold, hunger, and fatigue are the least of my pains. I am cursed by some devil, and carry about with me a private and eternal hell. Although - do you know, I feel that a spirit of good follows and directs my steps. How else have I stayed on the fiend's trail? There have been a score of times I thought I'd lost him, and then a clue was revealed to me as if by providence.
And it's not just the help of strangers - the sightings of a monstrous figure, the reports of stolen food and clothes. The spirit helps me in the wild too. Take yesterday. I had been unable to sleep, and after stalking a deer for miles through the frosty woods, my gun misfired and it got away from me. I could have sunk to the ground there and expired of fatigue and hunger. But I found a rock on which a repast was laid out for me. Look, I wrapped up some of it and I'll make my supper of it shortly. It's just plain fare, as you can see. The sort of coarse meal the peasants of this country eat. But what manna to a starving traveller!
Don't concern yourself. The spirit will not let me expire before I have had my chance for retribution. Why, just yesterday I had been stalking a deer for miles through the woods, and my gun misfired and it got away from me. I was in despair. But then I found a rock on which a repast was laid out for me. Look, I wrapped up some of it and I'll make my supper of it shortly. It's just plain fare, as you can see. The sort of coarse meal the peasants of this country eat. A banquet, though, could not be more welcome.
Remember the vow I took in the mausoleum? I mustn't doubt that this food was set there by the spirits that I invoked then to aid me. Often, when all there is around is this sere wilderness, and the heavens cloudless, and I am parched by thirst, a slight cloud bedims the sky, sheds the few drops I need to revive me, and vanishes.
Why are you looking at me like that? This food is sent by the spirits, I tell you. You believe that, don't you?

xoptx Yes.

xoptx No.

No. He left it. I won't eat it. He does it to mock me, but he underestimates his enemy. And he has made a grave mistake if he thinks his condescension will weaken my determination to see him dead. There - what's left can bait my snares and I may trap a dozen animals with the scanty fare he intended to sustain me for a single meal.

Good. Then I'll eat it. When I say the spirits left it, I'm not mad. I mean that the spirit must have entered the body of a peasant and induced him to prepare the meal and leave it carefully packed away where I would find it. Destiny can work through men, I think - don't you? I didn't intend to imply that the good spirit actually found these nuts and bread crusts itself. That would be insane.You don't believe that. You're saying so just to humour me. You don't think I'll eat it if I think he left it. Nor will I. There - let the wild animals have it. I have no appetite if you can't muster just a little faith. You sorely disappoint me. I thought, in the tomb, that you felt their presence too.

I follow the courses of rivers when I can, so as to have fresh water and fish to hand when I cannot find villages to trade at. I brought money with me, and gain the friendship of the villagers by distributing either that or game that I have snared. In return I can usually find shelter and a hearth to sleep at, in the early stages of our chase at least. But those settlements that lie along the rivers are the very reason that the demon I pursue generally avoids them. His habitat is the wild, so it must be mine too.
As we penetrate further north, human habitation becomes sparse. Now I seldom see another soul from one day to the next, and must subsist on the wild animals that cross my path. I have little time for hunting, though. The monster needs less food, you see, and I cannot allow the weakness of my appetites and mortal frailty to delay me. Today my head aches with hunger, and each mile feels like a league, but I must press on.

xoptx Why is he heading north? What's the reason?

xoptx You need to gather some food.

xoptx At least get some water from that stream.

You wonder as to the feelings of my quarry? How am I to know? He leaves me signs - sometimes taunting messages cut into stone or wood, like this one carved in the bark of a tree. It hasn't started to heal over. Not more than two days old, I'd say.
Yes, I can go without food but not without water. And one of these smooth river-pebbles will do to suck on. That's how the legionaries staved off hunger, you know, marching up and down their dead straight roads. Wait - wait, look! This footprint in the mud, it's his. Consistency sticky but not fully dry - that's a day, maybe two, in these conditions. So he came down to the stream here for water. What else? Ah, here on this tree he's carved some words. Can you make them out?
'My reign is not yet over.' That's definitely what he's written. It's unfortunate that he was exposed to Milton at an impressionable age.
Ah, and an arrow pointing to another inscription on this tree: 'You live, and my power is complete.' And yet another arrow, pointing I suppose to that next tree there. Yes, look - the bark has definitely been cut away.
He could have scattered these lurid little epigrams through the whole forest. I would do better to spend a few hours in hunting than follow this paper chase of messages.

xoptx No, read the whole message. It might be important.

xoptx You're right, your need for food is greater.

Important? In what way could it be important? He has nothing to tell me. A confession of his crimes? Those I know. His ultimate destination? Wherever I drive him to - the North Pole, if need be.
No, these messages are left only to mock me. The scoffing devil. Again I vow vengeance. Again do I promise thee, miserable fiend, a future of torture and death. I'll never stop searching until he or I perish - and then with what ecstasy shall I join my Elizabeth and those other loved ones who even now prepare for me the reward of this detestable pilgrimage.
Here he has written, 'Follow me. I seek the everlasting ices of the north...' and it continues on this tree, '... where you will feel the misery of cold and frost to which I am impassive.'
His purpose in leaving this is to sap my morale. It won't work. I know he is stronger, but I am cleverer and more determined. Are you sure the message is worth deciphering? Well, there's another part of it here: 'Come on, enemy. We have yet to wrestle for our lives.'
Wrestle nothing, I have a brace of pistols, a musket and a nine-inch knife to even up our fight. Let him come to wrestle me. I'll blow his kneecaps off first. Another part of it here: 'Many hard and miserable hours must you endure until that period shall arrive.'
This is foolish! These messages could stretch to the Arctic Circle, and his intent is only to mock me.

xoptx No, keep following them.

xoptx You're right, hunt for food instead.

Now this is interesting. 'If you follow not too tardily...'
Quickly, to the next tree. Ah. Look at this. You were right to make me read it all:
'... You will find near this place a dead hare. Eat and be refreshed.'
And here it is, in the hollow of the next tree, cut up and wind-dried and neatly parcelled in leaves stitched together with pine needles. Quite a little picnic. He's nicely solicitous of my welfare, the fiend I created.
Two hours' searching and all I can find are these mushrooms. They are Boletus edulis - ceps, in common parlance. Perfectly safe. No gills, that's how you can tell them from webcaps, which would kill even the monster in hours... Now there's a notion that gives me pause for thought. I must pray he doesn't die from eating poison mushrooms. That would be no revenge.
It's not much of a meal. No matter. It is enough to sustain me for another day. This and hate are all I need.

As I continue north, the snows thicken and the cold grows harder to bear. At least I now have a sledge and dogs, bought with the last of my mother's jewels, so I am making better ground. Days can go by without me seeing anyone. The peasants are shut up in their huts, firewood piled deep against the walls, roofs humped with snow. Few enough animals to be seen now, even though it must be spring in warmer climes. I still need to hunt, though - I can ignore my own hunger, but not the dogs'. Fish would be easiest, but the ice on the rivers is too thick.
Do you see that on the horizon? Like a great gleaming plain? It's the ocean. It must be frozen solid - look, you can only tell it from the land by its rugged desolation. There is a desert harsher than any of Arabia, my friend. An empty quarter indeed. And fathoms of water churning under that trackless ice. Out on that and you're lost to history. I can't imagine returning.

xoptx It's a good sign, that frozen sea.

xoptx You'll leave your bones out there.

xoptx Do you think you're gaining on the monster?

It is.
I'll tell you why. In the harsh country we've come through, where food is scarce, Adomthe monster's need for less sustenance has helped him. But out there, there's nothing. I'll have the supplies I can pack on the sledge. If the worst comes to the worst, I can feed one dog to the others. But Adommy foe will find no game, no vegetation. Nothing to eat. I'll harry him until he withers, drive him till his frame is blackened by the scalding cold. That's why the ocean is a good sign. The Greeks wept for joy when they beheld the Mediterranean from the hills of Asia, and hailed with rapture the boundary of their toils. I do not weep, but I will kneel down here and, with a full heart, thank my guiding spirit for bringing me to the battleground on which I can destroy my enemy.

I fear you may be right. I must now commence a destructive and almost endless journey across the mountainous ice - in cold that few of the natives of this land can long endure, and which I, used to a genial climate, cannot hope to survive.
But, no. I won't allow myself to think this way. The idea that the fiend should be triumphant - it makes my blood boil, it makes my pulse hammer in my chest. The heat of righteous anger must sustain me. And I have my constant companions, the spirits of the dead, hovering round and urging me onwards. I'll endure, whatever you may say.

Quite the contrary.
I believe so. He might have a sledge himself, but his size counts against him. He'd need more dogs to pull it, and that's more mouths to feed. I am sure that, just as I was losing ground before, I'm gaining on him now. I don't believe he can be more than one day's journey ahead. Perhaps I can even intercept him before he gets to the beach. A musket ball between the shoulder blades to start. Then I'll take my time about the rest.

Keeping the frozen ocean ever ahead, in two days I reach a hamlet on the shore. The inhabitants must have heard my dogs but remain stubbornly indoors. I crunch through the snow and knock on the door of the largest cabin, hoping it is a store where I can buy fuel and provisions. I catch a face at the window. After a minute the door opens a crack, releasing a waft of warm steamy air.
I've learned a few words. 'Food. Also wood. Oil. A bed tonight.'
It's getting late, though you would hardly know it from the eternally pale sky. Better to rest here and go on tomorrow.
The door opens wider and an old woman tugs me inside, jabbering angrily about - I assume - the loss of heat. The first thing I notice is the stink of pipe tobacco. My eyes adjust to the gloom and I see several men seated around a spitting, cracking pine fire. They turn away when they see me looking. The woman points to a stool and goes into the next room. The smell of cooking gives me some hope that she has understood.

xoptx These rustics dislike strangers. Best keep your distance.

xoptx Talk to them. They may have seen the monster.

Have no fear on that score; I have learned that it's wiser to stay aloof, keep silent, and show them as little money as possible. I have previously set aside a few coins, which I make a play of handing over with great reluctance when the old woman comes back with a plate of black bread and beetroot stew. Actually, I hardly need to pretend, as I'm down to the bottom of my purse and my fingers are so stiff with cold that it's hard to count them out anyway. I have enough for provisions, and I'll need to exchange my land sledge for one better suited to the frozen ocean. Other than that, I have no more use for money now.
It's a labour to eat the stew. I'm so weary. But I must - it could be the last good meal I have for a while, and I need the energy. The fire is so hot. The smoke makes my eyes raw.
The old woman is standing in front of me. She's asking me a question. What's that in her hand? A folded piece of paper. My first thought is that it must have dropped from my pocket, as the writing looks like my hand. But it's his. He's been here, and he left me a letter.
I nod and take it from her, aware of the hostile looks this earns me from the men around the hearth. There's fear as well as anger in their muttering. No doubt the fiend terrorized their village, took what he wanted, and went on across the frozen sea. I want to tell them I'm not like that, I'm not with him. But I don't speak their language, and in any case it wouldn't be true.

xoptx Are you going to read the letter?

xoptx You should get some rest.

I have learned that it's wiser to stay aloof, keep silent, and show them as little money as possible. I have previously set aside a few coins, which I make a play of handing over with great reluctance when the old woman comes back with a plate of black bread and beetroot stew. Actually, I hardly need to pretend, as I'm down to the bottom of my purse and my fingers are so stiff with cold that it's hard to count them out anyway. I have enough for provisions, and I'll need to exchange my land sledge for one better suited to the frozen ocean. Other than that, I have no more use for money now.
It's a labour to eat the stew. I'm so weary. But I must - it could be the last good meal I have for a while, and I need the energy. The fire is so hot. The smoke makes my eyes raw.
The old woman is standing in front of me. She's asking me a question. What's that in her hand? A folded piece of paper. My first thought is that it must have dropped from my pocket, as the writing looks like my hand. But it's his. He's been here, and he left me a letter.
I nod and take it from her, aware of the hostile looks this earns me from the men around the hearth. There's fear as well as anger in their muttering. No doubt the fiend terrorized their village, took what he wanted, and went on across the frozen sea. I want to tell them I'm not like that, I'm not with him. But I don't speak their language, and in any case it wouldn't be true.

xoptx Are you going to read the letter?

xoptx You should get some rest.

One of the men speaks a little French, so conversation is not impossible. I am down to my last coins, but buying them a bottle of vodka from the old woman's pantry proves worthwhile, as they are soon telling me of the monster who lately terrorized their village.
'A giant,' says the man who speaks French. 'And disfigured, as if his face had been flayed.'
'Armed?'
'Oh yes, armed. Many pistols. He shot Arto's best dog.'
Hearing his name, one of the other men nods vigorously and starts jabbering interjections in his own tongue.
'He and his wife had to run for it,' says my translator. 'The monster ransacked his place. Took his sledge, his dogs, most of his stores. We thank God he didn't stay long. Tore the shutters off Arto's hut before he left, though. The wind goes right through. That's why he's in here.'
'Where did he go?'
'Out onto the ice. No land the way he was going, not for a thousand miles, I reckon. He'll freeze, most likely fall in the water when the fissures open up. That's not solid land. Only looks it. It'll break under a man and icebergs big as a hillside will come up as fast as – ' He sweeps his hand beside the fire, evoking the daunting image of cliffs of ice rearing up as quick as flames.
'When was this?'
'Less than a day.'
The old woman comes over and says something. My translator looks more keenly at me and what little trace of a smile he wore is replaced by a suspicious scowl.
'That's right, he left something.' Arto takes a crumpled letter from his pocket. 'Is that you?'
He holds it up. Scrawled across the front in the bold, educated hand that is so like my own is the single word FRANKENSTEIN.
'That's me.' I have to tug the letter from his fingers. I order more vodka, but they are all scowling at me now.

xoptx You'd better read it.

xoptx It will only be another of his taunting messages.

xoptx You should set their minds at rest first.

Clad in thick furs to make his frame seem even more colossal, guns in each hand, with dogs going mad behind him - he must have seemed truly to be a devil climbed from the pit. Of course they were terrified, and now they want a safer target for their aggression.
'He's a criminal,' I tell the one who speaks French. 'He murdered many people. I'm here to bring him to justice.'
The men converse about this for a while. 'You are a policeman? You are here to arrest him?' asks my translator.
'Not that kind of justice.''Tell them I have come to kill him.'
He translates this. They don't laugh - they are still too shaken for that. But I am treated to narrow surly looks of disbelief.
'I created him. I can kill him. Tell them that if you want to. I don't care.'

xoptx Are you going to read the letter?

xoptx You need to get some rest before tomorrow.

'Prepare!' he writes. 'Your travail is finally about to begin. Wrap yourself in furs and provide food, for now we journey to a place where your sufferings will satisfy my everlasting hatred.'
These empty boastful messages, composed in such a pompous style. He's wasted the life I gave him. Startling the other patrons of the tavern, I screw up the note and lob it past them into the fire.

You don't look well. Why not get some rest?

The stuffy, noxious air of the cabin affects me badly after the dry chill outside. My head sinks onto my arms and waves of feverish weakness shake my body. I have pushed myself beyond endurance these last weeks - but I cannot falter now, not when I am so close to my quarry.
The old woman shakes me and leads the way to a box room with a cot where I can lie down. Young goats peer in through beams that separate this from the next room. A thin icy draft makes its way in under the rafters, reviving me slightly. Thanking the old woman, I pull the furs around me and wait for sleep to come.
How hateful life has become to me. To endure each day I have to force the bitter memories away, and build a wall that stops me thinking of those I have lost. It's only in sleep that I can recall what it is to be happy. Oh, why can't I banish this turmoil of thoughts? Let me sink into sleep. Where are the dreams I need that will give me a respite from the darkness?

Rest while you can. You'll need your strength.

A soft hand brushes my cheek. Elizabeth is here. I smell her, like blossom and violets. I can hear her gentle breathing as she bends to whisper in my ear.
'Why revenge, darling Victor? Vengeance has power to poison life. I look down on you, living in a maze of darkness you have created for yourself, and I ask if you cannot turn to remorse rather than revenge? Nothing is beyond forgiveness.'
I try to ask her how she can speak of forgiveness, but it is as though my lips are stitched shut. My breath swells within me but I cannot find my voice.
'Enmity feeds on hatred, my love, and it will consume both you and the one you follow.' She's drawing away. Her voice is getting fainter. I want to open my eyes and gaze on her, but they too are sealed.
'Elizabeth!' I manage to blurt out. But she has gone and I sink ever deeper into a dreamless, fevered sleep.

The spirits that watch over me provide these brief interludes of happiness. Without them I would give in to despair. All that sustains me is this promise of sleep, when my friends return to my side and I am again with my wife in our beloved country.
There! The silver tones of Elizabeth's voice. Henri's gay laughter. They are coming. Often, weary to the bone, I persuade myself that the day's journeying is a dream, and sleep is reality. Here I can forget all heartache in the arms of my dearest friends.
A sense of peace enfolds me. The vengeance that burns within me dies away. 'If only you could forgive.' That's Elizabeth's voice.
I tell her I must bring an end to the demon, but not out of hate. I am the instrument of the spirits now. What I must undertake is a task enjoined by heaven, the mechanical impulse of some power of which I am not conscious. And dimly I consider that this may be true of every mortal action, and that free will is just a succouring illusion like these trysts in sleep, but by then the rational mind of Frankenstein is dissolved away like a fog and I am left in the limpid clarity of my dreams.

I can hear my father's voice. William is with him, and - yes - there are Elizabeth's silver tones. Henri too. All of my friends, gather me to your arms, give me strength for what is to come.
They emerge out of a fog. The fog of reality is lifting as dreams come roiling up, and the light that hangs around them is dazzling. I am familiar with that light. It is the celestial exhalation of the spirits that guide me.
But why is Elizabeth's face so contorted with anguish? Come closer, dear cousin. Speak to me.
'Destroy the monster, Victor. You must sunder him in pieces. Burn him. Cut out his eyes, torture him, make him pay for the suffering he inflicted on us.'
'Pour acid in his veins,' says my father.
'Let his screams echo across the plain,' says Henri. 'Smash in his skull. Let him feel what it is to have life brutally taken away.'
'Give him a slow death,' says little William. 'Let him crawl in agony all the way to the gates of hell.'
And all of them, as they urge me thus, are smiling like cherubs before the throne of God.

END OF CHAPTER TWO


CHAPTER THREE
CHAPTER THREE
Lost in Darkness

It's good to have Henri beside me on the sledge. The rigorous happiness of unbeing has stamped his face with a permanent smile, and his brow is smooth of care. We'd all want to be dead, seeing how well he looks on it.
I think I've lost track of the days. The last human settlement is far behind me now. Immense and rugged mountains of ice often bar my passage. For a while the weather became warmer, opening tracts of melted ice. On the black water rolled great blocks of ice, which looked white but were also black, like liquorice dipped in sherbet, and they clinked and clashed together, producing a continuous noise in which, faintly, I could make out an orchestra tuning up far below the surface.
But now the frost has closed in again, and the sea has frozen up, making my path straighter and more secure.

xoptx You say that Henri is with you?

xoptx Has there been any sign of the monster?

Well, you wouldn't think so, but I catch him out of the corner of my eye, holding onto the side of the sledge. Listen, and you might hear his laughter over the huskies' howl.
Is there anything you want to ask him?

xoptx Yes.

xoptx What about the monster?

He hasn't got long here. The dead are busier than the living, though you wouldn't think it. I'll ask him for you if you're nervous of talking to him yourself.

xoptx What is it like to be dead?

xoptx Does he know where you'll find your foe?

xoptx No, never mind.

It's not the seat of desolation you might suppose, he says - a region of beauty and delight, rather. There the sun is forever visible, its broad disk just skirting the horizon, and diffusing a perpetual splendour. There, snow and frost like this are banished. To die is to sail over a calm sea to a land surpassing in wonders any territory of the habitable globe. The heavenly bodies hang close like Christmas baubles in those undiscovered solitudes. What may not be expected in a country of eternal light? I'll join you there, Henri, when this last labour is complete.

You must be close on the monster's trail.

Where things fold in, he says. Where the edge becomes the centre. The furthest limit and the origin are one, and that's where we'll meet. He can see it already because the afterlife is outside time.
You don't understand? Too cryptic? The dead have different ways of thinking from us. Henri is speaking mythematically, you see, that's how I can understand him.

Have you seen the monster's tracks?

No, no - I don't think so. I see your cynical eye. Don't say a word, Henri. Play dead, ha ha! Oh yes, you can look around, but you won't see any living thing except the dogs and me. Ghosts won't stay where there is disbelief.

Have you seen the monster yet?

I caught sight of my quarryhim a few days ago. I had toiled up the long slope of an ice mountain. Oh, it went on forever. One of the dogs fell and I had to get out and untie it - it could not go on. I reached the summit at last and viewed the expanse before me with anguish, when suddenly my eye caught a dark speck upon the dusky plain.
I lost a layer of skin getting out my telescope. The metal was ice cold and I had to take my gloves off. But then I found the distant speck and as it leapt into focus before my eyes I uttered a wild cry of ecstasy. It was a sledge, and standing within it a figure whose distorted proportions are well known to me. Warm tears filled my eyes. I hastily wiped them away that they might not intercept the view I had of the demon. Hope was a burning gush within me.
There was no time to lose, but after the ascent it was necessary to feed the dogs and give them an hour's rest. The time crawled by. I must have consulted my watch a hundred times, shaking it and listening to see if it still ran. He was still in sight, and I kept behind him. And I am still. At times a crag of ice hides him from view, and I always wait with bursting hope until I round it and can scan the horizon once more. You can't see him now, but he's there. The gap between us must be closing. Over this rise, or the next, and I'll catch sight of him again.

Then there's no time to lose.

Has it been hours, or days? My mind is dazed by trackless ice. The pinprick of the sun, fixed low in the shell of the firmament, has the effect of a kind of camera obscura reflecting an upside-down world: a turbulent, restless landscape beneath a placid sky of endless day. To eat, to rest - these are words that have lost their meaning. My choices have contracted to the unapproachable horizon, a vanishing point beyond which time dissolves and he and I will plunge into a mythopoeic terrain in which our struggle is like the seasons, and this chase could end and yet go on forever.
I am gaining on him, though, foot by foot. See there! He's - what? No more than a mile ahead! The torpor lifts. My pulse is racing now. Where's the musket?
And suddenly, dreadfully, a groaning noise from all around that I have waited for with abated fear. It is the thunder of the ground sea, the deep uterine roar beneath the pane of ice. What can I do? I can only press on, whipping the dogs, urging them to one last effort. Don't let it be too late, you spirits. The roar of the sea is swelling. Every moment it grows more ominous.
My one chance is to overtake Adomthe monster before calamity strikes. But I already know it is in vain. The wind is rising, sending blistering shards of ice skittering along the ground. It heaves like an earthquake, cracking across the whole width of the world with a tremendous and overwhelming sound. A gulf opens ahead through which the sea lashes up, violet-grey and menacing. I have to rein in the dogs or we'd be drowned. And ahead my foe drives off into the haze of sleet, abandoning me on a raft of ice in the midst of this tumultuous sea.

It's hopeless. He's gone.

Hard to stay awake, but no time seems to pass with the sun hovering always there on the horizon. My dogs are dying. I'm too weak to get food, fingers too numb. No blood at all above the top joint. I don't need to tell you what that means.
The ice floe on which we're drifting is melting in any case, so I expect to drown rather than starve. They say it's a pleasant death, like falling asleep. Though who alive can describe what the moment of either sleep or death is like?

xoptx Do you still see the ghosts of your loved ones?

xoptx Couldn't you swim to the pack ice?

No longer. The approach of death has quietened my fever, strangely. Or is it only that my senses are dulled and I cannot hear them now? I am lucid enough to ask the question, but answers have ceased to be important.

Is there nothing to be done?

The water would leech the strength out of me before I was halfway to firmer land. And then, waterlogged and without means to light a fire, I'd freeze to death in minutes. That's not the way I choose to die. Ah, but I had forgotten there's another choice...
Here's the pistol. I can't feel my fingers but they're still working. This is the best way. A bullet through the great brain of Frankenstein, who released such affliction on the world. My only consolation is that the breaking ice will also strand him. Even he, for all his strength, is a living man whom cold and starvation will finally overcome.

Wait!

What is that? A ship? I had no idea vessels came this far north.
'Hello! Help!'
They're too far off. They don't hear me.

xoptx Use the pistol.

xoptx Perhaps you can get nearer.

Of course! I discharge it in the air. And the musket. Even if they don't notice the sound above the continual creaking of ice, they must surely see the flashes and the plumes of gun smoke.
Yes. I see faces at the rail. They're coming over.
They'd never hear it over the constant cracking of the ice. But if I break off the side panel of the sledge I can use it to scull nearer. Have to be careful not to tip the ice floe over. I'm so tired. No strength left but I must get closer - not for the sake of my own life, but so that the fiend does not escape.
'Here! I'm here!' Look at me, damn you. Don't they see?
Yes! There are faces at the rail. I hear shouts. They're coming...
But how? Ah, I see what you mean. If I break off the side panel of the sledge I can use it to scull nearer. Have to be careful not to tip the ice floe over. I'm so tired. No strength left but I must get to that ship - not for the sake of my own life, but so that the fiend does not escape.
'Here! I'm here!' Look at me, damn you. Don't they see?
Yes! There are faces at the rail. I hear shouts. They're coming...
How would I do that? I have no means of making a sail. But I do have the pistol. I discharge it into the air. And the musket. Even if they don't notice the sound above the continual creaking of ice, they must see the flashes and the plumes of gun smoke.
Yes. I see faces at the rail. They're coming...
They are Russian, I think, but I am able to make myself understood to one or two who speak French. They are lowering ropes towards the fragment of ice on which I lie.
'Where are you bound?' I call up. 'I will not come aboard until I know that.'
'He is mad,' I hear one say in English. 'Captain! Here is a man who wants to perish on the open sea.'
They make way for a young fellow who must be their skipper. He leans over and addresses me in native English. 'Let us bring you up on deck, man. In God's name, I can practically see the ice melting from under you.'
He seems like a gentleman, although youthfully brusque. 'Before I agree,' I tell him, 'will you have the kindness, sir, to inform me whether you are sailing north? For that must be my destination.'
'We set out with that intention. Now, you men, go down the ropes and help him.'
I note his prevarication, and also the challenging glances he receives from the crew. My enemy is to the north. That's where I must travel. But it seems the captain can't make that promise. A couple of his men are looping ropes so they can hoist me up to the deck. Should I agree?

xoptx Of course you must go aboard.

xoptx Don't - you could lose any chance of revenge.

Reluctantly, feeling that my opportunity to overtake my adversary may be slipping away, I submit to being strapped into a harness and lifted up onto the deck.
I most certainly will if I die out here on the ice. Be assured, my friend, if there were any choice then I would tell them to leave me - but I am sick, starving, frostbitten, and even if the weather were to turn, and the sea to freeze again, how will I proceed now that my dogs are dying? No, I must submit to being strapped into a harness and lifted up onto the deck. This vessel is my only hope now.
One of the men who has come down from the deck leans anxiously over me. I can see from the look on his face that I must be in a bad way. The ice floe tilts under his weight. Urgently he holds up a loop of rope for me to ascend in.
'You come! You come!'
The current bumps the ice against the hull. Alarmed, the man catches hold of the rope and swings away, his feet just inches above the water. The others run along the rail, keeping pace with my little island as I am slowly carried the length of the vessel.
'Let us bring you aboard!' shouts the captain. 'The current is sweeping you to a certain death.'

xoptx Get on board while you can.

xoptx Bid them farewell.

I watch the vessel slip away from me and dwindle into the distance. Its passing is like a lantern show, a flickering of inexorable images as I pass in and out of consciousness.

I wake with a shout echoing in my ears, but the ship has long gone. The dogs have stopped whimpering. While I slept, one dragged itself to the sledge and lies nuzzled up to me, its head resting on my hand. I don't feel it. The fingers are black.
I think it's grown colder. I'm too weak to look, but I hear the creak of forming ice all around. The floe has stopped moving, anchored once more on a landscape of frozen sea. Something like ash falls from the sky, or rather forms spontaneously in the air - a fine cold powder that I can hardly call snow.

Later still. A white haze. I feel as though my body has sloughed away and I am no more than a shrivelled consciousness, lurking in a nest of warmth in the middle of a world from which all the heat has gone. I am lucid enough to recognize the sensation of warmth as an illusion, the last of the illusions of reality to fall away.
'We have destroyed each other's hopes,' speaks a voice, 'but without satisfying our own desires. It has taken a long journey to discover that.'

xoptx Kill him!

xoptx Talk to him.

Too late for talk of killing. None of it matters any more.
My hand must move towards the pistol, though I can't feel it. He reaches down and takes it from my nerveless fingers.
'What can be worse than to dwell here, driven out from bliss, condemned in this abhorred deep to utter woe?'
He moves around the sledge, so that his wild raw face hangs in the blistering white void before me. That hated face - though I cannot summon up my hatred now. At the brink of death, we would rather have any companionship than face oblivion alone.
 that I have hunted here to the end of the earth. And I am helpless.
'In your murder my crimes are consummated.' The ice shudders under us as he sinks to his knees. 'My miserable existence is wound to its close. Oh, Frankenstein - generous and self-devoted being. What does it avail that I now ask thee to pardon me? I, who irretrievably destroyed thee by destroying all thou lovest.'
'Are those tears? Quote Milton and weep - you have become humanI congratulate you on finally achieving humanity, hypocritical wretch.'
I can hardly make out my own voice. For a moment I am not sure that I even spoke. But he has heard me.
'It is true that I am a wretch. I have murdered the lovely and the helpless. I have strangled the innocent as they slept, and grasped to death the throat of he who never injured me or any other living thing. I have punished you, my creator, paragon of all that is worthy of love and admiration among men, with misery. I have pursued you to this irremediable ruin. No doubt you hate me, but your abhorrence cannot equal that with which I regard myself.'' "We must exasperate the almighty Victor to spend all his rage - and that must end us, that must be our cure." ' He laughs, a harsh rattle in the aristocrat's larynx I gave him. 'Well, there you lie in your incunabulum, creator: a body with but a spark of life in it. You must appreciate the symmetry of the situation.'
'You've won, monster.' I wonder if he can hear me, my voice is so faint. 'Enjoy your triumph as your blood turns to ice and your tissues freeze. Either that or you'll drown when the ice melts again. I, at least, go into the arms of my loved ones. You will be forever alone.'
He leans close. I think of orchards - a fruity odour on his breath. So he is starving to death. I don't think I'll mention that.
'Don't pretend to believe that you expect an afterlife,' he says. 'Or that benevolent God plays nicely with His toys. You created me as a spit in the eye to a senseless, uncaring universe. The oblivion that waits to enfold us is yet more fathomless than the ocean that rolls its thunder under these shores.'
I want to ask him if that's what he intends - to surrender the life I gave him, to die out here beside me on the ice. But the whiteness grows until I can see nothing else. That roar could be the ground sea or my own blood, but in either case it's a dimming tide. I float, and for a moment look down on the sad, misshapen giant and the small limp body beside him. Then I am soaring towards the horizon and -
Nothing.

He pulls off a glove and shows me his huge sinewy hand. 'Here is the hand that executed the deeds. I think of the heart in which they were conceived. And I tell you, Frankenstein, I long for the moment when these sights and thoughts will haunt me no more.
'Fear not that I shall be the instrument of future mischief. My work is nearly complete. Neither yours nor any man's death is needed to accomplish what remains to be done - only my own. Some years ago, when the images this world affords first opened upon me, when I felt the cheering warmth of summer, and heard the rustling of the leaves and the chirping of the birds, and these were all to me, I should have wept to die. Now it is my only consolation. Polluted by crimes, and torn by the bitterest remorse, where can I find rest but in death?
'With fragments of my sledge I will journey to the northernmost extremity of the globe. There I'll build a funeral pyre and this miserable frame you built will soon be consumed to ashes. Thus I shall ensure that nothing remains to guide the curious to create another like myself.
'I shall die. I shall no longer feel the agonies which now consume me, nor be the prey of feelings that can never be satisfied. You who called me into being will soon be dead, and when I am no more the very remembrance of us both will speedily vanish. We shall no longer see the sun or stars, or feel the winds play on our cheeks. Light, feeling, and sense will pass away, and in this condition must I find my happiness.'
I cannot answer him either with forgiveness or with reproach. As he has been speaking, the whiteness has grown blinding until I can see nothing else. That roar could be the ground sea or my own blood, but in either case it's a dimming tide. I float, and for a moment look down on the sad, misshapen giant and the small limp body beside him. Nothing.

Epilogue.

EPILOGUE

Frankenstein is dead. It feels to you as if there were a lifetime of words that now must go unsaid. What difference does it make? All of those words are meaningless.
You rise from beside the sledge. It will be his funeral pyre, and the fire will warm you. Meat from the dogs will give you sustenance for the journey back. In your pocket is his notebook. It tells you everything you need.
A new race of man is coming.Frankenstein is dead. It seems to you as if there were a lifetime of words that now must go unsaid. What difference does it make? All of those words are meaningless.
You rise from beside the sledge. It will be his funeral pyre, and the fire will warm you. Meat from the dogs will give you sustenance for the journey back. You'll survive. You are stronger and more durable than any of the old race of man. However long you have to wait, eventually another will replicate Frankenstein's discoveries.
And you'll be waiting.You hold your creator's hand. You will not long survive him, and what you now feel will be no longer felt. Soon your misery will be over. The light of your funeral pyre will fade away, your ashes will be swept into the sea by the winds, and your spirit will sleep in peace. Or, if it thinks, it will surely not think thus.
The wind and ice surround you to the limits of existence, and the frail, heatless sun looks down. But it knows nothing of the cares of human beings. Nor would it intervene to help them if it did.

I pass out as soon as they carry me below. A little brandy brings me round - they rub me with it, then wrap me in blankets. I'm placed in a cot beside the chimney of the galley-stove. Ah, the pain as circulation comes pricking back into my limbs.

Is it the same day? I realize I know the captain's name - Walton. So we must have spoken, though I have no recollection of it. He's giving me a mug. I hold it between my palms and sip a little soup, more to please him than because I feel hungry. I'm hardly aware of any sensation now. Certainly not in my fingertips. I can see they're dead. The pain will come there later.

Another day? My cot has been moved to the captain's cabin. He's sitting with a book. I don't know how long I've been awake. I frame a question, which emerges from my lips as a deep groan. Walton drops his book and hurries to my side.
'How are you feeling now?'
'Are we under way?' It seems uncivil, but I am having to ration out my words, each one torture to my cracked lips. Again he looks evasive. I remember now. 'Going north?' I press him. 'Must go north.'
'We're still ice-locked,' he says. 'My purpose was to reach the northern Pacific through the seas that surround the pole, and thereby to study the phenomenon of the aurora borealis at close quarters.'
'Was?'
'The men aren't happy about going on. It's unseasonably cold for the time of year, and they fear that worse weather is ahead.'
'I need to go north.' A little brandy is making it easier to talk. 'There is one whom I pursue. If you are going south, I'll trust myself to the mercy of the weather rather than abandon the chase.'
'Another man, out on the ice?'
His tone - he knows something.

We found ourselves surrounded by ice, which closed in around the ship on all sides scarcely leaving her the sea room in which she floated. Our situation was perilous. If the temperature dropped further and the whole sea froze, it could crush the hull. To make matters worse, a thick fog descended. We lay to, hoping for a change in the weather. About two o'clock, the mist cleared away. Stretched out in every direction we saw unending plains of ice. The crew were daunted, and I strove to instil confidence although I too thought our situation very precarious. Then a strange sight attracted our attention. It was a sledge, no more than half a mile off, driven by a man of gigantic stature. I trained my telescope and watched him continue driving his team north, ignoring all our signals, until he was lost among the ice crags.'
'Did you not find that astonishing?'
'Of course. Our reckoning shows us hundreds of miles from the nearest land. I plotted his course on our charts but, shut in by ice, we could not follow. Soon after, we heard the ground sea, and before night the ice broke, freeing the ship. But at night there was a risk of running into the loose ice floes, so I gave the order to lie to till morning. And that's when we found you. At first I thought you were the same man, but he was a giant, as I say.'

I notice some of Walton's scientific instruments mounted on deck. He evidently intends to monitor the electrical and magnetic flux from the aurora. Already I can see several ways that his investigations could be better arranged.

Walton and I are sitting in his cabin. We're wrapped in blankets as there is only coal dust left to go on the stove. Patches of ice have formed on the window, plunging the cabin into gloom. Walton offers me a candle but I am too listless to read.
Half drowsing, I'm brought fully awake by a hammering on the door. Walton is conversing in urgent whispers with half a dozen sailors who insist on coming in. Their leader glances at me, then addresses a long speech in Russian to Walton, who I watch slowly wilting before the vehement demands.
'What is it?' I say in French.
Walton is sitting at his desk and seems not to hear me. It's one of the sailors who replies, using the respectful tones that I've noticed they apply to me, perhaps from awe at the way I arrived in their midst.
'We been chosen as a deputation, sir, is what it is. And what we ask is only what any skipper could not in justice refuse. Being stuck in the ice this last week, most likely we won't never escape, but if heaven was to shine a bit of mercy on us, and a free passage opened up - '
'They fear I will lead them into fresh dangers,' breaks in Walton, as though roused from a stupor. 'They want me to promise that if the ice recedes we'll turn back - abandon the mission.'
'That's it in a nutshell,' agrees one of the other sailors. As an ironic emphasis to his words, the hull at that moment gives a loud creak under the intolerable pressure of the ice, and the men look around with wild eyes.
'I had not yet given up,' Walton says. He's speaking in English, but his gaze is directed not at me but towards the jutting spars of ice outside the window. 'How can I turn back now and relinquish my dream?'
'Then explain why it matters, this voyage. Inspire them.'
'I don't have the gift of authority that you possess.' He turns to me with a pleading look. 'Speak to them, Frankenstein – they respect you. Convince them we must go on.'

I rouse myself to address them, though it takes all of my strength. 'Are you so easily cowed by a spell of bad weather? When you signed on, didn't you recognize this as a glorious expedition? And what made it glorious? Not smooth waters and placid weather, such as sailors in the south enjoy. This is a rugged climate that demands rugged men. The voyage is glorious because it is full of dangers and terror. Because every new incident tests your courage. Because danger surrounds us, and these are dangers you have the strength and experience to overcome. For those reasons is it glorious.'
I don't know how many of them understand French, so I drag myself to my feet and shuffle over to stand behind Walton. I rest my hand on his shoulder, trying not to wince at the stab of pain that leaps up my frostbitten fingers.
'You set sail knowing that you would be acclaimed heroes, benefactors of mankind, brave men who faced death for the universal benefit of your fellows. And now, behold, the first intimation of danger. Here it is – the first real test of your courage, and you shrink away. You are content to be remembered as men who had not strength enough to endure cold and peril. And so, poor souls, they were chilly and returned to their warm firesides. Why, if that was all you hoped to achieve it could have been done with far less trouble. You need not have come this far, and dragged your captain to the shame of a defeat, merely to prove yourselves cowards. Men do that every day, in the southern seas.
'Oh, be men – or be more than men. Be steady to your purpose and firm as a rock. This ice is not made of so strong a stuff as your hearts are. It is mutable, cannot withstand you, if you say that it shall not. Do not return to your families with the stigma of disgrace marked on your brows. Return as heroes who have fought and conquered, and who know not what it is to turn their backs on the foe.'
That's it. All of my strength is used up. Seeing this, Walton makes way for me to sit in his chair. Outside, a crag of ice breaks and falls to the water with a soft boom, allowing a shaft of clear white sunlight into the cabin. The men are silent in its glare. Convinced? I don't know. But thoughtful, certainly.
Walton sends them all back to their posts. He's high-spirited now – he thinks my words have swayed them. I feel the fever eating me within. I'm dying.

Perhaps, but not yet.

'How can I tell them that? See what my own endeavours have brought me to, Walton. I had a dream, a vision for mankind, and it has blighted my life. Far from exhorting your crewmen to continue, I urge you to reconsider. Return home, find a wife, have children. Eschew ambition - live out your days as all your forbears did. In striving for a better world, man creates ruins and ash. In searching for the universe's secrets, we only succeed in unlocking the casket of woe.'
I sit a long time contemplating my own words. I am broken and feverish. When I look up, the room seems darker. The men have gone and there is no sign of Walton. The stove is cold but I am too weak to light it, and in any case the coal is used up.

I wake, still alone, and strain my ears but the only sounds are the soft groan of the hull as ice grips it, and the occasional muffled splash as icebergs split and fall into the half-congealed water.

Up on deck now. I don't know how I made it. I lean against the rail, my pulse thundering in my ears. The shrouds hang bare in a thick white fog that hides the top of the masts from view. Where is everyone? I see shadowy figures whirling in the haze, but there's no sound of voices.
Ah - I slipped. The deck is treacherous with ice. Can't get up. I'm too weak. I shout, but the sound is swallowed up. Where are they all? I start to pull myself back towards the companionway. Every inch is agonizing, my fingers feel as if the skin has been peeled away and the raw nerves are being etched with acid.

I'm back in the cabin. Did I dream that I went above? No, see the dampness of the fog on my sleeve. But if I'm awake, where are they all?
I hear a tread in the passage outside. Too heavy to be Walton or any of his crew. I'm not alone, then. Adom has come for me.He has come for me.

xoptx This is your chance to kill him.

xoptx Talk to him.

My guns - there on Walton's desk, but out of reach. Still stretched helpless on the floor, it takes all my strength to twist around as his footsteps approach. I must face my tormentor at the end, at least.
Even if my weapons were in reach, to what end? I've had enough of killing. At least it will end now.
He fills the frame of the door, having to twist his hulking torso to enter the cabin so that for a moment he resembles one of those corpses unearthed after being buried alive, their rigorous limbs pressed taut against the confines of the wood. His flesh gleams like fresh blood in the weak daylight. As he steps closer, he is able to straighten up, but even so his angular head still bumps against the cabin ceiling, and the very mass of him seems to press the air and light away. I had forgotten his size. I feel as an inhabitant of a doll's house might feel, when the wall is suddenly thrown open and a giant child intrudes its looming face and limbs and vital energy.

He spins a chair. It is Walton's corpse, face dark in death. So that was how his dreams of adventure ended. I think of the devoted sister who will wait out the rest of her life with no news of his fate.
I blink away tears, but I don't know if my sorrow is for him or for myself.

I want to ask him if that's what he intends - to surrender the life I gave him, to die out here in the deserted ship. But I cannot speak or hear for the thundering in my ears.
