Epilogue.

He presents to me his red right hand. 'Here is the instrument that executed my evil deeds. I think of the heart in which they were conceived. And I tell you, Frankenstein, I long for the moment when these sights and thoughts will haunt me no more.
'Fear not that I shall be the instrument of future mischief. My work is nearly complete. Neither yours nor any man's death is needed to accomplish what remains to be done - only my own. Some years ago, when the images this world affords first opened upon me, when I felt the cheering warmth of summer, and heard the rustling of the leaves and the chirping of the birds, and these were all to me, I should have wept to die. Now it is my only consolation. Polluted by crimes, and torn by the bitterest remorse, where can I find rest but in death?
'With wood from this vessel I will journey to the northernmost extremity of the globe. There I'll build a funeral pyre and this miserable frame you built will soon be consumed to ashes. Thus I shall ensure that nothing remains to guide the curious to create another like myself. I shall die. I shall no longer feel the agonies which now consume me, nor be the prey of feelings that can never be satisfied. You who called me into being will soon be dead, and when I am no more the very remembrance of us both will speedily vanish. We shall no longer see the sun or stars, or feel the winds play on our cheeks. Light, feeling, and sense will pass away, and in this condition must I find my happiness.'
I cannot answer him either with forgiveness or with reproach. As he has been speaking, the whiteness has grown blinding until I can see nothing else. I float, and for a moment look down on the sad, misshapen giant and the small limp body beside him. I feel the nearness of that wing which no man can avoid and darkness closes over everything.

Epilogue.

EPILOGUE

You rise from beside the body, uncertain of your feelings even now. Is it possible to love and hate at the same time? Frankenstein, your creator, is dead. You are resolved: this whole ship will become a conflagration, the funeral pyre on which he will enter whatever world exists beyond this one. You were dust of the ground and he breathed life into you, and for that he deserves exaltation.
The man can die, but the ideas need never do, for in your pocket you have his notebook still. It describes every detail of your creation. You take it out and stroke the cover, breath in the sacred aroma of ink and chemicals from the page. Such a precious text. You'll guard it well.
It is the Bible for the new race of man that is to come.You rise from beside the body, uncertain of your feelings even now. Is it possible to love and hate at the same time? Frankenstein, your creator, is dead. You are resolved: this whole ship will become a conflagration, the funeral pyre on which he will enter whatever world exists beyond this one. You were dust of the ground and he breathed life into you, and for that he deserves exaltation.
Between here and civilization lie a thousand miles of ice, but you'll survive. You are stronger and more durable than any of the old race of man. However long you have to wait, eventually another will replicate Frankenstein's discoveries.
And you will be waiting.When we are young, don't we all feel destined for greatness? I did. My feelings were deep, but that passion was coupled to a cool judgement that fitted me for illustrious achievements. Confident of the worth of my nature, I was able to persevere where others would have given up, for it would have been dereliction not to use my talents for the good of mankind. When I reflected on what I had accomplished - nothing less than the inception of a living, rational creature, I could not rank myself among the common herd.
But this feeling, which supported me at the start of my career, later served only to plunge me lower in the dust. All my speculations and hopes were as nothing and, like the archangel who aspired to omnipotence, I was chained in an eternal hell.
My imagination was vivid and my powers of analysis and application were intense. By the union of these qualities I was able to conceive of instilling life and to carry out the creation of a man. Even now, at the end, when I think of those early days when my project was still incomplete, I burn with the passion of my ideals. I trod heaven in my thoughts, exulting in my genius, transported by the vision of what I would achieve. I was ambitious, and ambition is a merciless sun. My genius proved to bear me on Icarian wings. I have had a long time to contemplate the greatness of my fall.
But here is the final darkness. The world has shrunk to a point of light. It is fading. I am fading. There is nothing else.
You hold your creator's hand. You will not long survive him, and what you now feel will be no longer felt. Soon your misery will be over. The light of your funeral pyre will fade away, your ashes will be swept into the sea by the winds, and your spirit will sleep in peace. Or, if it thinks, it will surely not think thus.
The wind and ice surround you to the limits of existence, and the frail, heatless sun looks down. But it knows nothing of the cares of human beings. Nor would it intervene to help them if it did.

This morning the ice began to move. From all around us comes a continual roar like muffled thunder as the floes split and crack in every direction. Occasionally, very close at hand, I hear the boom and splash as a boulder of ice detaches itself from the immuring crags and plummets hissing into the deeps below. We are in the most imminent peril but, as we can only remain passive, Walton sits with me in his cabin, hoping to distract himself by a conversation that, in my weakened state, is increasingly one-sided.
'The ice is breaking behind us, and with this breeze from the west I am sure that a passage to the south will soon become clear.'
I have no energy to waste on a reply, but he seems to expect none. I doze for a short while, and wake to hear a tumultuous shouting from up on deck. Walton has just come back into the cabin. As he hangs up his coat, he sees my eyes are open.
'They are cheering because they will soon return home.'
'You really mean to go back?'
'Alas, I cannot withstand their demands. I cannot lead them unwillingly to danger.'
As I hear him say this, I realize I have been expecting it for days. I feel, not passion, but the need for passion. 'Return if you will,' I tell him, 'but I will not. You may give up your purpose, but mine is assigned to me by Heaven. I am weak, but surely the spirits who assist my vengeance will endow me with sufficient strength.'
I try to rise from the bed but even that little speech has spent me up. Fingers of darkness spread over my vision.

I come to. I cannot tell how long I was unconscious, but Walton and the man who serves as the ship's doctor are both beside me. I see from the looks they exchange the truth that they will not put into words.
I raise my head feebly. 'Now
My strength has deserted me. I will die soon, and in these final hours left to me I cannot help but dwell on the thought that the monster is out there, still alive, his malignity undimmed.
It is not revenge or hatred that I speak of now, those are gone, but I feel I am justified in desiring the death of my enemy. These last few days have given me time to reflect on my conduct. I do not find it blameable - or, if it is, then a young man's lack of wisdom must be a deadly sin. In a fit of enthusiastic madness I created a rational creature, and so was responsible for his happiness and welfare. In that I failed. Later, he called upon my sense of duty to provide him with a mate - and I was weighed down by a sense of guilt. I knew I had done wrong, and I pitied him. But I had also a duty to my fellow man, and so I refused - and did right in refusing - to create a female to be his companion.
He showed unparalleled selfishness and evil. He murdered my friends. And I call that evil not because they were my friends, but because they were human beings who possessed exquisite sensations, love, and wisdom. They had not harmed him - were unaware of his existence. He destroyed them only to cause me pain. Nor do I know where his thirst for vengeance may end. Without me to torment, all mankind could become his enemy. Miserable himself, he will render others wretched. For that he ought to die. The task of his destruction was mine, but that is another duty in which I have failed.

Epilogue.

The creature looks at Walton as though he were but a phenomenon of nature: a leaf that had drifted to the ground, or a drop of rain in a puddle. Turning back towards the lifeless body on the bed, he seems to tremble in the grip of uncontrollable emotion.
'So here is my last victim. In his death my crimes are consummated, and my existence is wound to its close. Oh, Frankenstein, generous and self-devoted being - what does it avail that I now ask thee to pardon me? I, who irretrievably destroyed thee by destroying all thou lovest. 'Are you dreaming?' says the creature. 'Do you think that I am dead to agony and remorse? He suffered not a ten-thousandth portion of the anguish that has been mine. A frightful selfishness hurried me on, while my heart was poisoned with remorse. Think ye that the groans of his brother William were music to my ears? My heart was fashioned to be susceptible of love and sympathy - and, when wrenched by misery to vice and hatred, it did not endure the violence of the change without torture such as you cannot imagine.'
He falls to his knees beside the body. Walton's eyes go to the pistol on the desk, but wisely he makes no attempt to reach it.

I recollected my threat and resolved that it should be accomplished. I knew that I was preparing for myself a deadly torture - but I was the slave, not the master, of an impulse which I detested, yet could not disobey. Yet when she died - ! Nay, then I was not miserable. I had cast off all feeling, subdued all anguish, to riot in the excess of my despair. Evil thenceforth became my good. Urged thus far, I had no choice but to adapt my nature to an element that I had willingly chosen. The completion of my demoniacal design became an insatiable passion. And now it is ended. Even after the deathmurder of Clerval, our enmity could have ended in an armistice. He prises the gun from Walton's hand, but gently, and tosses it into the corner of the cabin. Then, bracing himself to leap from the window, he says, 'You think me crudely made? Study these remote spaces of the globe - these inhospitable wastes, these deserts and ice-fields. We may let you live in them. But your time in Eden, man, has come to an end.'
He springs from the window to the ice-raft that lies close to the vessel. I would follow him, and see where he goes and what befalls him, but my part in his life is over. The scene recedes and soon is lost in darkness and distance.

Epilogue.

'You are the one he pursued...' says Walton. 'The giant.'
'We pursued each other, both victims.'
Walton looks towards the pistol on his desk. He wisely makes no move towards it, but in coming further into the cabin he gets a closer look at the monstrous form in front of him, which gloves and fur cloak had previously concealed.
'What are you?' he says with a gasp.
'Frankenstein's shadow - or his child, or his guilt. The thing he tried to bury. What does it matter? I have hounded him to death, but while I succeeded in destroying his hopes, I did not satisfy my own desires.'
The creature springs to the window, startling Walton with his agility. I see again that he is like a great ape rather than a malformed man. There is something majestic about him. Or is that only the residue of my pride?

'I leave you,' he says, 'and in you the last of humankind whose eyes will ever behold this monstrous form. Farewell, Frankenstein! If thou wert yet alive, and yet cherished a desire of revenge against me, it would be better satiated in my life than in my destruction. But it was not so. Thou didst seek my extinction that I might not cause greater wretchedness. And if yet, in some mode unknown to me, thou hast not ceased to think and feel, thou wouldst not desire against me a vengeance greater than that which I feel. Cursed as thou wert, my agony was still superior to thine, for the bitter sting of remorse may not cease to rankle in my wounds until death shall close them for ever. But soon I shall die, and what I now feel be no longer felt. Soon these burning miseries will be extinct. I shall ascend my funeral pyre triumphantly, and exult in the agony of the torturing flames. The light of that conflagration will fade away; my ashes will be swept into the sea by the winds. My spirit will sleep in peace - or, if it thinks, it will not surely think thus.'
'I leave you,' he says, 'to carry back the mortal remains of my creator. Farewell, Frankenstein! In life I desired only your suffering, but now I forgive you your crimes against me. Your body I will see enshrined - the saint and progenitor of a new race. Or perhaps I will meet my end out here on the ice, and your species will be spared. Suffer as you did, my agony was far greater, for the bitter sting of injustice will never cease to rankle in my breast, and even had you died a hundred deaths it would burn still. And if, in some mode unknown to me, you have not ceased to think and feel, perhaps you experience a peace that I will never know. Farewell!'
He springs from the window to the ice-raft that lies close to the vessel. I would follow him, and see where he goes and what befalls him, but my part in his life is over. The image below me recedes and soon is lost in darkness and distance.

Epilogue.

EPILOGUE

Remember the tree I told you about? The one I saw blasted from existence by lightning?When I was a youth, I saw a tree blasted by lightning - completely destroyed, as though it was part of the drawing that the artist had decided to erase. At that moment I conceived the idea of the universe as a locked gate for which we, as children, hope to steal the key. That was where my mistakes began.
We start as children, but are not bound to remain so. Here is Eden - it's all around us, not a lost secret from which we are excluded. The failure to believe in the possibility of our own salvation is what traps us in the cage of the past. In ceding moral authority to distant figures, we absolve ourselves of blame and at the same time abandon responsibility for the trail of decisions that constitute our lives.
The truth is that there is almost no act, if it could but be forgiven, from which a man cannot be redeemed. Men are never monsters, though they can suffer from monstrousness. If the serpent is part of us then the divine is too, and that should warrant neither shame nor pride. What I learned too late is that it is always possible to rise above the one. Goodness is there waiting, not as forbidden fruit on the bough of a mysterious tree, but plainly in the heart.
Am I talking about myself, or Adommy creature? Or all mankind? I have reached that moment when there is no longer any distinction. The world has shrunk to an infinite point. It is fading. I am fading. There is nothing else.When we are young, don't we all feel destined for greatness? I did. My feelings were deep, but that passion was coupled to a cool judgement that fitted me for illustrious achievements. Confident of the worth of my nature, I was able to persevere where others would have given up, for it would have been dereliction not to use my talents for the good of mankind.
But this sentiment was uncoupled to the wisdom and compassion that I should have developed. I saw only the goal, not the purpose that should have lain behind it, and when I had accomplished my goal, instead of a living being that turned to me and deserved my guidance, I saw only an experiment that I wished to abort.
It was not evil, it was ambition, and ambition is a merciless sun towards which my genius bore me on Icarian wings. I have had a long time to contemplate the greatness of my fall.
But here is the final darkness. As I surrender to it, everything of my life is unwrapped and cast away. Sparks of memory, perhaps no more than electricity and chemicals, break down into the void of unbeing. But here is the final darkness. The world has shrunk to a point of light. It is fading. I have had a long time to contemplate the greatness of my fall.
But here is the final darkness. As I surrender to it, everything of my life is unwrapped and cast away. Sparks of memory, perhaps no more than electricity and chemicals, break down into the void of unbeing. And the single thought that hovers when my mind has all but gone is a realization that comes too late: the monster I made was myself.When we are young, don't we all feel destined for greatness? I did. My feelings were deep, but that passion was coupled to a cool judgement that fitted me for illustrious achievements. Confident of the worth of my nature, I was able to persevere where others would have given up, for it would have been dereliction not to use my talents for the good of mankind. When I reflected on what I had accomplished - nothing less than the inception of a living, rational creature, I could not rank myself among the common herd.
But this feeling, which supported me at the start of my career, later served only to plunge me deeper in the dust. All my speculations and hopes were as nothing and, like the archangel who aspired to omnipotence, I was chained in an eternal hell.
My imagination was vivid and my powers of analysis and application were intense. By the union of these qualities I was able to conceive of instilling life and to carry out the creation of a man. Even now, at the end, when I think of those early days when my project was still incomplete, I burn with the passion of my ideals. I trod heaven in my thoughts, exulting in my genius, transported by the vision of what I would achieve. I was ambitious, and ambition is a merciless sun. My genius proved to bear me on Icarian wings. I have had a long time to contemplate the greatness of my fall.
But here is the final darkness. The world has shrunk to a point of light. It is fading. I am fading. There is nothing else.


THE END

Interactive fiction by Dave Morris
